Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLOOD, CHARLES ANDREW
Snippets: FLOOD--Charles Andrew, 77, died at his home in New York City on December 23 with his adored wife Kristin by his side. Born in New York City, Charlie was a graduate of Riverdale Country Day School and Amherst College. He spent his early investment career at M.A. Shapiro, New Court Securities, and E.M. Warburg Pincus. For the past 32 years, Charlie and Kristin were business partners of Flood Gamble Associates, an investment management firm. Recently, Flood Gamble joined American Capital Management. Charlie was a dedicated and scrupulously honest businessperson who brought his deep intelligence to his tireless work for his clients. He enjoyed getting to know people of all backgrounds and loved nothing more than the everyday banter he had with friends, clients, neighbors, and everyone he encountered. He had a unique sense of humor and enjoyed gently ribbing people. His weekends were spent gardening and doing chores-Charlie's way of relaxing-in their second home and beloved community of Hudson, New York. Charlie loved the Hudson Valley and, with Kristin, was dedicated to the protection of the Hudson River and its environs. A lifelong Democrat and avid Obama supporter, Charlie enjoyed talking politics and railing against what he felt were the wrongs in society. He also contributed to many social causes. Charlie learned guitar as an adult and his playing and singing were an integral part of his time spent with family. A much-loved spouse, father, and grandfather, Charlie will be greatly missed by his wife of 40 years, Kristin Gamble, his daughters Deborah Flood and Karen Flood, his son-in-law Michael Benedek, and his grandchildren Naomi, Oscar and Violet. A celebration of Charlie will be held at 4:30pm on January 7 at the Metropolitan Club at 1 East 60th Street in New York City. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Scenic Hudson at http://www.scenic hudson.org/donate, or Scenic Hudson, Attn: Veronica Renzo, One Civic Center Plaza, Suite 200, Poughkeepsie, NY 12601. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHORT, STEPHEN
Snippets: SHORT--Stephen. June 11, 1945-December 12, 2015. Stephen Short, a former Procter of the Admiralty, who also served in the Merchant Marine, passed away on December 12th. A longtime member of the New York State bar, his legal career encompassed maritime, criminal and personal injury law. In his youth, Mr. Short was also a gifted athlete, excelling as a swimmer, skier, sailor and avid tennis player. He was also deemed an Olympic caliber fencer by Maestro Odon Niederkirchner, of the NYAC. A colorful figure and lifelong champion of the underdog, he will be missed by all who loved him, including his sisters, Leslie Blake and Cheryl Bulbach and his brother, Dr. Wayne Blackmon. As per his wishes, Mr. Short's corneas were donated to the Eye Bank for Sight Restoration. A Memorial will be held in mid-January at the Village Funeral Home. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLANTZ, IRWIN L.
Snippets: GLANTZ--Irwin L.,91, died peacefully at home on December 26, 2015 after a brief illness, with his loving family at his side. He is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, Gene; devoted children Paul, Judith Kingman, and Robert; grandchildren Alexander and Garrett Kingman and Michelle and David Glantz, and nephew Bruce Kauderer. A consummate gentleman, he was a World War II veteran, lawyer, founder of real estate development, investment and management firm, Windsor Properties, and esteemed patriarch of his extended family. His patience, wisdom, optimism, generosity and strong family values will be sorely missed by all who were privileged to know him. Laid to rest in Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, New York on December 28, 2015. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEIGER, MELISSA BROWN WILEY
Snippets: GEIGER--Melissa Brown Wiley, died of natural causes in New York City on Saturday, December 19, 2015 surrounded by her loving family. Born in Bay Shore, NY in 1937, she was the oldest child of Melissa Adams and Robert Hoffman Wiley. Melissa graduated from Spring Valley High School, Spring Valley, NY in 1955. She attended Skidmore College and married in 1957. Howard and Melissa began their marriage at Dartmouth College. Howard's career brought them to many places: Munich, Germany; New Jersey; Minneapolis; San Francisco and finally settling down in Manhattan in 1987. Their lifelong home was on Lake George in Putnam, NY. Melissa brought music and friendship wherever she went; these passions defined her life. An extremely talented pianist, she played the organ for her church beginning at age 12. Melissa played an active role in her children's education, always volunteering, often as the accompanist for school musical productions. She sang in the Plymouth Church Choir and with the Plymouth Music Series. She supported the Minnesota Opera. Melissa was the Minister of Music, Organist and Choir Director at Suffern Presbyterian Church in Suffern, NY. While living in San Francisco, she sang in the Unitarian Church Choir and was a board member of The San Francisco Chamber Singers, now called Volti. In Manhattan, she joined the music department of the Rudolf Steiner School as a faculty member and retired in 2002. Melissa joined The Riverside Church in 1988 committed to making our world a better place through music. She was a member of The Riverside Choir, the Riverside Choral Society, served as Music Committee chair, raised funds for the Men's Shelter and was actively involved in the founding of the Catherine Van Buren Endowment Fund and the Friends of Music. She most recently enjoyed spending time with her children, grandchildren, friends, and her dog. Melissa is survived by her children, Melissa Ann Geiger (Paul Marvin) of New York, NY, Kirsten Geiger Rider (Harold) of Winnetka, IL, Howard (Skip) Wilton Geiger III of New York, NY, Christopher Wiley Geiger of Larkspur, CA and her brother, William Adams Wiley (Lynn) of Grantham, NH; nine grandchildren, Paul and Oliver Marvin of New York, NY, Harold, Sarah and Christopher Rider of Winnetka, IL, Lillian Geiger of New York, NY, Wiley, Bourke and Finley Geiger of Larkspur, CA as well as many adored nieces, nephews and her beloved dog Libee. Her husband of 56 years, Howard Wilton and her brother, George Martin Wiley III, predeceased Melissa. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Friends of Music, The Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive, New York, NY, 10027. Services will be held at The Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive, New York, NY at 12:00pm on Monday, January 4. A memorial reception will immediately follow. There will be additional opportunities to meet with family and friends. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKLER, RUTH
Snippets: DICKLER--Ruth. It is with deep sadness that we note the passing of Mrs. Ruth Dickler who first joined The Citizens Housing & Planning Council as a volunteer in 1962, where she began to build and shape our archival library. She was an important resource for New York City's researchers, academics, and students. Upon her retirement she became a member of CHPC's Board of Directors. A talented writer and editor, her research and organizational skills helped to shape CHPC's work for nearly five decades. A mentor and friend to all of us at CHPC, her legacy continues in the historic library that bares her name. Our heartfelt condolences to her family and friends and to our city which has lost a great lady. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, ELLSWORTH
Snippets: KELLY--Ellsworth. The Board of Directors and the staff of the Foundation for Contemporary Arts notes with sorrow the passing of Ellsworth Kelly. His unique artistic vision and his consistent generosity were unparalleled examples of how one artist's work and life can enrich so many. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, ELLSWORTH
Snippets: KELLY--Ellsworth. Pratt Institute is saddened by the loss of one of the most defining abstract painters of our time, Ellsworth Kelly, who studied at the institution in the 1940s. Minimal in form, bold in color, and widely influential, Kelly's work is featured in prominent museums, galleries, and private collections across the globe. As a true pioneer extending the boundaries of creativity, Kelly will be revered for his iconic style and artistic vision for generations to come. Pratt Institute Board of Trustees Chairman Bruce Gitlin, President Thomas F. Schutte 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREILICH, DR
Snippets: FREILICH--Dr. Gerald. Emeritus professor of mathematics at Queens College of SUNY who specialized in geometric measure theory, passed away on December 27th, 2015 at age 88. Professor Freilich was the author of several books and many research articles and reviews in academic journals. He was a former governor of the Mathematical Association of America as well as Chairman of the New York Metropolitan Section and served on the national panel of the Committee on the Undergraduate Program of Mathematics. Born in Brooklyn, he received a bachelor's degree, Summa Cum Laude, from City College in 1946 and a Doctorate in Mathematics from Brown University in 1949. He taught at Brown University and then at City College of New York, advancing to full professor and Chairman of the Mathematics Department in 1966. During those years, he was an original member of the organizing Committee of the SUNY Doctoral Program and single-handedly established the SUNY graduate Mathematics Library. He also taught at Wesleyan University as a visiting professor. He joined the faculty of Queens College in 1971 and taught there until his retirement in 1995. Professor Freilich served in the US Navy in World War II. After the war, he was a Lieutenant J.G. in the Navy Reserves. He also did research for the National Ordinance Lab on helicopters and submarines. He was survived by Marion (nee Freudenberger) after 62 years of marriage. He is also survived by his brother Dr. Herbert Feilich and children Sandra Novetsky (Dr. Gary) and Dr. David Freilich (Erica) as well as eight grandchildren and six great-grandchildren and many nephews and nieces. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  DWEK, JOE
Snippets: DWEK--Joe. On behalf of the entire New York-Presbyterian/Queens family, we are saddened by the passing of Joe Dwek, M.D., an admired and respected physician, who joined the staff at NewYork- Presbyterian/Queens (then Booth Memorial Hospital) in 1965. Dr. Dwek was chairman of the Department of Medicine and program director from 1973-1989 and was chairman of Academic Affairs from 1989-93. Our sincere condolences to Dr. Dwek's wife Sally, his children and grandchildren, and the many people whose lives he influenced. Stephen S. Mills, President Gary Zuar, Chairman, Board of Trustees Ruby Malva, M.D., President, Medical Staff Society Jack Mann, M.D., President, Medical Board NewYork- Presbyterian/Queens 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIFKIN, COMRAS, BLANCHE
Snippets: RIFKIN-COMRAS--Blanche. Passed away December 31, 2015 at the age of 99. Loving wife to the late Oscar Comras and Louis Rifkin; Dear sister to Gertrude Goldstein; Beloved mother to Madelyn Katz (Albert) and Donald Comras (Albert Husted); Adored grandmother of Jay Katz and David Katz (Lauren Hurvitz); Ecstatic great- grandmother of Sam Katz, Amanda Katz, Natalie Katz, CC Katz, and Lila Katz; Cherished aunt to all her nieces and nephews. A bundle of energy and pillar of the community, she worked tirelessly for: The Advisory Board of Jacobi Hospital; The Advisory Board of Einstein/Montefiore; Member of the Community Board 11 for 30 years; The Board of Directors of Bronx House; and National Council of Jewish Women. Services will be held at the Shalom Jewish Funeral Home, 1528 Castle Hill Avenue, Bronx on Sunday, January 3, 2016 at 11:30am. Interment: Mt. Hebron Cemetery. Donations in her name may be made to: www.bronxhouse.org or to: www.ujafedny.org. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLOOD, CHARLES ANDREW
Snippets: FLOOD--Charles Andrew, 77, died at his home in New York City on December 23 with his adored wife Kristin by his side. Born in New York City, Charlie was a graduate of Riverdale Country Day School and Amherst College. He spent his early investment career at M.A. Shapiro, New Court Securities, and E.M. Warburg Pincus. For the past 32 years, Charlie and Kristin were business partners of Flood Gamble Associates, an investment management firm. Recently, Flood Gamble joined American Capital Management. Charlie was a dedicated and scrupulously honest businessperson who brought his deep intelligence to his tireless work for his clients. He enjoyed getting to know people of all backgrounds and loved nothing more than the everyday banter he had with friends, clients, neighbors, and everyone he encountered. He had a unique sense of humor and enjoyed gently ribbing people. His weekends were spent gardening and doing chores-Charlie's way of relaxing-in their second home and beloved community of Hudson, New York. Charlie loved the Hudson Valley and, with Kristin, was dedicated to the protection of the Hudson River and its environs. A lifelong Democrat and avid Obama supporter, Charlie enjoyed talking politics and railing against what he felt were the wrongs in society. He also contributed to many social causes. Charlie learned guitar as an adult and his playing and singing were an integral part of his time spent with family. A much-loved spouse, father, and grandfather, Charlie will be greatly missed by his wife of 40 years, Kristin Gamble, his daughters Deborah Flood and Karen Flood, his son-in-law Michael Benedek, and his grandchildren Naomi, Oscar and Violet. A celebration of Charlie will be held at 4:30pm on January 7 at the Metropolitan Club at 1 East 60th Street in New York City. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Scenic Hudson at http://www.scenic hudson.org/donate, or Scenic Hudson, Attn: Veronica Renzo, One Civic Center Plaza, Suite 200, Poughkeepsie, NY 12601. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, JOEL "GONK," DIED ON TUESDAY
Snippets: KAPLAN--Joel "Gonk," died on Tuesday, December 29, 2015, in his home in Wallkill, NY after a long illness. He was born in Brooklyn and was the son of the late Florence and Harry Kaplan. He was predeceased by his twin brother Ira Kaplan. He is survived by his loving wife Carol Kaplan; sons Laurence Berland and Noah Berland; brothers Steven Kaplan and Richard Kaplan; sister-in-law Jo-Ann Segal; brother-in-law Keith Crossley; sisters-in-law Denise Kaplan, Ann Johnson, and Sherry Kaplan; nieces and nephews Michelle Kratochvil, Michael Kaplan, Rachel Newell, and Casiel Kaplan. Joel was a true Renaissance Man and salt of the earth who was loved by all he touched. He will be deeply missed by all. Donations can be made to the Perlmutter Cancer Center, NYU Langone Medical Center, Lung Cancer Research Fund. Graveside service Sunday, 11am, Wellwood Cemetery. For further information, visit www.jewish-funeral- home.com. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTE, JUDITH SHEREFF
Snippets: HARTE--Judith Shereff, of Livingston, NJ, passed away in New York City on Wednesday, December 30, 2015 after a long and courageous fight with lung cancer. She was 77. Judi was an amazing mother, grandmother, sister, and woman. She enjoyed gardening, reading, painting, sculpting, music and building and fixing things. For a small person, Judi had a huge heart and always opened up her home and her heart to help others. After Hurricane Sandy, she had many displaced people stay with her for extended periods of time and never felt like it was too much; instead, she always said that she wished they would stay longer since she really enjoyed being with them and helping them. Judi was born to Abraham and Rose Shereff on June 18, 1938 in New York City and raised in Forest Hills, NY. She was preceded in death by her parents. Judi is survived by her brother and sister-in-law Richard and Susan Shereff; daughter Helaine Harte and son-in-law David Rhode, her sons and daughters-in-law Douglas and Ronni Harte and Jonathan and Belynda Harte; and the pride of her life, her grandchildren, Alex and Haleigh Harte and Tyler, Casey and Rebecca Rhode. Judi loved all animals. After being a teacher and raising her children, she worked at Turtle Back Zoo in West Orange, NJ, and spent many years rescuing and rehabilitating injured and orphaned wild animals and birds. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to The Turtle Back Zoo in Judi's honor. Funeral service will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 630 Amsterdam Avenue in New York City at 11:30am on Sunday, January 3rd. 1/3

Snippets: STEVENS--Herbert J. 23 years have not dimmed the superb memories we shared. Remembering you forever. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  SABATINE, CAROL ROTH
Snippets: SABATINE--Carol Roth. Died peacefully of a rare neurodegenerative brain disease on November 12th, at the age of 80. A native of Port Huron, Michigan (born July 3, 1935), she graduated from the University of Michigan Architecture and Design School (1957). Soon after, she moved to New York City to begin a career in interior design. In 1960, she married Leo E. Sabatine (died 1976). She dedicated her life to raising her two sons and to volunteer work. She was a fixture in Brooklyn Heights, the neighborhood where she lived for over 40 years. She will be remembered for her kindness, elegance and utmost generosity. Along with serving on the vestry at Grace Church Brooklyn Heights, she served numerous executive positions, including president, for the Brooklyn Woman's Exchange and Brooklyn Heights Garden Club. She had a great interest in the arts and culture, loved travelling with her sons, enjoyed playing and watching tennis, and spending time at her beloved beach club. Her brain was donated for research to the Mass General Hospital Frontotemporal Disorders Unit. She is survived by her loving sons, Michael and Edward, by her daughter-in-law Marcela, and granddaughter, Maria Carolina, brother, John R. Roth (Karen), sisters Miriam L. Roth and Judith R. Armstrong (Ned). A memorial service will be held at Grace Church Brooklyn Heights, at 11am on January 9th. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIELINSKI, ERICA HERZIG
Snippets: ZIELINSKI--Erica Herzig, of Old Bridge, NJ and formerly of Manalapan, NJ and Manhattan, passed away at her home on Sunday, December 27th. She received her master's degree from Columbia University and became a nurse practitioner, specializing in women's health for over 40 years, most recently at New York University. She retired in December 2014. Erica is survived by her loving husband of 32 years, Thomas James Zielinski of Old Bridge; son, Adam Zielinski of Asbury Park; daughter, Brenna Zielinski of Manhattan; and sister, Beth Herzig of Miami. Family and friends are invited to gather at the Old Bridge Funeral Home, 2350 Rt. 516, Old Bridge, NJ 08857 on Saturday, January 9, 2016 from 10:30am to 12:30pm for a memorial visitation. There will be a memorial service beginning at 12:30pm at the funeral home. In lieu of flowers, Erica's family requests you donate to "The Erica Herzig- Zielinski Charitable Fund" more information can be found at www.oldbridge fh.com. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLANTZ, IRWIN L.
Snippets: GLANTZ--Irwin L.,91, died peacefully at home on December 26, 2015 after a brief illness, with his loving family at his side. He is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, Gene; devoted children Paul, Judith Kingman, and Robert; grandchildren Alexander and Garrett Kingman and Michelle and David Glantz, and nephew Bruce Kauderer. A consummate gentleman, he was a World War II veteran, lawyer, founder of real estate development, investment and management firm, Windsor Properties, and esteemed patriarch of his extended family. His patience, wisdom, optimism, generosity and strong family values will be sorely missed by all who were privileged to know him. Laid to rest in Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, New York on December 28, 2015. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCHBERG, IRVING
Snippets: HIRSCHBERG--Irving, resident of Amagansett, NY, died suddenly on December 30th at age 88. He was predeceased by his beloved wife, Phyllis. He is survived by his two daughters, Lise and Wendy, sister Shirlee (Geri Grossman), and his grandson Miles Emanuel. He retired as an accomplished electrical engineer at Fairchild Camera. He had a major impact on the East End community. Irving was a tutor of ESL students at East Hampton High School, a friend to senior citizens through R.S.V.P. and an active Democrat. He was devoted to his tennis and golf games. Irving was a loyal and generous friend to many. Contributions may be made in his memory: Cinema Arts Centre, Huntington, Long Island or the Southern Poverty Law Center. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, MARJORIE
Snippets: GORDON--Marjorie. Passed away on December 8, 2015. A kind and generous person with a great sense of humor, she was devoted to her many friends and students. She taught at many universities and music camps, and was the founder of the Detroit Opera Theater, the Detroit Piccolo Opera, and co-founded "Adventures in Music" for the Detroit Public School system. She made her operatic debut with the New York Philharmonic, and went on to sing with the best orchestras in the country. She gave recitals with her violist husband, Nathan Gordon in Greece, Europe, Canada, and Israel. She was a member of many musical organizations, including the Florida Music Teachers Association, the National Teachers Association, and the Broward County Music Club. She left one child, Peter Gordon and three grandchildren, Ted and Josh Gordon and Douglas Schwartz. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDLER, SHELDON
Snippets: SEIDLER--Sheldon. October 25, 1930-November 23, 2015. Renowned graphic designer, painter, sculptor, teacher. Father to Elana Werts and Heidi Sanchez. Grandfather to Matt, Kody and Ariel. Forever in our hearts. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, BARAN
Snippets: ROSEN--Baran. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the loss of our longtime, dedicated member Baran Rosen, beloved husband of Margery Rosen. We will miss his devotion to family, friends and community. Our deepest condolences to Margery, their children, Sarah and Michael, and all dear ones. Robert N. Levine, D.D., Senior Rabbi Martin Flumenbaum, President 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENFELD, HENRY
Snippets: ROSENFELD--Henry. Henry passed away peacefully in his home on December 26, 2015. He is survived by his children Jessica, Diego (Heidi), Julia, grandchildren and brother Albert. Henry was an elegant man with a strong moral compass, a passion for world affairs and Israel. He was born in Chile and travelled throughout South America with his family for business in film, settling in Argentina. After graduating Columbia University and falling in love with America he raised a family with his late wife Leonor in Scarsdale, NY. Henry was prosperous in business which afforded him time to spend with family, contribute to Jewish causes, and play golf with friends. His generosity and cheerful sense of humor will be missed. Rest in peace father, friend, husband, and visionary. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARIS, HARRIET
Snippets: PARIS--Harriet, died on January 1, 2016 at the age of 87. She is survived by her son, Michael Bloomberg and daughter-in-law Terue Tokoro and her brother George David Paris. She is predeceased by daughter Deborah Bloomberg. As the owner and Director of the Peter Pan Laurel School, Dr. Paris was instrumental in educating generations of children of Brooklyn. Dr. Paris loved going to the museums and plays of New York. She volunteered at the Brooklyn museum for more than 20 years and at the Photography Museum in Manhattan. She donated much of her art collection to the City Museum of New York campus on 5th Avenue. Services Monday, 11:30am at "The Riverside" 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  RATNER, LAURA
Snippets: RATNER--Laura, on Decem- ber 30, 2015, formerly of Hewlett Harbor. Beloved wife of the late Arthur. Adored mother of Dennis and Andrea and Felice and Jay Seeman. Loving grandma of Allison, Rebecca and Andy, Ari and Brendon. Doting GG of Ethan, Lily and Meyer. We will never forget her strength of mind and body. A graduate of NYU Business School. Snippets: LIEBERMAN--Philip H.,M.D. 91 years old. WWII veteran. Retired chief of surgical pathology Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. Died December 26. Beloved husband of Cynthia, proud and loving father of Samuel (Cara) and David (Asya). Devoted grandpa to Daniel, Henry, and Lucy. He was the most gentle of gentlemen. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, MARCIA BESS
Snippets: PARKER--Marcia Bess. Born March 22, 1927, passed away November 18, 2015. Preceded in death by parents and sister. Survived by brother Chase Parker, Jr. Marcia lived in New York for over 50 years. She received a Masters Degree from Columbia University. She later became employed by Church Women United. As a fundraiser, she made many friends all over the United States. Marcia also made many friends at Laureate Hall where she was a tenant for around 50 years. Friends at the apartment, old and new, helped her survive a few more years while suffering with poor health. Marcia's body was donated to Columbia University Medical. 1/3

Snippets: SELK--Phyllis, on January 1, 2016. Beloved wife of Leonard, devoted mother of Ronnie and Michael, adored grandmother of Andrew, Douglas and Mark, cherished great- grandmother of Hayley. Service Monday, January 4, 11:00am at Riverdale Temple, 4545 Independence Ave., Riverdale. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHARGEL, LEO
Snippets: SHARGEL--Leo, died on January 2, 2016 at 99. Caring and sincere, Leo was a devoted husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather and friend, as well as a WWII Veteran. A true gentleman and energetic storyteller who loved to play cards, Leo will be missed by his wife of 73 years, Lillian, his children, Gerald and Judith, his daughter and son-in-law Terry and Robert, his grandchildren Johanna, David, Jake, Jill and Jamie and their spouses, as well as his 9 (soon to be 10) great-grandchildren. Shiva Monday-Wednesday at home of Gerald Shargel. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, ELLSWORTH
Snippets: KELLY--Ellsworth. The Board of Trustees and Staff of World Monuments Fund mourn the passing of Ellsworth Kelly, husband of our trustee Jack Shear. Ellsworth, along with Jack and the Ellsworth Kelly Foundation, was for years a deeply committed champion of preserving the world's most treasured places, with a passion for supporting the crafts-people and skills vital to heritage conservation. We all will greatly miss him. Christopher Ohrstrom, Chairman, and Joshua David, President and CEO, World Monuments Fund 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEREZ, ALFREDO J.
Snippets: PEREZ--Alfredo J.,83, of Sheffield, MA died peacefully on December 18. Born in New York City, he graduated from Columbia College and Columbia University Graduate School of Business. After serving in the U.S. Navy he had an extensive career in public service, most notably as deputy CEO of Planned Parenthood; acting director of the U.S. Peace Corps; president of the college, The Experiment in International Living and its School for International Training; confidential assistant, U.S. Agency for International Development; and Senior Vice President, Management of Family Health International, supervising programs with USAID for controlling the AIDS epidemic in developing countries. Charming and courtly, Alfredo was a gentle, loving man, compassionate, caring and always there for you. An avid reader, he had a love of good conversation, strong coffee, and music - classical, jazz, flamenco, and blue grass. His greatest love was for his family - his grandchildren and great-grandchildren. He is survived by his wife, Ann-Marie Light, daughters, Carole Montanari and Xanne Perez; sons, Tom, Robbie and Michael Perez; twelve grandchildren, eight great-grandchildren; brother, George Peters; and his first wife, Florence Perez. A memorial will be held in the spring. Contributions may be made to The Association for Frontotemporal Degeneration, theaftd.org. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  REED, DOLORES
Snippets: REED--Dolores, died peacefully at her Wellington, FL home on December 29, 2015 surrounded by her family. She was a devoted wife for 66 years to her husband, Howard, a loving mother to her children, Janet and Rob, their spouses Dan and Julie, and her grandchildren, Lindsay, Ben, and Michael. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, January 3rd at 10am at Gutterman-Warheit Memorial Chapel at 7240 North Federal Highway, Boca Raton, FL. A graveside service will be on Wednesday, January 6, 2016 at 11am at the Beth David Cemetery, 300 Elmont Rd, Elmont, NY. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOSPIN, TOBIAS
Snippets: YOSPIN--Tobias, of Roslyn, NY, Brooklyn born and bred, on December 31, 2015, at age 96. Beloved husband of the late Andrey (Kreinik) Yospin. Loving father of Richard Yospin, and the late Marjorie Yospin Newman. Adoring grandfather of Matthew, Gabriel and Sarina Yospin, and Eric and David Newman. Dear brother of Elaine Melnikoff and Thelma Kanig. Graduate of City College, and NYU Dental School; emeritus professor, City University of New York; painter and sculptor; lifetime tennis player, golfer and swimmer; passionate classical music listener; together with Audrey, world traveler. Graveside services at Beth Moses Cemetery, 1500 Wellwood Ave., West Babylon, NY 11704, on Monday, January 4 at 1pm. Memorial Observance at the home of Joan and Richard Yospin, Wednesday, January 6, 2016. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to: the Yiddish Book Center, 1021 West Street, Amherst, MA 01002. Levine Chapels, Brookline, 617-277-8300. www.levinechapel.com 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Memorials  CARR, KRISTEN ANN
Snippets: CARR--Kristen Ann. Memories of you inspire us today and always. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALLAHAN, DANIEL J
Snippets: CALLAHAN--Daniel J. III, 83, died peacefully on December 30, 2015 at the home he shared with his wife of 59 years, Colleen Mount Callahan. Mr. Callahan was a fourth generation Washingtonian. He was an Insignis Medal recipient at Georgetown Preparatory School (1950), a member of the Delta Kappa Epsilon Fraternity at Williams College (B.A.) (1954), served four years in the ROTC, and served in the United States Air Force, retiring as a Captain (1954-1956). He held positions with many financial institutions over his long career in banking, including Chairman of American Security Bank, President of Riggs National Bank and an executive of Chase Manhattan Bank. Mr. Callahan's most recent position was as Treasurer and Vice Chairman of The Morris and Gwendolyn Cafritz Foundation of Washington, DC. He had many business interests and held various board positions including Chairman of the Greater Washington Research Center, Vice Chairman of the Atlantic Council, Director Emeritus of Easter Seals Greater Washington- Baltimore Region, Inc., Independent Director of Washington Mutual Investors Fund Inc. and Director of Washington Gas Light Company and WGL Holdings Inc. Mr. Callahan's spiritual faith was an important and sustaining force throughout his life. He supported numerous charitable organizations. In 1991, he was bestowed the honor of Knight Commanders of the Order of St. Gregory the Great by Pope John Paul II; Cardinal James Hickey announced the papal honors. He is predeceased by his son, Daniel J. Callahan IV, his sister, Gerry Callahan Corcoran, and his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Callahan Jr. He is survived by his wife, Colleen Mount Callahan; his children, Carey S. Callahan, Caren A. Callahan, Carolyn Callahan Keller, Colleen Callahan Brown; nine grandchildren; three great-grandsons; and his sisters, Joanne McClure and Mary Alicia Callahan. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered at the Cathedral of St. Matthew the Apostle, 1725 Rhode Island Ave., NW, Washington, DC., 20036 at 1pm on Monday, January 4, 2016. Immediately following the Mass, friends will be received at the Mayflower Hotel, 1127 Connecticut Ave., NW, Washington, DC 20036. The interment will be private for family only. Memorial contributions may be made to the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of Washington. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, ELLSWORTH
Snippets: KELLY--Ellsworth. The Foundation for Art and Preservation in Embassies (FAPE) is profoundly saddened by the loss of Ellsworth Kelly. Revered and respected throughout the world, we will be forever grateful for his generosity, for the works he gave so enthusiastically to our Foundation, and for his commitment to FAPE's mission. From a sketch on a paper napkin came the design of two magnificent wall sculptures for the U.S. Embassy in Beijing, which greet more than 2,000 Chinese visa applicants daily, employing the colors in our two countries' flags to honor the relationship between the U.S. and China. In Berlin, Ellsworth watched as the 40- foot-high 'Berlin Totem' he created for the U.S. Embassy soared through the air to be placed in its courtyard garden. His extraordinary lithograph, 'Leaves,' adorns the walls of 50 U.S. embassies; and he contributed to our Collection at the U.S. Mission to the United Nations, as well as our millennium Gift To The Nation. He also donated the actual award that we present annually to the recipient of the Leonore and Walter Annenberg Award for Diplomacy through the Arts; the first honoree was Justice Stephen Breyer, who collaborated with Ellsworth on his site- specific installation at the John Joseph Moakley Courthouse in Boston. Ellsworth's last gift to FAPE was the establishment of an endowment, entitled the Ellsworth Kelly Fund for Preservation, to ensure FAPE's Collection is maintained in perpetuity at no cost to the government. Words cannot express how important Ellsworth was to FAPE. His gifts are a testament to his creativity, his genius and his extraordinary spirit. He will always remain in our memory, and his work will remind us of his belief in the importance of art as a means of freedom of expression and cross-cultural understanding. We send our deepest condolences to Jack Shear. Jo Carole Lauder, Chairman Eden Rafshoon, President Darren Walker, Vice President Elizabeth Pozen, Secretary Harrison Wellford, Treasurer Ann Gund, President Emerita Wendy Luers, President Emerita Jennifer Duncan, Director Robert Storr, Chairman, FAPE Professional Fine Arts Committee and Dean, Yale School of Art 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNOLLY, EDYTHE SLATTERY SHEEHAN
Snippets: CONNOLLY--Edythe Slattery Sheehan, born February 5, 1928; Died December 17, 2015 in Brooklyn, NY. Fifth generation Brooklynite, Edythe was the widow of William G. Sheehan and Edward J. Connolly, she was preceded in death by her parents Clare (nee Smith) and J. Warren Slattery and her sister, Clare Slattery Kelly. She is survived by her children, William Sheehan (Daria Doyle) Mount Vernon, NY, Kathleen Sheehan (Daniel Burke) Fairfield, CT, Jane Sheehan (Matthew Murphy) Princeton, NJ, Clare Sheehan, Brooklyn, NY, Kevin Sheehan, Brooklyn, NY and Brian Sheehan (Maria Fong) Syracuse, NY; her stepdaughter Jane D. Connolly (Edward Schwarz) Weston, CT, her sister, Marylou Slattery Millard, Fenwick, Old Saybrook, CT and 11 grandchildren and 12 nieces and nephews. A memorial service is being planned for spring 2016 in Brooklyn, NY. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANICAS, PETER T
Snippets: MANICAS--Peter T. 1934-2015. Peter T. Manicas, retired professor of philosophy at Queens College, City University of New York and the University of Hawaii at Manoa, passed away on December 27 in Honolulu. He is survived by his wife of fifty-five years, Kenoe Kauanoe 'Ti' Manicas, and their son Teddy (Theodore). Their daughter Tautasi died previously. Born into a Greek and Sicilian immigrant family in Binghamton, NY, Manicas was raised in Batavia, NY. He saw active service in the U.S. Air Force in the late 1950s and attained the rank of Captain. He received his BA from Syracuse University, and his MA from the University of Buffalo and his PhD in philosophy from SUNY Buffalo (1963). Professor Manicas moved to Hawaii in 1988 where he served as Professor of Sociology and Director of the Interdisciplinary Studies program at the University of Hawaii at Manoa (1988-2011). Early in his career he taught at C.W. Post College and Ohio Wesleyan University. A testimony to his scholarly productivity, Manicas published thirteen books and over fifty papers on realist philosophy, American pragmatism, and social theory including: "The Death of the State" (1974); "A History and Philosophy of the Social Sciences" (1987); and "A Realist Philosophy of Science" (2006). The consistent recipient of teaching awards, Manicas touched the lives of thousands of students. Peter was endowed with a fiery passion for social justice and had a curious mind, a wicked humor, and an open heart. A consummate epicure, he also was an enthusiastic fan of the New York Yankees, Knicks, and Giants, in addition to being a powerful presence in pick-up basketball. Peter was in many ways larger than life and will be irreplaceable. Services will be held at Borthwick Mortuary in Honolulu. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, JOEL "GONK," DIED ON TUESDAY
Snippets: KAPLAN--Joel "Gonk," died on Tuesday, December 29, 2015, in his home in Wallkill, NY after a long illness. He was born in Brooklyn and was the son of the late Florence and Harry Kaplan. He was predeceased by his twin brother Ira Kaplan. He is survived by his loving wife Carol Kaplan; sons Laurence Berland and Noah Berland; brothers Steven Kaplan and Richard Kaplan; sister-in-law Jo-Ann Segal; brother-in-law Keith Crossley; sisters-in-law Denise Kaplan, Ann Johnson, and Sherry Kaplan; nieces and nephews Michelle Kratochvil, Michael Kaplan, Rachel Newell, and Casiel Kaplan. Joel was a true Renaissance Man and salt of the earth who was loved by all he touched. He will be deeply missed by all. Donations can be made to the Perlmutter Cancer Center, NYU Langone Medical Center, Lung Cancer Research Fund. Graveside service Sunday, 11am, Wellwood Cemetery. For further information, visit www.jewish-funeral- home.com. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUNN, DONALD BRUCE

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, GILBERT
Snippets: KAPLAN--Gilbert, died peacefully on the morning of January 1, 2016, with Lena, his wife of 45 years, and their four loving children by his side. An uncommon man in every respect, he founded Institutional Investor magazine at the age of 26, serving as its Publisher and Editor-in-Chief for the next two decades, only to embark on a second life as a renowned amateur conductor of Mahler's Second Symphony. He said of the symphony that it "wrapped itself around me and never let go." This passion ultimately led to conducting engagements with over 60 orchestras throughout the world, acclaimed recordings of the work with the London Symphony Orchestra and the Vienna Philharmonic and, more recently, a faculty position at Julliard. His private life was just as rich. He married the woman he loved at first sight, loved her deeply to the end, and together they presided over a family of four beautiful children, Kristina Wallison, Claude Davies, John Kaplan and Emily Kaplan, and eight grandchildren. All grieve profoundly at his passing, but feel deeply blessed to have loved and been loved by this remarkable man. The family will receive friends at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street) in New York City, on Thursday, January 7 at 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Friends are invited to email stories and condolences to: gilkaplanfamily@gmail.com. 1/3

She is deeply missed by her children, Julian and Hannah, and by many loving family members, friends and business associates. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, GILBERT
Snippets: KAPLAN--Gilbert. The Board of Trustees and staff of Carnegie Hall mourn the passing of our dear friend and colleague Gilbert Kaplan, passionate music lover and devoted and beloved husband of Lena. Gil joined the Carnegie Hall Board of Trustees in 1980, and served the Hall with devotion for more than thirty-five years. Gil brought his financial acumen and keen insight to Carnegie Hall's management as a longstanding member of the Finance and Operations Committee, where he helped govern major institutional advances from the restoration of Carnegie Hall to the creation of an education center. Following his successful career in business and journalism, Gil became a celebrated scholar of Gustav Mahler, establishing the Kaplan Foundation and conducting Mahler's Second Symphony with leading orchestras around the world. Gil was invited by the Vienna Philharmonic to conduct the original version of Mahler's Second Symphony and his recordings of the Symphony with the London Symphony Orchestra and the Vienna Philharmonic were very successful. Gil demonstrated his deep love and knowledge of music every season as a frequent concertgoer, and many members of the Carnegie Hall's family were honored to be guests on Gil's acclaimed radio program "Mad About Music." We will always remember Gil for his warmth, musical scholarship, and his love of Carnegie Hall. We express our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Lena; his devoted children Kristina, Claude, John, and Emily; and their families and loved ones. Sanford I. Weill, President; Mercedes Bass, Acting Chairman; Clive Gillinson, Executive and Artistic Director 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTE, JUDITH SHEREFF
Snippets: HARTE--Judith Shereff, of Livingston, NJ, passed away in New York City on Wednesday, December 30, 2015 after a long and courageous fight with lung cancer. She was 77. Judi was an amazing mother, grandmother, sister, and woman. She enjoyed gardening, reading, painting, sculpting, music and building and fixing things. For a small person, Judi had a huge heart and always opened up her home and her heart to help others. After Hurricane Sandy, she had many displaced people stay with her for extended periods of time and never felt like it was too much; instead, she always said that she wished they would stay longer since she really enjoyed being with them and helping them. Judi was born to Abraham and Rose Shereff on June 18, 1938 in New York City and raised in Forest Hills, NY. She was preceded in death by her parents. Judi is survived by her brother and sister-in-law Richard and Susan Shereff; daughter Helaine Harte and son-in-law David Rhode, her sons and daughters-in-law Douglas and Ronni Harte and Jonathan and Belynda Harte; and the pride of her life, her grandchildren, Alex and Haleigh Harte and Tyler, Casey and Rebecca Rhode. Judi loved all animals. After being a teacher and raising her children, she worked at Turtle Back Zoo in West Orange, NJ, and spent many years rescuing and rehabilitating injured and orphaned wild animals and birds. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to The Turtle Back Zoo in Judi's honor. Funeral service will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 630 Amsterdam Avenue in New York City at 11:30am on Sunday, January 3rd. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKLER, RUTH CROHN
Snippets: DICKLER--Ruth Crohn, 102, died Thursday, December 31, at home of natural causes. A native New Yorker who loved the City-its parks, museums, concert halls and people, she lived with her father, Dr. Burrill B. Crohn, after her parents divorced when she was 12. Her brother, the late Dr. Eduard B. Crohn, lived with their mother, Lucile Pels Crohn, in Europe. Mrs. Dickler met her husband-to-be, the late Gerald Dickler, when they were in their mid-teens. He was already attending Columbia College; she went to Barnard College for two years before dropping out to help support them while he began practicing law. She was librarian and book review editor, as well as a board member, at Citizens Housing and Planning Council of New York. She also served as president of The Burrill B. Crohn Research Foundation at Mount Sinai Hospital. But her greatest passion was philanthropy. She and her husband made large donations to institutions they both loved: the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the New York Public Library, the 92nd Street Y, UJA and Planned Parenthood. They also planned gifts to other city institutions. She leaves three daughters, Abby Pratt of West Stockbridge, Massachusetts and Squirrel Island, Maine, and her husband, Larry Pratt; Jane Dickler Lebow of New York City and Susan Dickler of New York City and West Tisbury, Massachusetts, and her husband, Sig Van Raan. She had four grandchildren, Sam Pratt, Kate Lebow, Dr. Robert Pratt and Emily Hoppe; three stepgrandchildren, Jackson, Sofie and Zoe Van Raan, and four great-grandchildren, Lucy and Owen Pratt and Naomi and Jacob Lawrence. There will be no funeral. A gathering of family and friends is planned in the future. Donations in her memory may be made to The Burrill B. Crohn Research Foundation at Mount Sinai Medical Center or Citizens Housing and Planning Council. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEIGER, MELISSA BROWN WILEY
Snippets: GEIGER--Melissa Brown Wiley, died of natural causes in New York City on Saturday, December 19, 2015 surrounded by her loving family. Born in Bay Shore, NY in 1937, she was the oldest child of Melissa Adams and Robert Hoffman Wiley. Melissa graduated from Spring Valley High School, Spring Valley, NY in 1955. She attended Skidmore College and married in 1957. Howard and Melissa began their marriage at Dartmouth College. Howard's career brought them to many places: Munich, Germany; New Jersey; Minneapolis; San Francisco and finally settling down in Manhattan in 1987. Their lifelong home was on Lake George in Putnam, NY. Melissa brought music and friendship wherever she went; these passions defined her life. An extremely talented pianist, she played the organ for her church beginning at age 12. Melissa played an active role in her children's education, always volunteering, often as the accompanist for school musical productions. She sang in the Plymouth Church Choir and with the Plymouth Music Series. She supported the Minnesota Opera. Melissa was the Minister of Music, Organist and Choir Director at Suffern Presbyterian Church in Suffern, NY. While living in San Francisco, she sang in the Unitarian Church Choir and was a board member of The San Francisco Chamber Singers, now called Volti. In Manhattan, she joined the music department of the Rudolf Steiner School as a faculty member and retired in 2002. Melissa joined The Riverside Church in 1988 committed to making our world a better place through music. She was a member of The Riverside Choir, the Riverside Choral Society, served as Music Committee chair, raised funds for the Men's Shelter and was actively involved in the founding of the Catherine Van Buren Endowment Fund and the Friends of Music. She most recently enjoyed spending time with her children, grandchildren, friends, and her dog. Melissa is survived by her children, Melissa Ann Geiger (Paul Marvin) of New York, NY, Kirsten Geiger Rider (Harold) of Winnetka, IL, Howard (Skip) Wilton Geiger III of New York, NY, Christopher Wiley Geiger of Larkspur, CA and her brother, William Adams Wiley (Lynn) of Grantham, NH; nine grandchildren, Paul and Oliver Marvin of New York, NY, Harold, Sarah and Christopher Rider of Winnetka, IL, Lillian Geiger of New York, NY, Wiley, Bourke and Finley Geiger of Larkspur, CA as well as many adored nieces, nephews and her beloved dog Libee. Her husband of 56 years, Howard Wilton and her brother, George Martin Wiley III, predeceased Melissa. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Friends of Music, The Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive, New York, NY, 10027. Services will be held at The Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive, New York, NY at 12:00pm on Monday, January 4. A memorial reception will immediately follow. There will be additional opportunities to meet with family and friends. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRIEDMAN, REGINIA

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKLER, RUTH CROHN
Snippets: DICKLER--Ruth Crohn. The Division of Gastroenterology at The Mount Sinai Medical Center is saddened at the loss of our dear friend and benefactor, Ruth Crohn Dickler, daughter of a founding giant of our profession, Dr. Burrill B. Crohn. The miracle of Ruth's life is not simply that she remained active and healthy for 102 years, but that she used those years to raise such a distinguished and devoted family, to support such a wide range of worthy causes, and to promulgate the timeless legacy of her father at Mount Sinai by underwriting many of the ground-breaking research and educational initiatives of our Division. Bruce E. Sands, MD, The Dr. Burrill B. Crohn Professor of Medicine; Division Chief Steven H. Itzkowitz, MD, Professor of Medicine and Oncological Sciences, Program Director David B. Sachar, MD, Clinical Professor of Medicine; Division Chief Emeritus 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIFKIN, COMRAS, BLANCHE

She was a pillar of our community and will be missed by everyone who knew and loved her. Our condolences and prayers to her entire family and friends. Rest in peace. John Usdan, President Howard Martin, CEO 1/3

Traveler and adventurer, he roamed the planet from Bear Mountain, NY, to the Himalayas, San Francisco to the Galapagos, soaking up cultures and landscapes. He delighted in his family: his five children, Peter (Lew), Margy, Vicki (Nat), Rocky (Marjie), and Emily; his five grandchildren, Andrew (Erin), Rae (Billy), Spencer, Jordan (Megan), and Marisa; and his four great grandchildren, Betty, Josie, James, and Charlie. Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  METZGER, PHOEBE
Snippets: METZGER--Phoebe, 95, of Boca Raton, FL; died peacefully and naturally at home on December 29. She was the devoted wife for 64 years of Bernard (deceased). Mother of Robert and Steven, sister of Enid Lee, and brother Marvin Goldstein (deceased). She loved life with a large social circle, enjoying tennis, friendly gaming and philanthropy; she was a strong supporter of organizations for Jewish causes and the developmentally disabled. Services will be 1pm, Sunday, January 3 at Lakeside Memorial Park, Doral, FL; Shiva at the family home after 6pm. Honor her memory at JARCFL.ORG. 1/3

Snippets: VINSON--Myron "Mike", on December 30, 2015. Adored husband of Carol. Beloved father of Daniel and Laura. Cherished grandfather of Adam and Hannah. Service January 3, 2016, 10am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPERSMITH, DR
Snippets: COOPERSMITH--Dr. Sy, psychoanalyst, died peacefully at home of respiratory arrest on November 6, 2015. He was 84. Sy was born on June 19, 1931 and grew up in Boston. He graduated from Boston Latin High School, Bates College and earned his doctorate at Columbia University Teachers College. Sy did his psychoanalytic training at the National Psychological Association for Psychoanalysis where he also served on the faculty and was a senior clinical supervisor. He is survived by his wife Dr. Valerie Pinhas, and daughter Andie Coopersmith. A Memorial Service will be held at NPAP on January 10, 2016 from 1-3pm, 40 West 13th St., NY, NY 10011. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, ELLSWORTH
Snippets: KELLY--Ellsworth. The Checkerboard Film Foundation is very saddened at the passing of Ellsworth Kelly, seminal artist and true gentleman. In 2007, we were privileged to produce, with Jo Carole Lauder, the documentary film, "Ellsworth Kelly: Fragments." Most memorably, we filmed Ellsworth in Paris as he recounted his formative experiences while living there from 1948 to 1954, and his exploration of French culture and monuments that so informed his work. He said: "In my paintings, I am not inventing; my ideas come from constantly investigating how things look." They included the shadows of an arch of a bridge on the Seine ("White Plaque: Bridge Arch and Reflection," 1951-55); the external chimneys on the wall of a building ("Ormesson," 1950); and the long angular windows at The Museum of Modern Art, Paris ("Window," his first panel painting, 1949). We send our very sincere condolences to Jack Shear, whose inspiration and guidance were invaluable. The Board of Trustees and Edgar B. Howard, President 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  HSU, TA CHUN
Snippets: HSU--Ta Chun. Weill Cornell Medicine is saddened by the passing of our friend Ta Chun Hsu, former president of The Starr Foundation and a graceful, longtime generous champion of our institution. His legacy endures through the C.V. Starr Biomedical Information Center, which the foundation established in 1987 to provide physicians, scientists, staff and students with the latest information resources. The foundation's commitment to education is also exemplified in the C.V. Starr Scholarship, which has supported the training of generations of medical students since its creation nearly 30 years ago. We will greatly miss his friendship and sage advice. Our condolences to The Starr Foundation leadership, his family and his many friends. Dr. Laurie H. Glimcher, Dean, Weill Cornell Medicine Jessica M. Bibliowicz, Chairman, Board of Overseers 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREILICH, DR
Snippets: FREILICH--Dr. Gerald. Emeritus professor of mathematics at Queens College of CUNY who specialized in geometric measure theory, passed away on December 27th, 2015 at age 88. Professor Freilich was the author of several books and many research articles and reviews in academic journals. He was a former governor of the Mathematical Association of America as well as Chairman of the New York Metropolitan Section and served on the national panel of the Committee on the Undergraduate Program of Mathematics. Born in Brooklyn, he received a bachelor's degree, Summa Cum Laude, from City College in 1946 and a Doctorate in Mathematics from Brown University in 1949. He taught at Brown University and then at City College of New York, advancing to full professor and Chairman of the Mathematics Department in 1966. During those years, he was an original member of the organizing Committee of the SUNY Doctoral Program and single- handedly established the SUNY graduate Mathematics Library. He also taught at Wesleyan University as a visiting professor. He joined the faculty of Queens College in 1971 and taught there until his retirement in 1995. Professor Freilich served in the US Navy in World War II. After the war he was a Lieutenant J.G. in the Navy Reserves. He also did research for the National Ordinance Lab on helicopters and submarines. He is survived by Marion (nee Freudenberger) after 62 years of marriage. He is also survived by his brother Dr. Herbert Freilich and children Sandra Novetsky (Dr. Gary) and Dr. David Freilich (Erica) as well as eight grandchildren and six great-grandchildren and many nephews and nieces. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKER, ELIZABETH
Snippets: BAKER--Elizabeth, "Betsy." Elizabeth "Betsy" Lentz Baker died unexpectedly in Savannah, GA on December 4, 2015 after a brief illness. A resident of Manhattan's Upper West Side for 50 years, and more recently of Tuxedo Park, NY, Betsy was born in Kittanning, PA, on August 13, 1936 to Elizabeth Fleming Wagner and William Roy Baker and was raised in State College, PA and Wilmington, DE where she graduated from Alexis I. DuPont High School. She earned a B.S. degree from Drexel University specializing in textile chemistry and was a member of Delta Zeta Sorority. She worked for Celanese, Hercules, Inc., and as a commercial print model. Betsy volunteered with The Leukemia Society, Community Board 7, various cancer support groups, and Manhattan's Bull Moose Dog Run. A longtime survivor of tonsilar area cancer, which she faced with courage and conviction, Betsy was an inspiration to all those who knew her. Despite the physical challenges with which the disease left her, Betsy was able to flourish thanks to the devoted care of her physician, Dr. Margaret Lewin. Survived by stepfather Romeo Barrick Wagner, cousins Robert Hayman, Sr. (Sally), Robert Hayman, Jr. (Sherry), and Victoria Sutton (James) and her poodle, Queen Victoria "Tori." Donations in Betsy's memory may be made to "Case Western Reserve University School of Medicine/The Albert L. Lewin, M.D. Award Fund for Clinical Excellence in Pediatrics," Office of Advancement Services, Case Western Reserve University, 10900 Euclid Avenue, Cleveland, Ohio 44106-7035. Telephone 216-368-2000. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHORT, STEPHEN
Snippets: SHORT--Stephen. June 11, 1945-December 12, 2015. Stephen Short, a former Procter of the Admiralty, who also served in the Merchant Marine, passed away on December 12th. A longtime member of the New York State bar, his legal career encompassed maritime, criminal and personal injury law. In his youth, Mr. Short was also a gifted athlete, excelling as a swimmer, skier, sailor and avid tennis player. He was also deemed an Olympic caliber fencer by Maestro Odon Niederkirchner, of the NYAC. A colorful figure and lifelong champion of the underdog, he will be missed by all who loved him, including his sisters, Leslie Blake and Cheryl Bulbach and his brother, Dr. Wayne Blackmon. As per his wishes, Mr. Short's corneas were donated to the Eye Bank for Sight Restoration. A Memorial will be held in mid-January at the Village Funeral Home. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERIKSEN, STEIN
Snippets: ERIKSEN--Stein, December 11, 1927-December 27, 2015. Stein Eriksen Lodge mourns the passing of our namesake Stein Eriksen. It was Stein's vision that created the lodge. He set the high standard for hospitality and service that still exists today. His celebrity charisma created a special ambiance within the Lodge, restaurant and out on the mountain that was warm and inviting and contributed to Deer Valley Resort being named number one and the Lodge being named "World's Best Ski Hotel." As one of the most recognized names in the ski world, Stein Eriksen has been synonymous with skiing style and elegance for more than 60 years. Our thoughts are with his wife Francois and his son Bjorn, three daughters, Julianna, Ava and Anja, as well as his five grandchildren. Stein will be sorely missed. Ski well our friend! Dennis A Suskind, President Russ Olsen, CEO 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENDAHAN, MAURICE
Snippets: BENDAHAN--Maurice, died peacefully January 1. Loving husband of Yvette and father of Miriam and great uncle. Funeral Sunday, January 3, 9:30am, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave at 91st St, New York. Interment at Beth Olam Cemetery in Ridgewood, Queens. 1/3

Snippets: ROSEN--Baran S.,passed away after a brief illness. He is survived by his wife Margie; children Sarah and Michael; brothers Russell (Eileen) and Alan (Lyn); sister and brother-in-law Susan and Bob Lewin and many nieces and nephews. Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKLER, RUTH
Snippets: DICKLER--Ruth. It is with deep sadness that we note the passing of Mrs. Ruth Dickler who first joined The Citizens Housing & Planning Council as a volunteer in 1962, where she began to build and shape our archival library. She was an important resource for New York City's researchers, academics, and students. Upon her retirement she became a member of CHPC's Board of Directors. A talented writer and editor, her research and organizational skills helped to shape CHPC's work for nearly five decades. A mentor and friend to all of us at CHPC, her legacy continues in the historic library that bares her name. Our heartfelt condolences to her family and friends and to our city which has lost a great lady. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSKOVITZ, ADELE
Snippets: MOSKOVITZ--Adele. Died December 31, 2015, two days after her 100th birthday. Generous, gracious and beautiful, she lost her beloved husband, Irving, in 1996, just short of their 59th Wedding Anniversary. She is survived by her children, Anne Davis and Peter (both widowed), grandchildren Ariel Morvan, David and Zoe, and three great-grandchildren, Eleanor, Angelica and Benjamin. Adele studied dramatic arts at NYU, acted briefly, and was passionate about music, art and travel. She loved her home in New York and a second home in Cannes, France, in which places she brought family and friends together. While her children were growing up in Scarsdale, NY, she was an officer of the PTA, served as co-leader of a Girl Scout troop and hosted a foreign exchange student, Delcia Bence Rusk, to whom she remained close all her life. In a brief reprise of her acting career, she played Mrs. Frank in a 1961 Scarsdale High School production of The Diary of Anne Frank in which her daughter, Anne, was played by Liza Minnelli in her acting debut. A lover of music and constant concertgoer, she was an active Board Member of Young Audiences, the Bowden International Music Festival, and the Marlboro Music Festival, which she attended for over forty years. She took great pleasure in encouraging young musicians at the beginning of their careers. The funeral is private. There will be a memorial service, the date to be announced. Contributions in her memory may be made to Marlboro Music, 1528 Walnut Street, Suite 301, Philadelphia, PA 19102. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Memorials  BROOK, JONATHAN EDWARD
Snippets: BROOK--Jonathan Edward. 6 months have passed without you. We miss you more than words can say. Our love for you will always live on in our hearts. Nicole, Juliette, Cassie, Mom, Dad, Adam 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERALTA, RAMOS, ARTURO JR
Snippets: PERALTA-RAMOS--Arturo Jr. Born in Southampton, L.I. to Arturo H. Peralta-Ramos Sr. and Millicent Rogers, Arturo Henry Peralta-Ramos, Jr. passed away December 21, 2015, at his home in Taos, NM at the age of 87. He is survived by his wife of fifty years, Jacqueline Blanchard Peralta-Ramos, his son Arturo H. Peralta-Ramos III, (Eunjae Peralta-Ramos) of Jackson Hole, Wyoming, his daughter Lorian Peralta- Ramos Buckley, (Peter Buckley) of Aiken, South Carolina, his grandchildren, Sascha and Syler Peralta-Ramos, Jamie and Ian Buckley, Ashley and Lindsey Gamble, and his step-mother Mercedes Peralta-Ramos. In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by his older half brother Peter Salm, and younger brother, Paul Peralta-Ramos. Arturo Peralta-Ramos Jr. grew up in the United States and Europe. He attended school on both continents, most notable being Institut Le Rosey in Switzerland and Staunton Military Academy in Virginia. He briefly attended the University of Virginia before striking off to pursue his life-long career as an Entrepreneur. Based out of New York City, his business interests spanned a diverse array of industries including mining, flour milling, defense, electronic marketing, recreation and entertainment. His most recognized achievement was as a co-founder of Comp-U- Card International, one of the leading edge precursors to online marketing. A staunch patriot, over many years Arturo acted as an advisor to the Lyndon Johnson administration, along with numerous senators and congressmen, and participated in a number of classified assignments. One of his greatest passions throughout his life was bird hunting. In that pursuit he travelled the world and won numerous domestic and international championships. Arturo also maintained strong affection for the Millicent Rogers Museum in Taos, NM, dedicated to the life and artistic creations, collections and endeavors of his mother, Millicent Rogers. Over the years he served on the board and participated both as an avid advisor and benefactor. Funeral services will be performed on January 9, 2016, at 11am at the San Francisco de Asis Church in Ranchos de Taos by Father Dino Candelaria, followed by a final graveside blessing at the Taos Sierra Vista Cemetery. A reception for family and friends will be held at the Trading Post Restaurant following the interment. In lieu of flowers, gifts or donations in his memory should go to the Millicent Roger Museum. www.millicentrogers.org 1/3

He leaves behind a loving family that will carry on his tradition of exceptional philanthropy. He is survived by his wife, Rupa Doshi and his son and daughter-in-law, Nirav and Alma Doshi. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  HSU, TA CHUN (T.C.)
Snippets: HSU--Ta Chun (T.C.), our esteemed president emeritus and director, died peacefully in his sleep on Sunday, December 27, 2015 at the age of 97. T.C. lived a full life. He was a gentleman in every sense of the word, dedicated, deeply loyal, a good friend, and counselor to generations of colleagues at the Starr Companies and The Starr Foundation. T.C. was born in Beijing in 1918, son of Yu Hsuen Yang (mother) and Tsing Lo (Singloh) Hsu (father), brother of the late Ta Ching (Irene) Hsu and the late Vivian Hsu Jee, and beloved "Uncle T.C." to many. T.C.'s father was one of the earliest backers of Cornelius Vander Starr's businesses in Shanghai and, when Tsing Lo Hsu was killed in the early days of World War II, Mr. Starr brought T.C. to America to complete his college education. T.C. never forgot Mr. Starr's generosity and friendship and made significant contributions to Starr's organizations over the years. T.C. attended the University of Shanghai from 1936-1938 and graduated from Haverford College in 1942 with a B.S. in economics. He earned a masters degree at Columbia University in the School of Journalism in 1944 and began his career with the news department of the Chinese Information Service in New York. He returned to Shanghai to work on the Chinese edition of The Shanghai Evening Post and Mercury, newspapers owned by Mr. Starr. In 1947, T.C. joined the staff of the Shanghai Commercial & Savings Bank until 1949, and then joined Starr's American International companies in Hong Kong and later San Francisco. In 1964, T.C. moved to New York to work directly with Mr. Starr on a variety of projects, including the management of The Starr Foundation, Mr. Starr's private philanthropic foundation. After Mr. Starr's death in late 1968, T.C. became President of The Starr Foundation and served in that role until 1999. T.C. remained an active director of the Foundation until his death. T.C. will be laid to rest in China. A memorial service in New York City is planned for a future date. M.R. Greenberg, Chairman The Starr Foundation 1/3

A bundle of energy and pillar of the community, she worked tirelessly for: The Advisory Board of Jacobi Hospital; The Advisory Board of Einstein/Montefiore; Member of the Community Board 11 for 30 years; The Board of Directors of Bronx House; and National Council of Jewish Women. Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  HSU, TA CHUN
Snippets: HSU--Ta Chun. The faculty and staff of the Edward Harkness Eye Institute are greatly saddened by the loss of T. C. Hsu, a wonderful friend and member of the Board of Advisors. As past president of The Starr Foundation for more than three decades, T. C. helped to advance the mission of many organizations in the arts and sciences throughout the world. Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMANT, JOAN CHAMPION
Snippets: DIAMANT--Joan Champion, died December 18 in Lenox, MA. Born in New York; studied at The Walden School and The Art Students League; worked at Pierre Matisse Gallery. Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRISON, MARIA T
Snippets: HARRISON--Maria T. (nee Preite) of Short Hills died on Thursday, December 31st, surrounded by her family. She was 56. Maria was born in Brooklyn, NY, and has lived in Short Hills for the past 25 years. She graduated from St. John's with a B.A., which led her to pursue a masters in education at Caldwell College. Maria was a firm believer in the potential of others and dedicated her life to helping them achieve it. Former New York City Mayor Ed Koch appointed her to serve on the New York City Commission on the Status of Women, where she advocated for gender equality through dialogue and policy proposals. She later spent a decade as an elementary school teacher for Ecole Toussaint Louverture, a public elementary school in East Orange, New Jersey. Maria was the beloved wife of Edmond Harrison, devoted mother of Meghan and E.J. Harrison, loving daughter of Joseph Preite and the late Gloria Mercorella Preite, and dear sister of Ralph Preite. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral Mass at St. Rose Of Lima Church, 50 Short Hills Avenue, Short Hills, NJ, on Tuesday, January 5th, at 10:00am. Visitation will take place at St. Rose of Lima Church on Sunday and Monday from 4:00-8:00pm, with Interment also at St. Rose of Lima. Services provided by The Jacob A. Holle Funeral Home, Maplewood. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Look Good Feel Better (http://lookgood feelbetter.org/donate). 1/3
