Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, GILBERT
Snippets: KAPLAN--Gilbert. The Board of Trustees and staff of Carnegie Hall mourn the passing of our dear friend and colleague Gilbert Kaplan, passionate music lover and devoted and beloved husband of Lena. Gil joined the Carnegie Hall Board of Trustees in 1980, and served the Hall with devotion for more than thirty-five years. Gil brought his financial acumen and keen insight to Carnegie Hall's management as a longstanding member of the Finance and Operations Committee, where he helped govern major institutional advances from the restoration of Carnegie Hall to the creation of an education center. Following his successful career in business and journalism, Gil became a celebrated scholar of Gustav Mahler, establishing the Kaplan Foundation and conducting Mahler's Second Symphony with leading orchestras around the world. Gil was invited by the Vienna Philharmonic to conduct the original version of Mahler's Second Symphony and his recordings of the Symphony with the London Symphony Orchestra and the Vienna Philharmonic were very successful. Gil demonstrated his deep love and knowledge of music every season as a frequent concertgoer, and many members of the Carnegie Hall's family were honored to be guests on Gil's acclaimed radio program "Mad About Music." We will always remember Gil for his warmth, musical scholarship, and his love of Carnegie Hall. We express our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Lena; his devoted children Kristina, Claude, John, and Emily; and their families and loved ones. Sanford I. Weill, President; Mercedes Bass, Acting Chairman; Clive Gillinson, Executive and Artistic Director 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCHBERG, IRVING
Snippets: HIRSCHBERG--Irving, resident of Amagansett, NY, died suddenly on December 30th at age 88. He was predeceased by his beloved wife, Phyllis. He is survived by his two daughters, Lise and Wendy, sister Shirlee (Geri Grossman), and his grandson Miles Emanuel. He retired as an accomplished electrical engineer at Fairchild Camera. He had a major impact on the East End community. Irving was a tutor of ESL students at East Hampton High School, a friend to senior citizens through R.S.V.P. and an active Democrat. He was devoted to his tennis and golf games. Irving was a loyal and generous friend to many. Contributions may be made in his memory: Cinema Arts Centre, Huntington, Long Island or the Southern Poverty Law Center. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSTREICH, ELLEN S.
Snippets: OSTREICH--Ellen S.,88, of Lake Mary, Florida (former resident of New York and Boca Raton, Florida), passed away on January 2, 2016. Born January 14, 1927 to Rose Lehman Stein, Esq. and Simon Stein, M.D. Graduated from Cornell University in 1946 and received M.A. in 1947 from New York University. Beloved wife of the late Leonard L. Ostreich, M.D. Beloved mother to Marjorie (Dustan) Smith, Richard, M.D. (Helene) Ostreich, Steven (Andrea) Ostreich and Peter Ostreich (deceased) and Glenda. Adored grandmother to nine, Carey, Jordan, Tamara, Amy, Debbie, Rachel, Danielle, Stacey and Emily and adored great-grandmother to five, Chloe, Myles, Jeremy, Mason and Lily. The funeral service will be on January 5, 2016 at 12:00pm at Gutterman's Memorial Chapel, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, New York. Family requests donations be made to Vitas Healthcare (Hospice) or Boys Town Jerusalem. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOWAY, MICHAEL
Snippets: SOLOWAY--Michael, "Mickey," on January 2, 2016. Loving husband to Loretta and father to Spencer (Alex). His smile and sense of humor will be missed by all who had the joy of knowing him. Services today, Monday, 12:45pm, at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, GILBERT
Snippets: KAPLAN--Gilbert, died peacefully on the morning of January 1, 2016, with Lena, his wife of 45 years, and their four loving children by his side. An uncommon man in every respect, he founded Institutional Investor magazine at the age of 26, serving as its Publisher and Editor-in-Chief for the next two decades, only to embark on a second life as a renowned amateur conductor of Mahler's Second Symphony. He said of the symphony that it "wrapped itself around me and never let go." This passion ultimately led to conducting engagements with over 60 orchestras throughout the world, acclaimed recordings of the work with the London Symphony Orchestra and the Vienna Philharmonic and, more recently, a faculty position at Juilliard. His private life was just as rich. He married the woman he loved at first sight, loved her deeply to the end, and together they presided over a family of four beautiful children, Kristina Wallison, Claude Davies, John Kaplan and Emily Kaplan, and eight grandchildren. All grieve profoundly at his passing, but feel deeply blessed to have loved and been loved by this remarkable man. The family will receive friends at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street) in New York City, on Thursday, January 7 at 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Friends are invited to email stories and condolences to: gilkaplanfamily@gmail.com. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDOFSKY, JESSE FRANK
Snippets: RUDOFSKY--Jesse Frank, of Belmont, MA. Music producer with group Ace, Dollface and Franky Lightning, passed on December 26. Beloved husband of Carolee Beberian Rudofsky. Son of Toby (Gross) Rudofsky and Harry Rudofsky. Father of Cherie, Jessica and Danna Heidi Rudofsky. Funeral, Holy Trinity Armenian Church, 145 Brattle St., Cambridge, MA, January 7, 11am. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSKOVITZ, ADELE
Snippets: MOSKOVITZ--Adele. Died December 31, 2015, two days after her 100th birthday. Generous, gracious and beautiful, she lost her beloved husband, Irving, in 1996, just short of their 59th Wedding Anniversary. She is survived by her children, Anne Davis and Peter (both widowed), grandchildren Ariel Morvan, David and Zoe, and three great-grandchildren, Eleanor, Angelica and Benjamin. Adele studied dramatic arts at NYU, acted briefly, and was passionate about music, art and travel. She loved her home in New York and a second home in Cannes, France, in which places she brought family and friends together. While her children were growing up in Scarsdale, NY, she was an officer of the PTA, served as co-leader of a Girl Scout troop and hosted a foreign exchange student, Delcia Bence Rusk, to whom she remained close all her life. In a brief reprise of her acting career, she played Mrs. Frank in a 1961 Scarsdale High School production of The Diary of Anne Frank in which her daughter, Anne, was played by Liza Minnelli in her acting debut. A lover of music and constant concertgoer, she was an active Board Member of Young Audiences, the Bowden International Music Festival, and the Marlboro Music Festival, which she attended for over forty years. She took great pleasure in encouraging young musicians at the beginning of their careers. The funeral is private. There will be a memorial service, the date to be announced. Contributions in her memory may be made to Marlboro Music, 1528 Walnut Street, Suite 301, Philadelphia, PA 19102. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHARGEL, LEO
Snippets: SHARGEL--Leo, died on January 2, 2016 at 99. Caring and sincere, Leo was a devoted husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather and friend, as well as a WWII Veteran. A true gentleman and energetic storyteller who loved to play cards, Leo will be missed by his wife of 73 years, Lillian, his children, Gerald and Judith, his daughter and son-in-law Terry and Robert, his grandchildren Johanna, David, Jake, Jill and Jamie and their spouses, as well as his 9 (soon to be 10) great-grandchildren. Shiva Monday-Wednesday at home of Gerald Shargel. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOSPIN, TOBIAS
Snippets: YOSPIN--Tobias, of Roslyn, NY, Brooklyn born and bred, on December 31, 2015, at age 96. Beloved husband of the late Audrey (Kreinik) Yospin. Loving father of Richard Yospin, and the late Marjorie Yospin Newman. Adoring grandfather of Matthew, Gabriel and Sarina Yospin, and Eric and David Newman. Dear brother of Elaine Melnikoff and Thelma Kanig. Graduate of City College, and NYU Dental School; emeritus professor, City University of New York; painter and sculptor; lifetime tennis player, golfer and swimmer; passionate classical music listener; together with Audrey, world traveler. Graveside services at Beth Moses Cemetery, 1500 Wellwood Ave., West Babylon, NY 11704, on Monday, January 4 at 1pm. Memorial Observance at the home of Joan and Richard Yospin, Wednesday, January 6, 2016. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to: the Yiddish Book Center, 1021 West Street, Amherst, MA 01002. Levine Chapels, Brookline, 617-277-8300. www.levine chapel.com 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRYFOROS, NICHOLAS JAMES
Snippets: TRYFOROS--Nicholas James, July 27, 1923-December 31, 2015. Nicholas James Tryforos, son of James and Garufa, was the youngest and last survivor of thirteen children. In explaining why "Mama and Papa had thirteen children, not twelve or fourteen" Nick said, "When I was born, papa picked me up, checked me out, and said 'Mama! FINALLY a perfect baby.'" A lifelong New Yorker, he was a proud graduate of The Greek American Institute, Theodore Roosevelt High School and New York University. He served in the Army in WWII. After basic training, the Army sent him to language school to become a Hindustani interpreter. He received horse cavalry and military intelligence training, and then served in the Philippines and in General MacArthur's headquarters in Tokyo during the occupation of Japan. Nick used his Hindustani skills for the rest of his life to surprise and delight both friends and complete strangers from India. After returning from Japan Nick worked for 15 years in the family flower and novelty business, then had a 25-year career with the IRS, retiring in 1986 as a Group Manager, supervising large corporation tax audits. Amateur gymnast, superb photographer, family documenter and archivist, Nick was the favorite uncle of many and worked hard to make and cultivate relationships with family and friends. He collected any piece of junk that could potentially serve a future purpose, taught his children the value of a dollar and the importance of grunt labor, and was the original tiger mom and DIY guy. He was the resident teaser (while being wheeled to major surgery with four children at home, Nick whispered to his wife "don't worry dear, as long as we have our health!") and an inveterate joke teller ("Have you heard the one about the skeleton that walked into a bar..."). Nick delighted in meeting his children's friends, showing them photos related (and unrelated!) to their discussion, and always enjoyed giving them another tour of the garage! Nick was quietly proud of everyone in his family, and his family was very fortunate to have him. He leaves behind his dear wife of 63 years and best friend Mary, and his children, Margaret and her husband Paul, Jim and his wife Sue, Tom, and Tina and her husband David. He also leaves his grandchildren, Peter, Evan, Kate and her husband Pat, John, Lucas, Eva, and Eli, and great-grandson Theo. Within minutes of Nick's passing, his second great-grandson, Grant, was born. Visitation will be held from 6 to 9pm Monday, January 4th at Frederick Funeral Home in Flushing, and funeral services at 11:30am Tuesday at St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church in Flushing. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to SmileTrain.com, DoctorsWithoutBorders.com or World Vision In Support of Syrian Refugees. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINSTEIN, SABENA
Snippets: RUBINSTEIN--Sabena. Bnai Zion mourns the loss of Sabena Rubinstein, former president of the New York Region, and second generation supporter of Bnai Zion. Sabena was the daughter of former National Vice President, Anna Gelman and her husband Nat, who were all longtime supporters of the Bnai Zion Medical Center in Haifa. Our heartfelt condolences go out to her husband Sergio, and may the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. George W. Schaeffer, Chairman of the Board David H. Eisenberg, National President Cheryl Bier, Executive Vice President 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOSHI, SHRENIK RAMANIKLAL

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOESCHENSTEIN, JOSEPHINE MOLL
Snippets: BOESCHENSTEIN--Josephine Moll, "Molly." October 29, 1930-December 30, 2015. Josephine Moll "Molly" Boeschenstein passed away peacefully Wednesday, December 30, 2015, in Hobe Sound, FL. Molly was born Josephine Hamlin Moll on October 29, 1930, in Detroit, MI, to Josephine Hamlin and The Honorable Lester Moll, a prominent Detroit prosecutor and judge. She grew up in Grosse Pointe, MI. In 1953, she married William W. Boeschenstein, who was working for Owens Corning in Detroit. The couple later moved to Perrysburg, Ohio, where they raised four sons. Mr. Boeschenstein ultimately became Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of Owens Corning in Toledo, Ohio. Although her husband became the public face of the company, Molly was a genuine partner to him throughout his career. Molly was known for her intelligence, style, love of competition, and her outstanding, irreverent sense of humor. Conversations with her were punctuated by astute observations, humorous ripostes, and often times belly shaking laughter. She had a wide and deep circle of friends from every corner of her life. Molly was deeply involved in a number of civic and charitable organizations. Notably, she was the first President of the St. Vincent Medical Center Foundation in Toledo, OH, a committed volunteer at the Toledo Museum of Art, and a member of the Board of Directors of The National Council on Alcoholism and Addiction and The Freedom Institute in New York. Molly and her husband have made their principal residence in Hobe Sound, FL. She is survived by her husband of 62 years, William W. Boeschenstein, sons William Jr., Michael, Peter and Stephen, their spouses, and 10 grandchildren and one great- grandchild. Funeral services are pending. Memorial contributions may be made to the Toledo Museum of Art, the Jupiter Medical Center Foundation in Jupiter, FL or the Martin Health Foundation in Stuart, FL. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMANT, JOAN CHAMPION
Snippets: DIAMANT--Joan Champion, died December 18 in Lenox, MA. Born in New York; studied at The Walden School and The Art Students League; worked at Pierre Matisse Gallery. Moved with second husband Lincoln Diamant to Ossining, NY, where she mastered bookbinding, then returned to painting. Ageless at 91, she was, like one of her Hudson Valley or Berkshire landscapes, the cynosure of any room. Survived by her son, Anthony Bruck, of Chicago; stepson, Rolf Diamant, and daughter-in-law Nora Mitchell, of Woodstock, VT. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, WAYNE M
Snippets: ROGERS--Wayne M. The staff at Kleinfeld Bridal is deeply saddened by the death of its Chairman, Wayne Rogers. From the 1990's to the present, Wayne in partnership with Ronald Rothstein and Mara Urshel, built Kleinfeld into the most successful designer bridal retailer in the world. He helped expand the Kleinfeld name into 150 countries through the hit "Say Yes to the Dress" TV show and he licensed the brand to HBC for Canada. Wayne followed no rules, no industry practices and believed one always had to enjoy the freedom of free thought with no boundaries. Wayne loved Kleinfeld and its success, its dedicated staff and its brides. His personal charm and caring nature was a blessing to everyone who worked at Kleinfeld. We extend our sincere and heartfelt condolences to Amy, Laura, Bill and their families. He will be truly missed. Ronald R. Rothstein and Mara Urshel 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  COTTY, EDMOND
Snippets: COTTY--Edmond, 92, died December 28 at his home in Scarsdale, NY. Son of Gustave Cotty and Marie Parisod, he earned his MBA from the University of Lausanne, Switzerland. There he met his wife, Yvette Mina Chuard. He emigrated to New York City in 1948 to join the investment firm of Istel, Lepercq & Co. He went on to be president of John Bristol & Co. (1964) and founder of Cotty, Feldman & Co. (1971) which merged with New Court Securities/Rothschild, Inc. (1974) where he directed their Investment Management Division until his retirement (1993). He was very active in the Scarsdale Congregational Church. He is predeceased by his beloved wife of 57 years, Yvette, and by his treasured daughter, Isabelle Cotty. He is survived by his daughter Anne-Claude Cotty and son Phil Cotty. A celebration of his life will be held on Saturday, January 9 at 11am at the Scarsdale Congregational Church, 1 Heathcote Road, Scarsdale, NY. Donations may be made in his honor to White Plains Hospital or Scarsdale Volunteer Ambulance. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, GILBERT
Snippets: KAPLAN--Gilbert, died peacefully on the morning of January 1, 2016, with Lena, his wife of 45 years, and their four loving children by his side. An uncommon man in every respect, he founded Institutional Investor magazine at the age of 26, serving as its Publisher and Editor-in-Chief for the next two decades, only to embark on a second life as a renowned amateur conductor of Mahler's Second Symphony. He said of the symphony that it "wrapped itself around me and never let go." This passion ultimately led to conducting engagements with over 60 orchestras throughout the world, acclaimed recordings of the work with the London Symphony Orchestra and the Vienna Philharmonic and, more recently, a faculty position at Juilliard. His private life was just as rich. He married the woman he loved at first sight, loved her deeply to the end, and together they presided over a family of four beautiful children, Kristina Wallison, Claude Davies, John Kaplan and Emily Kaplan, and eight grandchildren. All grieve profoundly at his passing, but feel deeply blessed to have loved and been loved by this remarkable man. The family will receive friends at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street) in New York City, on Thursday, January 7 at 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Friends are invited to email stories and condolences to: gilkaplanfamily@gmail.com. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILBERT, EDWARD M.
Snippets: GILBERT--Edward M.,dubbed the "Boy Wonder of Wall Street" in the 1950's, died peacefully at his home in Santa Fe, New Mexico on Wednesday, December 23, 2015. He was five days short of his 93rd birthday. Eddie lived a unique and exceptional life. As a young man, Eddie fought bravely in World War II and received a Purple Heart and a Bronze Star. He had many achievements. He was a competitive springboard diver and in 1942 made the U.S. Open at Forest Hills; he had a world-renowned stamp collection and gave generously to many causes in Santa Fe. In 1992, Eddie co-founded BGK Group, a highly successful commercial real estate company headquartered in Santa Fe. Under Eddie's leadership the company acquired a large national portfolio as well as premier buildings in New Mexico, Texas and elsewhere. By 2010, when New York-based Rosemont Real Estate acquired part ownership of BGK, Gilbert's company was the largest holder of commercial real estate in New Mexico, owning properties in 28 states. He was "larger than life" say his children. He will be greatly missed. He is survived by his wife Peaches, seven children, Robin, Alexandra (Ronald), Dominique, Nina, Sasha, Beatrice and Zoe and three grandchildren, Brooke, Ross and Yeabsira. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANGELO, JOHN
Snippets: ANGELO--John. Central Park Conservancy mourns the passing of John Angelo, devoted husband of our friend and Board member, Judy Hart Angelo. Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIALER, STEWART SIDNEY
Snippets: BIALER--Stewart Sidney, died on November 27 following a battle with melanoma. He was 72. Stewart was born in Brooklyn, NY, to Lena and Solomon Bialer. He impacted countless lives as a passionate teacher in New York City's public schools. He gave generously, sharing his wisdom, compassion, time, home, heart, harvest and money-always seeking lives to enrich and the ways in which he could help. He is survived by his wife Susan BeGasse; children Emily and Lisa; sons-in-law Jordan and Jerry; and grandchildren Ori, Alyssa, Aaron, Julia, Jacob and Laila. Stewart's son, Adam, died suddenly two weeks following his death. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHSWENDER, WOODY
Snippets: HOCHSWENDER--Woody, June 20, 1951, to December 31, 2015. His name was Wiliam Joseph Hochswender III, but everyone knew him as Woody. For many, he was the lanky, redheaded and perennially boyish fashion and style reporter for The New York Times, Harper's Bazaar, Esquire and Golf. For others, he was an inspirational practitioner of Nichiren Buddhism: he brought comfort, joy and wisdom to many through his example, his guidance and his two books, "The Buddha in Your Mirror" and "The Buddha in Your Rearview Mirror." In Sharon, CT, where he had lived since 1993, he was known as a quirky character with memorable pickup trucks (his beautiful golden retriever, Lola, nearly always along for the ride) and a passion for swimming, biking and otherwise enjoying the beauty around him. For his daughter, Kate, he was her biggest cheerleader as well as the person who always encouraged her to set a high standard and then meet it. He adored her, and she adored him. A true journalist, Woody was interested in everything; for the past few years, he was able to travel widely and meet interesting people in the company of his girlfriend, Kirsten Jensen. His daughter and former wife, Cynthia, were glad that he was able to enrich his life and expand his horizons with Kirsten before his death, from a glioblastoma tumor, on December 31. For a full obituary and details of his January 17 memorial service in Lakeville, CT, go to his memorial website at www.forevermissed.com. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKLER, RUTH

The officers and staff of The Pollock-Krasner Foundation mourn the passing of Ruth Dickler, beloved wife and widow of Gerald Dickler, the Founder Chairman of The Pollock-Krasner Foundation. For over thirty years, Ruth gave advice and counsel to the Foundation's program. We will miss her wisdom, grace and generosity. We extend our deepest sympathy to her family. Charles Bergman, Chairman Samuel Sachs II, President Kerrie Buitrago, Executive Vice President 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANGELO, JOHN

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROAMAN, JOYCE
Snippets: ROAMAN--Joyce, of Hollywood, FL, 89, passed away January 1, 2016. Joyce is predeceased by her husband Alan Norman Roaman and her son Michael Warren Roaman. She is survived by her daughter Judi Roaman and a daughter-in-law Carla Chammas and a son Peter Michael Roaman, two grandchildren, Benjamin Michael Roaman and Katherine Mixer and her husband Scott Mixer, and three great-grandchildren. Funeral services will be held today, Tuesday, January 5 at 10:30am at Temple Solel in Hollywood, FL. Interment will take place on Wednesday, January 6 at 11am at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery in Glendale, NY. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIZZUTO, PATRICIA ANNE
Snippets: RIZZUTO--Patricia Anne, 71, of New York, NY passed away on January 1, 2016 in Portland, ME. Patricia was born in Newark, NJ on March 8, 1944 the daughter of Hall of Fame Yankees shortstop Phil Rizzuto and Cora Ann Esselborn Rizzuto. She was an incredibly loving and dedicated mother and grandmother. She enjoyed spending time at her house on Fire Island and playing with her granddaughter Lucia Rizzuto-Michelsen. She is survived by her daughter Jennifer Rizzuto and her daughter-in-law Heidi Michelsen Golden; sister Penny Yetto; brother Philip Rizzuto Jr; and her beloved granddaughter Lucia Rizzuto- Michelsen. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, WAYNE M
Snippets: ROGERS--Wayne M. The staff at Kleinfeld Bridal is deeply saddened by the death of its Chairman, Wayne Rogers. From the 1990's to the present, Wayne in partnership with Ronald Rothstein and Mara Urshel, built Kleinfeld into the most successful designer bridal retailer in the world. He helped expand the Kleinfeld name into 150 countries through the hit "Say Yes to the Dress" TV show and he licensed the brand to HBC for Canada. Wayne followed no rules, no industry practices and believed one always had to enjoy the freedom of free thought with no boundaries. Wayne loved Kleinfeld and its success, its dedicated staff and its brides. His personal charm and caring nature was a blessing to everyone who worked at Kleinfeld. We extend our sincere and heartfelt condolences to Amy, Laura, Bill and their families. He will be truly missed. Ronald R. Rothstein and Mara Urshel 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLOGG, JAMES C.
Snippets: KELLOGG--James C.,IV. Born in Elizabeth, NJ, on July 2, 1939. Departed on December 31, 2015 and resided in Short Hills, NJ. Memorial Service Friday, January 8th, 12:00pm, Short Hills Community Congregational Church. Luncheon Friday, January 8th, after the service, Short Hills Club, 144 Highland Avenue. James C. Kellogg, philanthropist and loving husband, father of three children, and grandfather of nine grandchildren, died on Thursday of congestive heart failure, surrounded by his family. He was 76 years old. Jim was a graduate of The Pingry School, Princeton University, and Harvard Law School. During his career, he was a partner at the Manhattan law firm Townley & Updike, the President of the Community Foundation of New Jersey, the President of the J.C. Kellogg Foundation, and a valued trustee of many non-profit boards. He was most proud of his philanthropic work in Elizabeth, New Jersey. He cherished the idea of creating opportunities for people from disadvantaged backgrounds to be healthy, learn, and grow. Jim grew up in Elizabeth, NJ and spent his summers in Bay Head, NJ, where he made many friends whom he kept throughout his life. Those friends would gather on a regular basis for couples' dinners and bridge marathons. He looked forward to Romeo lunches, Scorpions bridge, and the Literatti book club, where he always touted the latest political book. In the past few years, Jim became a Life Master at bridge by participating in ACBL bridge tournaments across the country. He spent his winters at Yeamans Hall in South Carolina. Jim had a deep commitment to public service; he advised and served on the boards of Frost Valley YMCA, Bay Head Chapel, Short Hills Community Congregational Church, Point Pleasant Hospital, the Children's Specialized Hospital, Trinitas Regional Medical Center, Meridian Health Systems, Council of Woodrow Wilson School at Princeton University, Union County College, Bloomfield College, the Prudential Insurance Company, New Jersey State in the Trust for Public Lands, and the Scholarship Fund for Inner City Children. He was appointed by the Governor to the boards of New Jersey Transit and the New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency. His lifelong passion for philanthropy paled in comparison to his love for his family- his wife, three children, and nine grandchildren. Jim was happiest at family gatherings and loved playing backgammon and gin rummy with his children and grandchildren. Pop Pop's signature backgammon move was to wait for his opponent to admit defeat only to turn the board around and play the losing side, teaching his mentee how to stage a comeback and win! He was active in every aspect of his children's and grandchildren's lives, including attending their school events, and offering advice on and help with work issues. He is survived by his wife, Gail Chambers Kellogg, his children, Jimmy Kellogg, Kate Kellogg, and Elizabeth Kellogg Winterbottom; adoring grandchildren, Emily, Jimmy and Grace Kellogg; Chris and Andrew Kellogg Peeler; Hailey, Francesca, Maile, and Penelope Winterbottom; and his three younger brothers, Peter, Kelly, and Rusty. A service to celebrate his life will be held Friday, January 8th at 12:00pm at the Short Hills Community Congregational Church. Immediately following the service, the family invites all attendees to join them for lunch at the Short Hills Club. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Frost Valley YMCA in Claryville, NY. For more info, or to send condolences to the family, please visit www.bradleyfuneral homes.com. 1/3

Polisi, President; Ara Guzelimian, Provost and Dean; Danielle La Senna, Director of Juilliard's Evening Division 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILBERT, EDWARD M.
Snippets: GILBERT--Edward M.,dubbed the "Boy Wonder of Wall Street" in the 1950's, died peacefully at his home in Santa Fe, New Mexico on Wednesday, December 23, 2015. He was five days short of his 93rd birthday. Eddie lived a unique and exceptional life. As a young man, Eddie fought bravely in World War II and received a Purple Heart and a Bronze Star. He had many achievements. He was a competitive springboard diver and in 1942 made the U.S. Open at Forest Hills; he had a world-renowned stamp collection and gave generously to many causes in Santa Fe. In 1992, Eddie co-founded BGK Group, a highly successful commercial real estate company headquartered in Santa Fe. Under Eddie's leadership the company acquired a large national portfolio as well as premier buildings in New Mexico, Texas and elsewhere. By 2010, when New York-based Rosemont Real Estate acquired part ownership of BGK, Gilbert's company was the largest holder of commercial real estate in New Mexico, owning properties in 28 states. He was "larger than life" say his children. He will be greatly missed. He is survived by his wife Peaches, seven children, Robin, Alexandra (Ronald), Dominique, Nina, Sasha, Beatrice and Zoe and three grandchildren, Brooke, Ross and Yeabsira. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANGELO, JOHN M
Snippets: ANGELO--John M. The Board of Directors, Volunteers, and Staff of the Ronald McDonald House of New York wish to express our sincere sympathy of the passing of our dear friend and benefactor, John M. Angelo. John dutifully served as a member of the Board of Directors of our charity from 2005 to 2014 when he became a Member at Large. He was both generous and kind to the special kids and families battling cancer at the Ronald McDonald House. Our sincere sympathy and deepest condolences go out to his dear wife, Judy, his children, and the entire Angelo family. Respectfully, Tina Lundgren, Chairman of the Board; Harris Diamond, Vice Chair, Chairman Elect; Stanley B. Shopkorn, Chairman, Emeritus; Joel Newman Interim President & Chief Executive Officer, Ronald McDonald House New York 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSLER, SHEILA HAWLEY SANDERS
Snippets: MOSLER--Sheila Hawley Sanders. The loving family of Sheila Hawley Sanders Mosler, 80, is profoundly saddened by her passing on January 4, 2016. Sheila was an incredibly loving and giving person and will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved her. Born and raised in New York City, Sheila was formerly married to John Mosler Sr., Chairman of Mosler Safe Company, mother to her sons John and Bruce, and daughter Michele. Her father was Chairman of the Hudson River Day Line and an original partner of the Circle Line. Sheila's career, which spanned more than 30 years, was focused on bridging her skills and expertise in acting between political, corporate, humanitarian and educational areas in New York City and internationally. She served as the Deputy Commissioner and Executive Lobbyist for the New York State Department of Commerce, where she was appointed by Governor Nelson Rockefeller as a corporate liaison with the top management of Fortune 500, medium sized and small businesses to maintain and bring new business to New York State. She also served as a Special Assistant and Lobbyist for the Governor's Consultant on Labor & Commissioner of Human Rights, where she acted as a bridge to the labor unions and minority grounds in New York State, as well as a Member of the Governor's Special Committee, where she was appointed as the youngest member of a special committee to review state laws and procedures in the areas of human rights and labor relations. While Sheila excelled in her professional career, she also had a place in her heart for giving back to the community. She was also a successful cabaret singer and recorded an album, "Rare! Hot!". Sheila was a graduate of Finch College and received an Honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters from St. John's University. Sheila is survived by her sons, Bruce (Wendy) Mosler and John (Jean) Mosler, her daughter Michele Mosler, and her grandchildren David and Charlotte Mosler. The wake honoring her life will take place on Thursday, January 7th from 5 to 8pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel and a private Mass will follow on Friday, January 8th at 9:30am at the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRISON, RICHARD
Snippets: MORRISON--Richard. We mourn the loss of our partner, colleague and friend Richard Morrison, who suffered a heart attack and passed away on January 4. He was an important member of Weil, Gotshal & Manges LLP for nearly 30 years, and was deeply devoted to his work, colleagues and clients. As Managing Partner of Weil's Miami office and a longstanding partner in our Real Estate practice, Richard was instrumental in the development of Weil's presence in Miami and was also integral in helping to shape our global Real Estate practice. Richard split his time between our Miami and New York offices, and was known and loved by partners, associates and staff across all of Weil's offices. He graduated with a B.A. from Vanderbilt University in 1981 and earned a J.D. from the University of Florida's Levin College of Law in 1984. We will remember Richard with the utmost respect and admiration, and we offer our deepest sympathy to his family; he will be greatly missed by his many friends and colleagues at Weil. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, GILBERT
Snippets: KAPLAN--Gilbert, died peacefully on the morning of January 1, 2016, with Lena, his wife of 45 years, and their four loving children by his side. An uncommon man in every respect, he founded Institutional Investor magazine at the age of 26, serving as its Publisher and Editor-in-Chief for the next two decades, only to embark on a second life as a renowned amateur conductor of Mahler's Second Symphony. He said of the symphony that it "wrapped itself around me and never let go." This passion ultimately led to conducting engagements with over 60 orchestras throughout the world, acclaimed recordings of the work with the London Symphony Orchestra and the Vienna Philharmonic and, more recently, a faculty position at Juilliard. His private life was just as rich. He married the woman he loved at first sight, loved her deeply to the end, and together they presided over a family of four beautiful children, Kristina Wallison, Claude Davies, John Kaplan and Emily Kaplan, and eight grandchildren. All grieve profoundly at his passing, but feel deeply blessed to have loved and been loved by this remarkable man. The family will receive friends at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street) in New York City, on Thursday, January 7 at 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Friends are invited to email stories and condolences to: gilkaplanfamily@gmail.com. 1/3

Dear grandmother of William Holbrook and Douglas McClure. Adoring great- grandmother of William and Thomas Holbrook. The family will receive friends at the Graham Funeral Home in Rye, NY on Thursday from 4pm to 7pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Friday at the Church of the Resurrection at 10am. Entombment to follow at Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSMAN, JULIA ZLABOVSKY
Snippets: WEISSMAN--Julia Zlabovsky, 98, died on October 15, 2015 after a brief illness. Born in El Paso, Texas, she graduated from the College of Mines and Metallurgy of the University of Texas and later settled in New York City to pursue a career as a writer and editor. As author or co-author, she published books and articles in many areas of the arts and crafts, including folk art, needlework and cooking. She was predeceased by her sisters, Vera Zlabovsky and Esther Boxer and by her brothers Isador (Saul) Stuart and David Stuart. She is survived by her daughter Erica Weissman, brother Frank Stuart, nephew David Stuart, nieces Elizabeth Stuart and Rebecca Orlowski (Steven), and grandnephews Jesse, Derek, and Paul Orlowski. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, DONALD K. SR.
Snippets: ROSS--Donald K. Sr.,of Franklin Lakes, NJ, Water Mill, NY and Vero Beach, FL passed away at his home in New Jersey on January 5, 2016 after an extended illness. He was born in 1925, the son of Alexander and Althea Grainger Ross of Ridgewood, NJ. Mr. Ross was the valedictorian of his Ridgewood High School class in 1942 and matriculated as an undergraduate at Yale University in the V 12 United States Navy training program. While at Yale he was a member of the varsity swim team and majored in electrical engineering. Upon graduation he was commissioned as an ensign in the U.S. Navy. After three years of active duty in the Navy he resigned his commission and entered Harvard Business School. Upon graduation he spent a summer as a counselor at Camp Pemigewassett in Wentworth, NH where he and his brother Sandy had spent their boyhood summers. He soon joined New York Life Insurance Company as a trainee. Mr. Ross spent his entire professional career at New York Life, culminating with his serving for a decade as its CEO, President and Chairman of its board of directors. Don met the love of his life, Mary Fyffe, in the second grade. They were married in 1949 and she survives him; along with their four children Catherine Lesher (Charles), Susan Morris (William), D. Keith Ross, Jr. (Suzanne) and Deborah Cipriano (Gaetano), along with nine grandchildren, three step-grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. He is also survived by his younger brother Alexander "Sandy" Ross and many nieces and nephews and their families. He was a beloved family man and a true gentleman of the old school with a calm demeanor, impeccable judgment, and an illuminating smile. Mr. Ross was a life- long, enthusiastic golfer. He was an active member of the Arcola Country Club in Paramus, NJ, National Golf Links of America in Southampton, NY, and the Moorings Country Club, Vero Beach, FL. He also was a longtime member of the Indian Trail Club in Franklin Lakes, NJ where he played competitive platform tennis for many years. In addition to his career with New York Life Insurance Co., Mr. Ross was Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the YMCA of Greater New York; Trustee of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc. and the Colonial Williamsburg Foundation; and a member of the Boards of Directors of the Committee for Economic Development and the New York Chamber of Commerce. In addition he was an elder and building committee member of the Presbyterian Church of Franklin Lakes, NJ and he was instrumental in the construction of its Church on Franklin Lake Road. A Memorial Service will be held on Friday, January 8, 2016 at 4pm at the High Mountain Presbyterian Church, 730 Franklin Lake Road, Franklin Lakes, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Hackensack UMC Foundation Heart Failure Fund, 360 Essex Street, Suite 301. Hackensack, NJ 07601 or by calling 551-996-3720. Services by Vander Plaat-Vermeulen Memorial Home, 530 High Mountain Road, Franklin Lakes, NJ 07417. For further info. please visit www.vpmemorial.com or call us at (201)891-4770. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOULEZ, PIERRE
Snippets: BOULEZ--Pierre. The Board of Trustees and staff of Carnegie Hall celebrate the life of our dear friend and colleague Pierre Boulez, one of the most important and influential artists of the 20th century. A legendary composer, conductor, musical philosopher and activist, Pierre Boulez was a visionary and trailblazing global force for modern music. Carnegie Hall was privileged to elect him an Honorary Trustee in 1995, and to appoint him as the Richard and Barbara Debs Composer's Chair from 1999 to 2003. Boulez made approximately 75 appearances at Carnegie Hall, conducting close to 60 performances on our stages, and his works have been performed on more than 80 programs. As an arts educator, he was inspirational-challenging audiences to explore a new aesthetic of music through his musical research center IRCAM, and, in the course of the Professional Training Workshops he led through Carnegie Hall's Weill Music Institute, offering profound insights to young musicians. Boulez's work in Paris served as an inspiration in the conception of Zankel Hall, the opening season of which included performances by Boulez with the Ensemble Intercontemporain. Pierre Boulez will be deeply missed by all of us at Carnegie Hall and by the entire artistic community, though his brilliant musical legacy and pioneering spirit will stay with us all. We express heartfelt condolences to his sister, Jeanne Chevalier Boulez, and brother, Roger Boulez, as well as their many children and grandchildren. Sanford I. Weill, President; Mercedes T. Bass, Acting Chairman; Clive Gillinson, Executive & Artistic Director 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Memorials  COOPER, WYATT E
Snippets: COOPER--Wyatt E. Sept. 1, 1927-Jan. 5, 1978. Daddy and Carter within us always. Gloria and Anderson. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, GILBERT
Snippets: KAPLAN--Gilbert. The Juilliard School community mourns the passing of Gilbert Kaplan, a member of the school's Evening Division faculty since 2000 and devoted supporter of the arts around the world. Through his popular courses on Mahler for music lovers, Gil brought his extraordinary expertise and passion to a composer whose work is better understood through his scholarship and performances. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Lena, and his beautiful family. He will be deeply missed by all. Joseph W. Polisi, President; Ara Guzelimian, Provost and Dean; Danielle La Senna, Director of Juilliard's Evening Division 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Memorials  PETSCHEK, CHARLES I
Snippets: PETSCHEK--Charles I. Three years without you. Most special of men. Always in our hearts, always loved. Elaine, children and grandchildren 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, GILBERT
Snippets: KAPLAN--Gilbert, died peacefully on the morning of January 1, 2016, with Lena, his wife of 45 years, and their four loving children by his side. An uncommon man in every respect, he founded Institutional Investor magazine at the age of 26, serving as its Publisher and Editor-in-Chief for the next two decades, only to embark on a second life as a renowned amateur conductor of Mahler's Second Symphony. He said of the symphony that it "wrapped itself around me and never let go." This passion ultimately led to conducting engagements with over 60 orchestras throughout the world, acclaimed recordings of the work with the London Symphony Orchestra and the Vienna Philharmonic and, more recently, a faculty position at Juilliard. His private life was just as rich. He married the woman he loved at first sight, loved her deeply to the end, and together they presided over a family of four beautiful children, Kristina Wallison, Claude Davies, John Kaplan and Emily Kaplan, and eight grandchildren. All grieve profoundly at his passing, but feel deeply blessed to have loved and been loved by this remarkable man. The family will receive friends at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street) in New York City, on Thursday, January 7 at 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Friends are invited to email stories and condolences to: gilkaplanfamily@gmail.com. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOULEZ, PIERRE
Snippets: BOULEZ--Pierre. The New York Philharmonic deeply mourns the passing of Pierre Boulez, our bold and innovative Music Director from 1971 to 1977 as well as a trailblazing composer and thinker. Under Boulez, the Philharmonic introduced concert formats that brought the audience in direct contact with composers and performers, including the informal Rug Concerts and downtown Prospective Encounters. He returned in 1986 for a 14- event series highlighting his work as conductor, composer, and leader of the Ensemble Intercontemporain. In 1992 he celebrated the Philharmonic's 150th anniversary in a concert also led by former Music Directors Zubin Mehta and Kurt Masur. In the same year Boulez was made an Honorary Member of the Society, an honor shared by such figures as Wagner, Stravinsky, and Bernstein. New York Philharmonic Music Director Alan Gilbert said: "Pierre Boulez was a towering and influential musical figure whose Philharmonic leadership implicitly laid down a challenge of innovation and invention that continues to inspire us to this day. To me, personally, he also was an unfailingly gracious mentor and friend, from the years when I worked with him in Cleveland and when I was appointed to the Philharmonic to the last time I saw him in Baden- Baden on a Philharmonic tour. I will miss his musicianship, kindness, and wisdom." The New York Philharmonic family sends our love and compassion to his family. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHANNON, GEORGE E.
Snippets: SHANNON--George E.,83, Broadcast Pioneer dies. George Shannon was President of CBS in the 70s and 80s, during the golden years of the "Tiffany Network." He oversaw all broadcast production facilities nationwide, all remote production including sports events and major news coverages, network distribution system, engineering and development. Countless Emmy Awards for engineering excellence were earned under his leadership and vision. Mr. Shannon, of West Islip, Long Island, passed on January 4, 2016. He was the beloved husband of the late Rita J. Shannon. He was the devoted father of Sharon Ann Fuentes, Barbara Ann Kelly and Michael T. Shannon and the cherished grandfather of six. Mr. Shannon will be reposing at The Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons West Islip Funeral Home, 1225 Montauk Hwy., (Quarter mile west of the Robert Moses Cswy). Celebration of the Liturgy of Christian Burial, Saturday 10:00am at St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Babylon, Long Island. Interment to follow at St. Patrick's Cemetery, Huntington, Long Island. Visiting Friday, 2:00pm until 4:30pm and 7:00pm until 9:30pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, P.O. Box 5028, Hagerstown, MD 21741-5028 or to St. Johnland Nursing Center, 395 Sunken Meadow Road, Kings Park, NY 11754. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERT, CAROLYN MCDANIEL
Snippets: HALPERT--Carolyn McDaniel. The Methodist Home for Nursing and Rehabilitation notes with sorrow the passing of our esteemed, very active Board member, Carolyn Halpert. Her hard work on behalf of the residents will be sorely missed, as well as her gracious presence at our meetings. We extend our sincere condolences to her family and her fellow parishioners at Christ Church United Methodist, where a memorial service will be held on Sunday, January 10 at 2pm. Methodist Home for Nursing and Rehabilitation Maria Perez, Chief Executive Officer Graham Relf, President, Board of Directors 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANGELO, JOHN M
Snippets: ANGELO--John M. The Board of Directors, Volunteers, and Staff of the Ronald McDonald House of New York wish to express our sincere sympathy of the passing of our dear friend and benefactor, John M. Angelo. John dutifully served as a member of the Board of Directors of our charity from 2005 to 2014 when he became a Member at Large. He was both generous and kind to the special kids and families battling cancer at the Ronald McDonald House. Our sincere sympathy and deepest condolences go out to his dear wife, Judy, his children, and the entire Angelo family. Respectfully, Tina Lundgren, Chairman of the Board; Harris Diamond, Vice Chair, Chairman Elect; Stanley B. Shopkorn, Chairman, Emeritus; Joel Newman Interim President & Chief Executive Officer, Ronald McDonald House New York 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, CLAIRE
Snippets: SCHNEIDER--Claire, 92, died on January 5, 2016. She was predeceased by her husband of 54 years, David. She is survived by her daughters Stephanie Singer of Florida, Amy Schneider of New Hampshire and Tina Schneider of Maine. She is also survived by her seven grandchildren, three great-grandchildren, and an extended family who loved her dearly. Funeral services to be held at noon on January 7th at Riverside Memorial Chapel, New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America or the Multiple Sclerosis Foundation. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWADOS, ELIZABETH
Snippets: SWADOS--Elizabeth. The Peter S. Reed Foundation extends deepest sympathies to fellow board member Roz Lichter on the passing of her brilliant wife, Liz Swados. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLOBUS, SARAH
Snippets: GLOBUS--Sarah, died at home on December 13, 2015. She is survived by her husband, Herschel Goldfield, her children, Ori and Vivian, and by sisters Martha Globus-Rodriguez and Laura Day. Sarah is remembered with great love and affection by her family and friends and by the community in Manhattan Valley, where she devoted many years of her life helping children and others in need as the founder of Neighborhood Kids of Harlem. Sarah graduated from Hunter College and Columbia Law School. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to Children's Aid Society. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRISON, RICHARD
Snippets: MORRISON--Richard. We mourn the loss of our partner, colleague and friend Richard Morrison, who suffered a heart attack and passed away on January 4. He was an important member of Weil, Gotshal & Manges LLP for nearly 30 years, and was deeply devoted to his work, colleagues and clients. As Managing Partner of Weil's Miami office and a longstanding partner in our Real Estate practice, Richard was instrumental in the development of Weil's presence in Miami and was also integral in helping to shape our global Real Estate practice. Richard split his time between our Miami and New York offices, and was known and loved by partners, associates and staff across all of Weil's offices. He graduated with a B.A. from Vanderbilt University in 1981 and earned a J.D. from the University of Florida's Levin College of Law in 1984. We will remember Richard with the utmost respect and admiration, and we offer our deepest sympathy to his family; he will be greatly missed by his many friends and colleagues at Weil. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLNEK, STEPHEN S
Snippets: WOLNEK--Stephen S. The Jewish Community Relations Council of New York mourns the passing of our esteemed Board member, Executive Committee member, and dear friend, Stephen Wolnek. A national and global Jewish leader, Steve was involved with JCRC-NY for three decades and served as an officer and co-chair of our Israel and International Affairs Commission. May his wife, Elysia, and entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Ronald G. Weiner President Michael S. Miller Exec. VP and CEO 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUBERT, DAVID PAUL
Snippets: SCHUBERT--David Paul, passed away on Saint John's Day 2015. Beloved of family Chris, Danielle and Joann. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANGELO, JOHN
Snippets: ANGELO--John. The Smithsonian Community is deeply saddened by the passing of John Angelo. Together with his wife, Judy Hart Angelo, a National Board member, John was a loyal and generous friend to the Smithsonian, strong and supportive partner in Judy's board service, gracious New York City host and leader with her in helping the institution renew its brand and external communications in this new millennium. We are grateful to have benefitted from his commitment, foresight and many contributions. Our deepest sympathies go out to John's wife, Judy, their children, Jack, Jesse and Kate and their families and friends. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANGELO, JOHN
Snippets: ANGELO--John. We mourn the death of our pal John Angelo, whose energy, confidence and love of life inspired everyone he knew. Our family's sympathies go to his devoted wife Judy and their children Kate, Jack and Jesse. Susan and Peter Solomon and Family 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANLEY, TED
Snippets: STANLEY--Ted. The Brain & Behavior Research Foundation, formerly the National Alliance for Research on Schizophrenia and Depression (NARSAD), mourns the passing of Ted Stanley, a prominent philanthropist for mental health research and our organization. Mr. Stanley in partnership with his wife, Vada, who passed away in 2013, were early supporters and kind friends to the Brain & Behavior Research Foundation. Their generosity in supporting research on mental illness is a great model for all of us. We recognize that they have enhanced the lives of many through their work and have the deepest gratitude to them both. Our deepest sympathies to their son Jonathan and to all of their loved ones. Jeffrey Borenstein, M.D., President Constance E. Lieber, President Emerita Stephen A. Lieber, Chairman of the Board Herbert A. Pardes, M.D., President of the Scientific Council 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALDWIN, ROBERT H.B
Snippets: BALDWIN--Robert H.B. NewYork-Presbyterian is deeply saddened by the loss of Robert H.B. Baldwin, a beloved friend of our institution. Mr. Baldwin served as Vice Chairman of the Board of Trustees at The Presbyterian Hospital (now NewYork- Presbyterian), and was elected a Life Trustee in 1997 in recognition of his outstanding contributions to the Hospital. A man of extraordinary talent and vision, he emphasized the importance of philanthropy as chairman of Morgan Stanley, and fostered an enduring bond between the firm and NewYork-Presbyterian that continues to advance patient care for New Yorkers and patients around the world. We offer our sincere condolences to his wife, Dorothy, his children and stepchildren and all of his family and loved ones. Frank A. Bennack, Jr., Chairman of the Board John J. Mack, Vice Chair of the Board Jerry I. Speyer, Vice Chair of the Board Steven J. Corwin, MD, CEO NewYork-Presbyterian 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWADOS, ELIZABETH
Snippets: SWADOS--Elizabeth. Pure of heart. Soul sister, goofmother, genius. She sang to the Lord a new song. We are with you, Roz. Nessa Rapoport, Tobi Kahn, Josh, Mattie, Doria 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARK, ERIKA REIDER
Snippets: MARK--Erika Reider, of New York City and East Hampton died on January 5, 2016 after a brief illness. She was predeceased by her husband Richard, to whom she was lovingly married for 57 years. She is survived by her daughters, Jennifer and Audrey, and grandchildren Emily, Johnny, Henry, Tommy and Charlie, as well as her brothers, Alan and Jeffrey Reider. She graduated from Wellesley College and had a stellar career as a magazine editor. She received the National Magazine Award for her work at Good Housekeeping and was honored at a reception with President Clinton at the White House. She was fluent in five languages and was an avid world traveler with an adventurous spirit. She enjoyed playing tennis at the East Hampton Tennis Club and golf at the Noyac Golf Club as well as participating in two book clubs. Most of all she loved spending time with her family who greatly adored her and will miss her terribly. Funeral services to be held Friday January 8, 2016 at 2:00pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, SYLVIA F.
Snippets: SIMON--Sylvia F.,age 89, died January 3 at her home in Rye, NY. Beloved wife of the late Franklin Simon II. Devoted mother of Cici Holbrook and Leslie Simon. Dear grandmother of William Holbrook and Douglas McClure. Adoring great- grandmother of William and Thomas Holbrook. The family will receive friends at the Graham Funeral Home in Rye, NY on Thursday from 4pm to 7pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Friday at the Church of the Resurrection at 10am. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAISER, WALTER
Snippets: KAISER--Walter, May 31, 1931 to January 5, 2016. Born in Bellevue, Ohio during the Depression, the son of a grocer, he became a page in the U.S. Senate in 1944 and then won scholarships to Philips Academy, Andover and Harvard, an institution he didn't leave until retirement. He graduated magna cum laude with highest honors in 1954, received his Ph.D. in 1960, and was made Professor of English and Comparative Literature in 1969. From 1988 to 2002 he served as Director of Villa I Tatti, the Harvard University Center for Italian Renaissance Studies in Florence. His leadership profoundly shaped I Tatti, and those were among his happiest years; he always felt that he truly belonged to the northern Mediterranean, especially to Greece and Italy. His love of learning and the arts gave color and depth to every aspect of his life. Few people have been more learned or more cultivated, wittier or more awake to beauty. Fewer still have had his genius for friendship. He was extraordinarily generous with his attention, and always finding opportunities for generosity where others wouldn't have seen them. He was the best of fathers. He is survived by his children, Miranda and David, and three granddaughters; by his brother, Bob; by his many godchildren; and by hundreds of others whose lives he enriched immeasurably, as the astonishing outpouring of grief and love from around the world since his death attests. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Walter Kaiser Fund for the Biblioteca Berenson at Villa I Tatti, Harvard University. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, HONORABLE JUDITH
Snippets: KAYE--Honorable Judith. The NYU School of Law mourns the passing of our distinguished alumna, the Honorable Judith Kaye '62. Judge Kaye, who served for 25 years on the New York Court of Appeals and was its Chief Judge from 1993 to 2008, was a trailblazer for women, a brilliant jurist, and a vocal advocate for legal reform. She was also a deeply committed member of the NYU Law community. In addition to serving as a trustee in the 1980s and '90s, she was an advisory board member of our Center on Civil Justice; a director of our Institute for Judicial Administration; and recipient of nearly all of our most distinguished awards for alumni achievement and service. We are grateful for her life and deeply saddened by her loss. NYU School of Law Trevor Morrison, Dean 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, JUDITH S
Snippets: KAYE--Judith S. With heartfelt sadness, the Trustees and Administration of Barnard College mourn the passing of the Honorable Judith S. Kaye '58, who was a devoted alumna, a Barnard Trustee from 1995 to 2002, and again from 2008 to 2009, an active trustee emerita, and a member of the Athena Center Board of Advisors. In 1987, she received the College's highest honor, the Barnard Medal of Distinction, and in 2010, the Frederick A.P. Barnard Award for all she has done for women, for the rights of the individual, and for her alma mater. Barnard honors the memory of this extraordinary woman and extends its deepest sympathies to her family. Jolyne Caruso-FitzGerald Chair, Board of Trustees Debora Spar, President 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARK, ERIKA REIDER
Snippets: MARK--Erika Reider, of New York City and East Hampton died on January 5, 2016 after a brief illness. She was predeceased by her husband Richard, to whom she was lovingly married for 57 years. She is survived by her daughters, Jennifer and Audrey, and grandchildren Emily, Johnny, Henry, Tommy and Charlie, as well as her brothers, Alan and Jeffrey Reider. She graduated from Wellesley College and had a stellar career as a magazine editor. She received the National Magazine Award for her work at Good Housekeeping and was honored at a reception with President Clinton at the White House. She was fluent in five languages and was an avid world traveler with an adventurous spirit. She enjoyed playing tennis at the East Hampton Tennis Club and golf at the Noyac Golf Club as well as participating in two book clubs. Most of all she loved spending time with her family who greatly adored her and will miss her terribly. Funeral services to be held Friday January 8, 2016 at 2:00pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, JUDITH S
Snippets: KAYE--Judith S. The members of the Boards of the Fund and Committee for Modern Courts mourn the passing of the former Chief Judge of the State of New York, our fellow Board member, colleague, and outstanding advocate for judicial reform. May she rest in peace. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, JUDITH
Snippets: KAYE--Judith. January 7. The partners, attorneys and staff of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP mourn the passing of our colleague and friend Judith Kaye. Before joining our New York appellate litigation and arbitration practice in 2009, Judith spent 25 years on the bench of the New York Court of Appeals, including the last 15 as its Chief Judge. The first woman to serve on New York's highest court, Judith earned a national reputation for her pioneering opinions and court reforms. She wrote seminal opinions on such issues as the death penalty, same-sex marriage, education and state constitutional rights while leading innovative changes to the New York court system, including the establishment of specialized courts to focus on issues of drug addiction, domestic violence and mental health. As Chief Judge, Judith created the Adoption Now program, helped establish the Center for Court Innovation and co-chaired the ABA Commission on the American Jury. She retired from the bench in 2008, having served longer than any Chief Judge in state history. At Skadden, Judith helped numerous clients navigate complex issues of New York law. She also served as a trustee of the Skadden Fellowship Foundation and continued her advocacy for families and children, including through her service as the chairwoman of the Permanent Judicial Commission on Justice for Children. Judith graduated from Barnard College ('58) and NYU School of Law ('62), where she was one of 10 women in a class of nearly 300. Judith is survived by her children, Luisa, Jonathan and Gordon, and seven grandchildren. She will be greatly missed. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, HON
Snippets: KAYE--Hon. Judith S. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts deeply mourn the passing of the Hon. Judith S. Kaye, former Chief Judge of the New York State Court of Appeals and the first woman to lead the state's judiciary. A passionate supporter of the performing arts, she was a Lincoln Center board member, where she made a lasting contribution as Chairman of the Legal Committee. Judge Kaye also served on the board of Lincoln Center Education and she was honored at our David Rubenstein Atrium Gala in 2013. Her wisdom, leadership and friendship inspired us daily. We offer our sincerest condolences to her children Luisa, Jonathan, and Gordon, their spouses and children, and to her many friends and former colleagues. Katherine Farley, Chairman Jed Bernstein, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLSON, CLAUDIA
Snippets: CARLSON--Claudia, died at the Dawn Greene Hospice in her 59th year on January 6, 2016. Claudia was born in Bloomington, Indiana to Elof and Helen (nee Zuckerman) Carlson and raised in six college towns. She was an illustrator, graphic designer, book designer, cartographer, photographer, and poet. She wrote three books of poetry, co-edited one volume of poetry, and wrote and illustrated a children's book. She worked for Farrar, Straus and Giroux, Oxford University Press, and American Friends of Magen David Adom. She also was a founding member of River Writers of Manhattan. She received her BA at Stony Brook University. After her mother's death she was raised by her father and Nedra (nee Miller) Carlson with her younger siblings, Christina, Erica, John and Anders. With David Allen she had two children Natalie (nee Allen) Hardaker, and Caitlin Allen. She is also survived by her husband, playwright James Racheff. A memorial service is planned for early spring. Condolences can be sent to: claudiacarlson@gmail.com 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, HONORABLE JUDITH S
Snippets: KAYE--Honorable Judith S. at home on January 7, 2016. Beloved wife of the late Stephen. Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  SQUIRE, ANNETTE C
Snippets: SQUIRE--Annette C. of Boynton Beach, FL, devoted and beloved wife for almost 60 years of the (late) Albert Squire, daughter of the late Irving and Bella (nee Lehman) Cohen, sister of the late Molly Gershen, mother of Jeffrey and Judi Squire, loving grandmother of Evan and Emma Squire, and aunt to Robert and Joe Gershen, Susan Stoll, Susan Albright and Laura Stamm, passed away peacefully surrounded by family on December 8, 2015 at Delray Medical Center following a stroke on December 7. Annette, who turned 90 December 2, graduated with a B.S. from Columbia University School of Nursing and an M.S. from the University of Pennsylvania School of Nursing. Starting her career in New York City for the Visiting Nurse Service, Annette then spent many years in Pennsylvania as a school nurse for the Pennsbury School System. All who knew Annette recognized that she was a caring and skillful nurse and loving mother, aunt, grandmother, sister, daughter, niece, cousin and friend. Annette cared deeply for the people in her life and we all will miss her warm smile, concern, and love. Her family expresses their heartfelt appreciation to her skillful, kind, loving and warm caregivers, Kimberly Barrett and Jacques Clervil. A memorial service is being planned for early 2016. The family knows that Annette would appreciate contributions in her memory to the University of Pennsylvania School of Nursing 215-898-484 nursing.upenn.edu/friends giving, Columbia University School of Nursing, 866-GIFTSYS, or nursing.columbia.edu/giving, a charity benefiting Israel or any charity of your choice. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAVET, STANLEY
Snippets: KRAVET--Stanley, 81, passed peacefully at home in Manhasset, NY, with his family and devoted wife Rhoda Kravet by his side. Born in 1934 in Brooklyn, NY to Rose and Morris Kravet, he graduated from Boys High and NYU School of Business, where he met his wife. He attended Brooklyn Law School on a full scholarship and after graduating he began working at Royal Abstract, a New York City title insurance agency. He spent over 45 years building Royal Abstract into a well known and successful company and welcomed his son Martin into the business in 1985. He was very well respected by all who knew him. Outside of his work he was involved in the rebuilding of the Jewish Center of Bayside Oaks, in Queens. He enjoyed golf and was an esteemed member of Engineers Country Club and Cold Spring Country Club. He and his wife spent winters at Boca West in Boca Raton, Florida where they were members of Boca West Country Club. He was a kind and proud man who was devoted to his family. He is survived by his wife of 59 years, Rhoda, loving father to son Martin (wife Susan) and daughter Susan Pecker (husband Elliot) and his adored grandchildren, Justin, Rachel, Dylan and Caroline. He was a loving husband, father, grandfather and brother and he will be greatly missed. Funeral service will be held at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, in New York City on Friday, January 8 at 12pm. 1/3

His patience, wisdom, optimism, generosity and strong family values will be sorely missed by all who were privileged to know him. Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOULEZ, PIERRE
Snippets: BOULEZ--Pierre. The Board of Trustees and staff of Carnegie Hall celebrate the life of our dear friend and colleague Pierre Boulez, one of the most important and influential artists of the 20th century. A legendary composer, conductor, musical philosopher and activist, Pierre Boulez was a visionary and trailblazing global force for modern music. Carnegie Hall was privileged to elect him an Honorary Trustee in 1995, and to appoint him as the Richard and Barbara Debs Composer's Chair from 1999 to 2003. Boulez made approximately 75 appearances at Carnegie Hall, conducting close to 60 performances on our stages, and his works have been performed on more than 80 programs. As an arts educator, he was inspirational-challenging audiences to explore a new aesthetic of music through his musical research center IRCAM, and, in the course of the Professional Training Workshops he led through Carnegie Hall's Weill Music Institute, offering profound insights to young musicians. Boulez's work in Paris served as an inspiration in the conception of Zankel Hall, the opening season of which included performances by Boulez with the Ensemble Intercontemporain. Pierre Boulez will be deeply missed by all of us at Carnegie Hall and by the entire artistic community, though his brilliant musical legacy and pioneering spirit will stay with us all. We express heartfelt condolences to his sister, Jeanne Chevalier Boulez, and brother, Roger Boulez, as well as their many children and grandchildren. Sanford I. Weill, President; Mercedes T. Bass, Acting Chairman; Clive Gillinson, Executive & Artistic Director 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEFF, GLORIA NELSON
Snippets: SEFF--Gloria Nelson, died on January 7, 2016 at the age of 90. Beloved mother of Liane B. Onish. Stepmother of Barbara. Sister of Miriam. Aunt of Janet and Robert. Contributions in her name may be made to Planned Parenthood or Hunter College Mother's Day Fund. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, JUDITH
Snippets: KAYE--Judith. January 7. The partners, attorneys and staff of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP mourn the passing of our colleague and friend Judith Kaye. Before joining our New York appellate litigation and arbitration practice in 2009, Judith spent 25 years on the bench of the New York Court of Appeals, including the last 15 as its Chief Judge. The first woman to serve on New York's highest court, Judith earned a national reputation for her pioneering opinions and court reforms. She wrote seminal opinions on such issues as the death penalty, same-sex marriage, education and state constitutional rights while leading innovative changes to the New York court system, including the establishment of specialized courts to focus on issues of drug addiction, domestic violence and mental health. As Chief Judge, Judith created the Adoption Now program, helped establish the Center for Court Innovation and co-chaired the ABA Commission on the American Jury. She retired from the bench in 2008, having served longer than any Chief Judge in state history. At Skadden, Judith helped numerous clients navigate complex issues of New York law. She also served as a trustee of the Skadden Fellowship Foundation and continued her advocacy for families and children, including through her service as the chairwoman of the Permanent Judicial Commission on Justice for Children. Judith graduated from Barnard College ('58) and NYU School of Law ('62), where she was one of 10 women in a class of nearly 300. Judith is survived by her children, Luisa, Jonathan and Gordon, and seven grandchildren. She will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be held at 10:00am (doors open at 9:15), Monday, January 11, at the David H. Koch Theater, Lincoln Center. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLANTZ, IRWIN L.
Snippets: GLANTZ--Irwin L.,91, died peacefully at home on December 26, 2015 after a brief illness, with his loving family at his side. He is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, Gene; devoted children Paul, Judith Kingman, and Robert; grandchildren Alexander and Garrett Kingman and Michelle and David Glantz, and nephew Bruce Kauderer. A consummate gentleman, he was a World War II veteran, lawyer, founder of real estate development, investment and management firm, Windsor Properties, and esteemed patriarch of his extended family. His patience, wisdom, optimism, generosity and strong family values will be sorely missed by all who were privileged to know him. Laid to rest in Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, New York on December 28, 2015. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, HON
Snippets: KAYE--Hon. Judith S. The Fordham Law community is deeply saddened by the death of Hon. Judith S. Kaye, former Chief Judge of the New State Court of Appeals. She was a great friend of Fordham Law School and its alumni, particularly those serving in the state and federal judiciary. Over the years, she wrote for the Fordham Law Review and other journals, and she inspired students, graduates, and alumni with her remarks at the school's diploma ceremony, conferences, and lecture series. The school honored her in 2002 with the Fordham- Stein Prize, which is presented annually to a member of the legal profession whose work embodies the highest standards of the legal profession. In 2012, she participated in a special conversation alongside retired Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O'Connor that canvassed their concerns about the election of judges, the importance of civic education and involvement for lawyers, and their pathbreaking appointments as the first women to hold their respective judicial roles. In addition to her jurisprudence, her administrative impact will leave an indelible mark on the office of Chief Judge of the State of New York. We extend our deepest sympathy to her colleagues at Skadden Arps and her family. Matthew Diller, Dean Fordham Law School 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Memorials  SINGER, DAVID
