Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, PETER L
Snippets: SIEGEL--Peter L. It is with heavy hearts, we announce that Peter L. Siegel died January 6, 2016 due to complications from a bone marrow transplant for the treatment of Leukemia. Peter was born in New York City on March 24, 1950 and grew up in Great Neck, NY. He has a BA from the University of Mass. Amherst, and holds two masters degrees from the University of Chicago. He was a passionate sailor and resided in Brooklyn, NY. He is survived by his sister and brother-in-law, Deborah and William Cosentino, seven cousins, as well as his very dear friends Dave Turner and Christine Benner. He is and will be greatly missed. We will be holding a memorial service for Peter this spring in New York City, time and location to be announced. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWAT, ANNE HADLEY
Snippets: HOWAT--Anne Hadley. 27 September 1937 - 5 January 2016. Executive volunteer in family planning through EngenderHealth. She was married to her best friend Jock, who died in June, for 57 years. She was a loving mother to her daughters, Karen and Laura, both surviving, and a kind and engaging friend to many. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to EngenderHealth, New York City. Memorial plans are to be determined. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIBERTINI, RICHARD JOSEPH
Snippets: LIBERTINI--Richard Joseph, actor, died January 7, after a two year battle against cancer. He was born nearly 83 years ago in Cambridge, MA to Esther and Rocco Libertini. He graduated from Emerson College and was partner with MacIntyre Dixon and Linda Segal in the uproarious act they named, "Stewed Prunes" which played in coffee houses in New York, Los Angeles, and Chicago. His first Broadway play was in Woody Allen's "Don't Drink the Water." His last was in Allen's "Relatively Speaking" in 2011-12. Richard worked in a number of television series, and movies, most notably as the Guru in the film, "All of Me," and the crazy General in "The In-laws." He is survived by his son Richard, a musician, sister Alice Langone, brother Albert, brother-in-law Mike Langone, sister-in-law Catherine Dillon, cousin Mario Libertini of Abruzzi, Italy, beloved nieces and nephews, former wife, and friend Melinda Dillon, and many true and great friends. A memorial service will be held in the future. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIGDER, HARRIET (FEIN)
Snippets: WIGDER--Harriet (Fein). We regret to announce the untimely passing of Harriet (Fein) Wigder. Harriet was born in Brooklyn, NY on June 23, 1930 to Betty and Victor Fein. She was a graduate of Hunter College and obtained a Master of Arts degrees from Teachers College, Columbia University. Harriet was an elementary school teacher in the New York City public school system. She had a special fondness for children, their education and integration into the mainstream of New York cultural life. Harriet was an early devotee of the fledgling State of Israel and visited Israel in her teenage years and many times thereafter. She was married to Dr. Bernard Wigder and they lived in Riverdale, New York for many years. They were actively involved in community charitable activities and were supportive of the Jewish Theological Seminary and the Riverdale Jewish Center. In retirement the Wigders lived in Pembroke Pines, Florida and continued their participation there in communal affairs. Bernard died in 2005. Harriet remained the beloved matriarch of her family and the extended Feinzeig clan. She passed away last Shabbat afternoon, January 2, 2016 with her immediate family in attendance. Harriet leaves her brother Jack, her sister-in- law Karin and her niece Shifra, who treasure her memory. Contributions in her name should be directed to the Hadassah Women's Organization. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOULEZ, PIERRE
Snippets: BOULEZ--Pierre. The Directors of the Amphion Foundation, Inc. acknowledge with deep regret and sorrow the passing of Pierre Boulez, longtime friend and colleague of our founder, Elliott Carter. Their close relationship began in 1955 when Carter attended the premiere of "Le Marteau Sans Maitre" and continued without interruption until Carter's passing in 2012. Although he will be greatly missed by many, his stature as a preeminent composer and conductor, and his devotion to contemporary music, has created a permanent legacy which will continue to influence the development of music for many years to come. The Amphion Foundation, Inc. Virgil Blackwell, President James M. Kendrick, Secretary 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHUBB, HENDON
Snippets: CHUBB--Hendon. Hendon Chubb, an eccentric polymath, died suddenly January 3rd. He was a husband, father, grandfather, brother, artist, writer, psychologist, dog-lover, Yale graduate, rug designer, director and CFO of a Fortune 500 Company, honorary Girl Scout, gardener, officer of the American Cycad Society, vintner, army veteran, civil rights election monitor, early programmer, lover of France, Justice of the Peace, and poet. He was much loved by many and is sorely missed. A service will be held in the spring. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHSWENDER, WOODY
Snippets: HOCHSWENDER--Woody, June 20, 1951, to December 31, 2015. His name was Wiliam Joseph Hochswender III, but everyone knew him as Woody. For many, he was the lanky, redheaded and perennially boyish fashion and style reporter for The New York Times, Harper's Bazaar, Esquire and Golf. For others, he was an inspirational practitioner of Nichiren Buddhism: he brought comfort, joy and wisdom to many through his example, his guidance and his two books, "The Buddha in Your Mirror" and "The Buddha in Your Rearview Mirror." In Sharon, CT, where he had lived since 1993, he was known as a quirky character with memorable pickup trucks (his beautiful golden retriever, Lola, nearly always along for the ride) and a passion for swimming, biking and otherwise enjoying the beauty around him. For his daughter, Kate, he was her biggest cheerleader as well as the person who always encouraged her to set a high standard and then meet it. He adored her, and she adored him. A true journalist, Woody was interested in everything; for the past few years, he was able to travel widely and meet interesting people in the company of his girlfriend, Kirsten Jensen. His daughter and former wife, Cynthia, were glad that he was able to enrich his life and expand his horizons with Kirsten before his death, from a glioblastoma tumor, on December 31. For a full obituary and details of his January 17 memorial service in Lakeville, CT, go to his memorial website at www.forevermissed.com. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSMAN, JULIA ZLABOVSKY
Snippets: WEISSMAN--Julia Zlabovsky, 98, died on October 15, 2015 after a brief illness. Born in El Paso, Texas, she graduated from the College of Mines and Metallurgy of the University of Texas and later settled in New York City to pursue a career as a writer and editor. As author or co-author, she published books and articles in many areas of the arts and crafts, including folk art, needlework and cooking. She was predeceased by her sisters, Vera Zlabovsky and Esther Boxer and by her brothers Isador (Saul) Stuart and David Stuart. She is survived by her daughter Erica Weissman, brother Frank Stuart, nephew David Stuart, nieces Elizabeth Stuart and Rebecca Orlowski (Steven), and grandnephews Jesse, Derek, and Paul Orlowski. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLATT, HELEN

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROSS, ARTHUR
Snippets: BROSS--Arthur, of Poughkeepsie, NY, died Wednesday, December 30, 2015 due to complications from Alzheimer's disease. He was surrounded by his loving family, caregivers and grand dog. Art was born October 17, 1928 in Bronx, NY to the late Joseph and Bessie Bross and preceded in death by five siblings. He was 87 years young. Art served in the Army and Army Reserves, attaining the rank of 1st Lieutenant and he received a National Defense Service Medal. Never one to back down from a challenge, he worked full time while attending City College of New York for his B.S.M.E and M.S.M.E. degrees. Art was a Senior Engineer at IBM Microelectronics in Hopewell Junction, NY, author or editor of three books, and holder of 10 U.S. patents. He loved the country, gardening, birding, antiquing, and barbecuing, with a penchant for overcooked meats. Art was a beloved husband of the late Isabel Beth Bross for 47 years, a devoted father to his two daughters, Judy (Jeff) Bramson of Highland Park, IL and Jill Bross of Westhampton, NY. His two grandchildren, Alex and Nina Bramson were the loves of his life. Memorial donations can be made in Art's memory to the Alzheimer's Association. www.alz.org 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, HON
Snippets: KAYE--Hon. Judith S. The lawyers and staff of Proskauer mourn the loss of our friend the Hon. Judith S. Kaye, the former Chief Judge of the State of New York, and wife of our esteemed and beloved late colleague Stephen Rackow Kaye, who served as senior partner and former Chair of our Litigation and Dispute Resolution Department. Judith was one of the nation's most esteemed jurists and public servants of her time. She was a true role model and helped to pave the way for future generations of women to succeed in the law. Judith exemplified the fundamental values of the profession, and we were profoundly privileged to have had Judith as a friend for the last 50 years. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, JUDITH S

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKOWITZ, LEONARD
Snippets: BERKOWITZ--Leonard, 89, Professor Emeritus of Psychology and Vilas Research Professor at the University of Wisconsin, died on January 3, 2016 in Madison, WI. Dr. Berkowitz was born in New York City on August 11, 1926. He received his bachelor's degree from NYU and his Ph.D. from the University of Michigan. He served in the United States Army during WWII. Dr. Berkowitz was on the faculty of the University of Wisconsin at Madison from 1955 to 1989. He also held visiting appointments at Stanford, Oxford, Cambridge, and Cornell Universities. He was one of the pioneers in the experimental study of altruism but is, perhaps, best known for studying influences on aggressive behavior, including the effects of television and film violence. Dr. Berkowitz was the author of over 170 articles and books, and is one of the most frequently cited psychologists of the twentieth century. After his retirement, he continued to write in his field, submitting his last article for publication on November 1, 2015. He was an avid world traveler, collector of modern art, follower of world events and opera-goer. Dr. Berkowitz was predeceased by his first wife, Nettie, in 1975. He is survived by his wife of forty years, Norma, and two daughters, two stepsons, five grandchildren, two step-grandsons and a brother. A memorial fund has been established in his honor for the benefit of Psychology graduate students at the UW- Madison. Contributions to the Berkowitz Memorial Fund may be mailed to the University of Wisconsin Foundation, Attn: A. Kitslaar, 1848 University Ave, Madison, WI 53726. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELFINER, HENRY
Snippets: DELFINER--Henry, of Lexington, MA passed away January 3, 2016. Born in Vienna, Henry and his sister fled Austria on the day of the Anschluss, coming to the United States via Paris. He graduated from Amherst College in 1943, joined the Army, serving with the 88th Infantry Division in northern Italy. On May 2, 1945, acting as the translator for his commanding officer, Henry took the surrender of a whole German corps, including the First German Parachute Division. Decorated with the Bronze Star, he left the Army as a major. After the War, he was instrumental in reclaiming the family business from the Nazis, thereafter running the Herzmansky Department Store himself. He was also involved with the family business Greene Tweed of Kulpsville, PA through most of his adult life. He received a Ph.D. from the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy and taught at Tufts University as a professor of International Relations. His class on "Understanding International News," which he taught in the Experimental College at Tufts was very popular. After retiring from Tufts in 1987, he continued to write scholarly articles about the history of central Europe. In 1999, concerned with a lack of balance in political views in academia, he joined with Hadley Arkes, Edward N. Ney Professor in American Institutions at Amherst College in establishing the Colloquium on the American Founding, a twice-yearly weekend series of lectures and seminars where well-known national figures and influential conservative speakers were invited to present their views. He will be remembered for his kindness and his extraordinary generosity. Beloved husband of Barbara (Schudawa) Delfiner. Devoted father of Hannah Delfiner, Michael Delfiner and his wife Tracey, and Ruth Delfiner and her husband Paul Cooke. Loving brother of Charlotte Sperber. Cherished grandfather of Allon Bloch and his wife Annelise, Benjamin Delfiner, Rebecca Delfiner and her fiance Tom, and Emma Cooke. Proud great-grandfather of Alexander Bloch. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKEAND, CAROL EVAN

Dearest Carol... you are deeply missed by your husband Nigel, your daughter Sarah (a.k.a Bishi), your son-in-law Ryan, and your two amazing grandchildren, Olivia, 11 and Griffin, 8. You touched everyone who knew you. A memorial will be held for Carol on January 23rd, 2016 in Beverly Hills. For information, please email carolevan1930@gmail.com. We have loved you through every "Glad and Sorry Season". 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  SQUIRE, ANNETTE C
Snippets: SQUIRE--Annette C. of Boynton Beach, FL, devoted and beloved wife for almost 60 years of the (late) Albert Squire, daughter of the late Irving and Bella (nee Lehman) Cohen, sister of the late Molly Gershen, mother of Jeffrey and Judi Squire, loving grandmother of Evan and Emma Squire, and aunt to Robert and Joe Gershen, Susan Stoll, Susan Albright and Laura Stamm, passed away peacefully surrounded by family on December 8, 2015 at Delray Medical Center following a stroke on December 7. Annette, who turned 90 December 2, graduated with a B.S. from Columbia University School of Nursing and an M.S. from the University of Pennsylvania School of Nursing. Starting her career in New York City for the Visiting Nurse Service, Annette then spent many years in Pennsylvania as a school nurse for the Pennsbury School System. All who knew Annette recognized that she was a caring and skillful nurse and loving mother, aunt, grandmother, sister, daughter, niece, cousin and friend. Annette cared deeply for the people in her life and we all will miss her warm smile, concern, and love. Her family expresses their heartfelt appreciation to her skillful, kind, loving and warm caregivers, Kimberly Barrett and Jacques Clervil. A memorial service is being planned for early 2016. The family knows that Annette would appreciate contributions in her memory to the University of Pennsylvania School of Nursing 215-898-484 nursing.upenn.edu/friends giving, Columbia University School of Nursing, 866-GIFTSYS, or nursing.columbia.edu/giving, a charity benefiting Israel or any charity of your choice. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWEENEY, ANNE J
Snippets: SWEENEY--Anne J. 85, passed away in Los Angeles on Friday, December 11, 2015. She was preceded in death by her adoring husband, Donald E. Sweeney, Sr., and her brothers, James (in infancy), Thomas, James, William, and Edward, and her sisters Claire Rose Taber and Marie Becker. She was born on March 1, 1930, in Wilkes-Barre, PA to James J. and Marie O'Connell Tormay. She moved to Onondoga Hill in Syracuse, NY in 1939. She was a communicant of St. Michael's Church in Syracuse. She received her Bachelor of Science degree from the State University of New York Teacher's College at Oswego in 1951, where she was President of the Newman Club. Her great passion in life was teaching and her favorite people were children. She completed her student teaching in Baldwinsville, NY and began her formal career in Liverpool. She moved to the Hudson Valley in the mid fifties and taught in Hudson, NY, and later in the Kingston Consolidated School District for 18 years. She taught second grade at both the Elisha M. Brigham Elementary School and Chambers Elementary School. Her students will remember her ability to do all of the voices when reading "Charlotte's Web" aloud to the class, lessons in "SC" (self control) and her mantra, "Life is Choices." She also taught evening adult education with her husband at John F. Kennedy Elementary School and was CCD instructor at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Kingston, NY, where she also served as a Eucharistic Minister. She is survived by her three children, Anne M. Sweeney and her husband Philip H. Miller of Los Angeles, Donald E. Sweeney of Kingston, and Rosemary Sweeney Hanczor and her husband, Robert Hanczor of San Diego. She also leaves seven adoring grandchildren - Christopher and Rosemary Miller, Michaela and Shelagh Sweeney, and Catherine, Elizabeth and Brigid Hanczor, as well as a cousin, Rita Tormay of Yonkers, NY and many nieces and nephews. A Funeral Mass was held on December 16 at St. Monica's Catholic Church in Santa Monica, CA, followed by a burial service at Holy Cross Cemetery in Culver City, CA. Donations can be made to the Donald E. and Anne J. Sweeney Memorial Scholarship Fund, St Monica Catholic Schools, 1030 Lincoln Blvd., Santa Monica, CA 90043. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, DAVID FRANCIS
Snippets: RYAN--David Francis, beloved husband of Linda Thung-Ryan, died peacefully in his home, Croton on Hudson, NY on January 4th. He was 73. David was born in Yonkers, NY. He graduated from the College of the Holy Cross and the Columbia School of Law. For over 40 years, he practiced Antitrust and Intellectual Property Law, as a partner, at the renowned New York City firms: Kaye Scholar, Fierman, Hays & Handler and Fitzpatrick, Cella, Harper & Scinto. Throughout his life, David was a humanist with a love and encyclopedic knowledge of the arts. He was an avid sports enthusiast. David is survived by his wife Linda; his son David Ryan III (Mary Ryan) and his daughter Deirdre Ryan (Warren Costikyan); six grandchildren; and his siblings, Veronica Plavonich, Judith Ryan, Deborah Johnson, Paul Ryan, Mark Ryan, and Mary Ryan. Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULSER, FRIDOLIN
Snippets: SULSER--Fridolin, M.D. December 2, 1926 - January 3, 2016. Dr. Fridolin Sulser, who devoted his life to understanding the physiological basis of mental disorders and their treatment, died on January 3, 2016 at age 89, surrounded by loving family. He is survived by his brother, Emil Sulser of Maienfeld, Switzerland, wife, Johanna Mooser Sulser, and children Anna (Sulser) Newton, Adrian Sulser, Daniel Sulser, and Bettina (Sulser) Bryant, along with eight grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Dr. Sulser was born in Grabs, Switzerland and grew up in the town of Maienfeld, amidst his beloved Swiss Alps. He graduated from the Humanistische Gymnasium in Chur in 1947, attended Medical School at the University of Basel (pre-clinical) and the University of Zurich (clinical), graduating with an M.D. in 1955. He served as a medical officer in the Swiss Army, married the love of his life, Johanna, and moved with his wife and infant daughter to begin a position as assistant professor at the University of Bern. The family's great American adventure began in the fall of 1958 when Fridolin accepted a post-doctoral fellowship in Neuropsychopharmacology at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, M.D. Four years later, he went to Burroughs Wellcome Research Labs in New York as Head of Pharmacology. In 1965 he joined the Vanderbilt University Medical School Faculty as professor and Director of the Pharmacology Research Center, becoming a Professor Emeritus of the University in 2000. Dr. Sulser received many honors during his research career, including the prestigious Anna-Monika Prize, and was a Fellow and President of the American College of Neuropsychopharmacology as well as a Fellow of the Collegium International Neuro-Psychopharmacolo- gium. He was a very proud father and grandfather, who celebrated the childrens' successes as they pursued their chosen paths. He found inspiration in nature, literature, philosophy and the fine arts. Memorial Service: January 24 at 4pm at the Greater Nashville Unitarian Universalist Church, 374 Hicks Road, Nashville, TN 37221. In lieu of flowers, please consider donating to the scholarship fund at Vanderbilt School of Medicine "In Memory of Dr. Fridolin Sulser" (Vanderbilt Gift Processing, PMB 407727, 2301 Vanderbilt Place, Nashville, TN 37240-7727) or to the Friends of Radnor Lake "In Memory of Fridolin Sulser" (www.radnorlake.org). 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, JUDGE JUDITH S
Snippets: KAYE--Judge Judith S. With great sadness the Yeshiva University community mourns the loss of Judge Judith S. Kaye, who was granted an honorary degree from the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law in 1993. Judge Kaye was the first woman to become Chief Judge of New York, serving with great distinction for 16 years, longer than any other chief judge in the state's history. The daughter of Jewish immigrants from Poland, Judge Kaye's distinguished legacy demonstrates her belief in equality before the law, and her commitment to break down barriers in the legal field, and in society at large. Judge Kaye is remembered for the exceptional warmth and generosity she displayed to the Cardozo community, especially in her interactions with students. May her entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Richard M. Joel, President, Yeshiva University Melanie Leslie, Dean, Cardozo School of Law 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, IRVING
Snippets: ROSENBERG--Irving, of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Oceanside, NY died suddenly January 1, 2016. Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, MRS
Snippets: O'BRIEN--Mrs. Elva L. of Manhattan, NY died on January 7, 2016. She would have been 97 years of age in February. Mrs. O'Brien was born on February 13, 1919, in West Springfield, Massachusetts to Henry and Mary (Choquette) Brassard. On May 30, 1944, she married Lawrence F. O'Brien, Jr., at St. Joseph's Church in Springfield. Mr. O'Brien went on to twice serve as chairman of the Democratic National Committee, as a senior White House aide to Presidents John Kennedy and Lyndon Johnson, and as Commissioner of the National Basketball Association. They were married for 46 years before Mr. O'Brien passed away in New York City in September of 1990. Mrs. O'Brien resided in Washington, D.C., from 1961-1973, before moving to New York City in 1973 where she lived at 860 U.N. Plaza for more than 40 years. She spent summers at her home in the town of Cotuit on Cape Cod in Massachusetts. A thoughtful and generous philanthropist, Mrs. O'Brien was involved in the Archbishop's Christmas Appeal/Catholic Charities of New York and also supported the New York Public Library, the Cotuit Library Association in Barnstable on Cape Cod, Massachusetts, and the Environmental Film Festival in Washington, D.C. Mrs. O'Brien was instrumental in creating the "Lawrence F. O'Brien Gallery" exhibit space within the National Archives in Washington, D.C. She was fiercely loyal to her family and friends, possessed a keen sense of humor and was a person inclined to speak her mind. Her passion for books and for reading was legendary. Mrs. O'Brien is survived by her beloved son Lawrence F. O'Brien III, and his wife Helen (Powell) O'Brien of Washington, D.C., and her two cherished grandsons Luke O'Brien and Peter O'Brien both also of Washington, D.C. Funeral services will be private. A reception in fond remembrance will be scheduled at a future date. The family requests that any donations in memory of Mrs. O'Brien be made to the New York Public Library/Audio Books Division or Catholic Charities of New York. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERG, IVAR E
Snippets: BERG--Ivar E. (1929-2016), an Emeritus Professor of Sociology at the University of Pennsylvania, who made important contributions to the study of higher education, labor markets and industrial sociology, died on January 1, 2016. Dr. Berg's classic book, Education and Jobs: The Great Training Robbery (1970) cast doubt on economists' assertions that people with more education earn more because they are more skilled and productive; instead, employers frequently hire people to work in jobs that do not make use of their education. His book played a major role in a landmark civil rights decision by the U. S. Supreme Court, Griggs vs. Duke Power Company (1971) and was credited with providing the bases of the theory of market signaling, for which Akerlof, Spence, and Stiglitz shared the 2001 Nobel Prize in Economics. Among his many honors, he was elected a Fellow of the International Academy of Management, which cited him as "one of the seminal figures in the sociological study of labor markets and the founder of economic sociology." Born January 3, 1929 in Brooklyn, NY, he earned his AB at Colgate and his doctorate at Harvard. He served in the U.S. Marine Corps, retiring as a major, and on the faculties of Columbia and Vanderbilt, in addition to Penn. Dr. Berg, author of more than 70 articles and chapters and dozen books, leaves a wife, Sharon (Calli) Berg, a son and daughter-in-law, Geoffrey and Amy Berg, and stepsons Tim Smallwood (and his wife, Staci Smallwood) and Jim Smallwood (and his fiance, Catta Keith). 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWAT, ANNE H
Snippets: HOWAT--Anne H. EngenderHealth mourns the passing of our friend, colleague, and Board member, Ms. Anne H. Howat. A champion for women's reproductive rights and health, Anne had served on the Board of Directors in various capacities for more than 45 years. Anne will be remembered for her passion for promoting women's rights and informed choice and increasing access to reproductive health services globally. We extend heartfelt condolences to Anne's daughters, Laura and Karen, and the entire family. We are indebted to Anne for her invaluable counsel and guidance, which made EngenderHealth an even stronger and more effective organization. We will miss her dearly. Pamela W. Barnes, President Rob Petty, Chair, Board of Directors EngenderHealth 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, JUDITH S
Snippets: KAYE--Judith S. The Historical Society of the New York Courts mourns the loss of our founder and guiding spirit, Judith S. Kaye. We recognize and celebrate that no one has had a more profound, positive impact on our court system. She was New York's first female, and longest serving, Chief Judge, and used her matchless energy and wisdom, heart and soul, to reshape the courts to improve the lives of countless people. She pioneered court innovations based on the premise that the legal system exists to serve the people with fairness and sensitivity. For this she was beloved, nationally and internationally. She neither sought nor basked in the accolades, acknowledging them with a shy smile and a handwritten note combining modesty and gratitude. She could be hilariously funny, but never at anyone else's expense. It is fitting that her memorial service will be held at Lincoln Center as the arts were important in her life, and she could be heard singing in the courthouse corridors. Judith once said she has a 5 to 9 job, arriving at 5am (often with grandmother photos to exchange with maintenance staff) leaving at 9pm, and yet she was always able to be there, undistracted, for her family and friends. Though as a historical society we focus on figures from the past, we were so fortunate to have had one of the nations' leading lights in our midst. She battled her illness with courage and dignity. It seemed to us that the day of her passing would somehow never come. But she was, after all, human. The Historical Society of the New York Courts 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, JUDITH
Snippets: KAYE--Judith. The law clerks to Chief Judge Judith S. Kaye deeply mourn the loss of our beloved Chief. A brilliant jurist, scholar, writer, thinker, she served as mentor to us all, our teacher, confidante, cheerleader and friend. Her passion for justice, her commitment to equal rights, her insistence that everything could be made better, powered by boundless energy and a never-ending cascade of new ideas, will continue to inspire us always. Each of us is sustained by treasured memories of the times we spent together, by uproarious laughter born of her mischievous wit. We all feel so lucky to have worked with her, our lives are richer for having known her, and we will miss her terribly. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, JUDITH
Snippets: KAYE--Judith. January 7. The partners, attorneys and staff of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP mourn the passing of our colleague and friend Judith Kaye. Before joining our New York appellate litigation and arbitration practice in 2009, Judith spent 25 years on the bench of the New York Court of Appeals, including the last 15 as its Chief Judge. The first woman to serve on New York's highest court, Judith earned a national reputation for her pioneering opinions and court reforms. She wrote seminal opinions on such issues as the death penalty, same-sex marriage, education and state constitutional rights while leading innovative changes to the New York court system, including the establishment of specialized courts to focus on issues of drug addiction, domestic violence and mental health. As Chief Judge, Judith created the Adoption Now program, helped establish the Center for Court Innovation and co-chaired the ABA Commission on the American Jury. She retired from the bench in 2008, having served longer than any Chief Judge in state history. At Skadden, Judith helped numerous clients navigate complex issues of New York law. She also served as a trustee of the Skadden Fellowship Foundation and continued her advocacy for families and children, including through her service as the chairwoman of the Permanent Judicial Commission on Justice for Children. Judith graduated from Barnard College ('58) and NYU School of Law ('62), where she was one of 10 women in a class of nearly 300. Judith is survived by her children, Luisa, Jonathan and Gordon, and seven grandchildren. She will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be held at 10:00am (doors open at 9:15), Monday, January 11, at the David H. Koch Theater, Lincoln Center. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAHLAVI, HER IMPERIAL HIGHNESS PRINCESS ASHRAF
Snippets: PAHLAVI--Her Imperial Highness Princess Ashraf, twin sister of His Late Imperial Majesty, Shah of Iran, died peacefully in her home in Europe January 7 at age 96. Survived by her son Prince Chahram Pahlavi, five grandsons and great-grandchildren. Her Imperial Highness was President of the Women's Organization of Iran, Honorary Vice Chair of Iran's National Committee for World Literacy Program, Vice President of the Imperial Organization for Social Welfare, Head of the Iranian Delegation to the United Nations, Chair of the First United Nations Conference on Human Rights in Tehran in 1968, Chair of the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women, Honorary President of the Foundation for Iranian Studies, Pioneer in women's rights and was the first woman to appear unveiled in public. As emissary for her brother, she developed tied to many nations of interest to Iran. A skilled diplomat who successfully established full diplomatic relations between Iran and the Peoples Republic of China. In exile she remained active supporting initiatives related to reviving Iran's cultural, literary and artistic heritage. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARPENTER, DAVID CHANDLER
Snippets: CARPENTER--David Chandler, 74, died January 9, 2016 surrounded by his loving family. He leaves his wife of 24 years, Elizabeth, son Stefan, daughter Leslie Kolczak (Franck), stepson Adam Gould (Natalie), and adored grandchildren, Luc and Sasha. David graduated from Middlebury College and Rutgers University, and was very happily retired after a successful career in international and private banking. Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, LORRAINE
Snippets: SHAPIRO--Lorraine. 1927-2016. A master teacher who inspired generations of children to live their dreams. Beloved wife of 65 years to Herb in a marriage for the ages. Adored mother of Michael, James, and Jill. Cherished grandmother of Eliza, Jay and Luke. Loving mother-in-law to Susan and Mary. She taught first grade until she was 78 and continued to volunteer in retirement, teaching children in oncology wards. An artist of quiltmaking and baking. Her imprint is indelible, a tribute to optimism, irrepressibility and zest. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAHLAVI, HER IMPERIAL HIGHNESS PRINCESS ASHRAF
Snippets: PAHLAVI--Her Imperial Highness Princess Ashraf, twin sister of His Late Imperial Majesty, Shah of Iran, died peacefully in her home in Europe January 7 at age 96. Survived by her son Prince Chahram Pahlavi, five grandsons and great-grandchildren. Her Imperial Highness was President of the Women's Organization of Iran, Honorary Vice Chair of Iran's National Committee for World Literacy Program, Vice President of the Imperial Organization for Social Welfare, Head of the Iranian Delegation to the United Nations, Chair of the First United Nations Conference on Human Rights in Tehran in 1968, Chair of the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women, Honorary President of the Foundation for Iranian Studies, Pioneer in women's rights and was the first woman to appear unveiled in public. As emissary for her brother, she developed tied to many nations of interest to Iran. A skilled diplomat who successfully established full diplomatic relations between Iran and the Peoples Republic of China. In exile she remained active supporting initiatives related to reviving Iran's cultural, literary and artistic heritage. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOPPELT, ELEANOR

Devoted grandmother of Brad, Kyle and Meredith Doppelt, Brian and Stephanie Doppelt, Jason, David and Jennifer Doppelt and Adam, Daniel and Brooke Kozek. Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARON, ANNE T.
Snippets: CARON--Anne T.,(Flanagan), 84, died at the Orchard Cove Retirement Community in Canton, MA on Saturday, January 9, 2016. She was the wife of the late Wilfred R. Caron. Born and raised in New York City, she was a graduate of Villa Maria Academy and St. John's University. Anne was a resident of Canton for four years after living in Little Compton, RI for 16 years. Prior to that, she resided in Scarborough, NY and Washington, DC. Mrs. Caron worked for IBM in New York, New Jersey and Washington, DC for 35 years, retiring as a manager in 1991. She enjoyed reading and was very active at Orchard Cove. Mrs. Caron was the sister of Catherine A. Sheehan of Brentwood, NY and the late John J. Flanagan. She is also survived by several nieces and nephews. Visitation will be held from the Farley Funeral Home, 358 Park St. (Rt.27), Stoughton, MA on Friday from 9-10am followed by a Funeral Mass at St. James Church, Stoughton at 10:30am. Interment will take place at the Massachusetts National Cemetery, Bourne. In lieu of flowers, donations in Anne's memory may be made to Massachusetts General Hospital Cancer Research, Development Office, 125 Nashua St., Suite 540, Boston, MA 02114. Directions and obituary at www.farley fh.com. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  VON ZUBEN, FREDERICK G.
Snippets: von ZUBEN--Frederick G.,died peacefully on January 7, 2016 at 77 years old with his devoted wife of 47 years, their two loving sons and his sister by his side. He is survived by his wife Antonia, his sons Christian and Max, his daughters-in-law Erin and Heather, his five grandchildren Michael, Aidan, Lucy, Phoebe and Grace, and his sister Jane Thompson. Fred was born in Hamilton, Ontario, Canada. He cherished his family and was a friend to many. He was an avid sportsman and was a Hall of Honor hockey player at Colgate University. Fred and Toni raised their sons in New Vernon, NJ and loved to spend time with family in Southold, NY and at Point Clark on Lake Huron in Ontario. The family will receive friends at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street in New York City on Monday, January 11 from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, January 12 at 11am at St. Mary's Abbey at Delbarton School, 230 Mendham Road, Morristown, NJ. Memorial donations may be made to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation at: www.pdf.org. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOPPELT, ELEANOR

Contact family for address. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUTTON, PAULINE BARBARA
Snippets: DUTTON--Pauline Barbara, of Kinderhook, NY and Canaan, CT passed away on January 10 at the age of 90. Born in New York City, she was the adored wife of the late Ben Joseph Dutton, an inspirational and devoted mother to Deborah Dutton Minton and Pamela Barbara Dutton and grandmother of Sebastian Frugone and Alexandra Frugone. She was imbued with great dignity and genuine goodness. Her enthusiasm for life, love of family, spiritedness and spontaneity touched us all. Her spirit will remain with us forever. A Mass of Christian burial will be held on Thursday, January 14 at 10:00am at St. Joseph's Church, 4 Main Street, Canaan, CT. Interment will take place on Thursday, January 14 at 2:00pm St. Michael's Cemetery, 7202 Astoria Boulevard, East Elmhurst, NY. Calling hours will take place at Finnerty & Stevens Funeral Home in Great Barrington, MA on Wednesday, January 13 from 11am to 1pm and 2pm to 6pm. Memorial contributions may be sent to the Kosciuszko Foundation Art Restoration Fund, 15 East 65th St., New York, NY 10065. 1/3

Snippets: GREASON--Mary Twomey. The entire Marymount Manhattan College community mourns the loss of Mary Twomey Greason. Mary Twomey Greason graduated magna cum laude from Marymount Manhattan College in 1986 with a Bachelor of Arts in art history and went on to a life of service for the College. Mary encouraged alumni to become involved and give back to the college, and demonstrated tremendous generosity and leadership in her work on the Board of Trustees from 1995 to 2004 and again from 2005 to 2014. She lit up every room she entered and was a friend to all. Mary's commitment to Marymount Manhattan and her dedication to the college's students, faculty, and staff will always be remembered. Services: visitation at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave., New York, NY, Tuesday, January 12th from 3:00-5:00pm and 7:00-9:00pm. Funeral Mass at 11:00am on Wednesday, January 13th, at Our Lady of Peace Church, East 62nd St. between Second and Third Avenues. In lieu of flowers, the family has suggested contributions to the Mary Twomey Greason Endowed Scholarship at Marymount Manhattan College. Kerry Walk, Ph.D., President, Marymount Manhattan College Hope Knight, Chairperson of the Board of Trustees, Marymount Manhattan College 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRESENT, DR
Snippets: PRESENT-- Dr. Daniel H. A brilliant, creative, and abundantly loved giant has left us. Dr. Daniel H. Present, born April 3, 1934, passed away on January 12th from complication of Parkinson's Disease. He was 81 years old. His passing will be deeply mourned by Jane Werner Present, his wife, partner, lover and best friend of more than 59 years, his three children, their spouses, and four grandchildren, Tracy Present, Stephanie, Michael, Billy and Katherine Podalak, Douglas, Susan, Adam and Margot Present, and his sister Judy Present Liss; his friends, associates and the thousands of lives he touched during his 50 years of practice. Dan graduated from Syracuse University Magna Cum Laude, Phi Beta Kappa in 1955 and State University of New York Downstate College of Medicine, Magna Cum Laude, in 1959. He completed an internship, medical residency, Gastroenterology residency and GI Fellowship at Mt. Sinai Hospital, and entered private practice in 1964, where he quickly began to focus his attention on the management of Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. He was the recipient of the first research award given by the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America. Dan brought clinical trials into clinical practice. His first paper was accepted for publication in 1966. He subsequently published 329 papers. At the time of his retirement, his publications had been cited more than 15,000 times. During his 54 years at Mt. Sinai, he served as President of both the Association of the Attending Staff and the Alumni Association for which he received the coveted Jacobi Medallion for Conspicuous Service to the Alumni. Dan received every award in his field including the Samuel Bronfman Department of Medicine Distinguished Service Award, The American Gastroenterology Association Distinguished Clinician Award, Master of the American College of Gastroenterology, The WiIIiam Dock, M.D. Master Teacher Award in Medicine State University of New York, the Janssen Award for Outstanding Achievement Award in Clinical Gastroenterology, the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America Lifetime Achievement Award and the George Arents Award for Excellence in Medicine, the highest achievement awarded by Syracuse University. He is generally recognized as having pioneered the way Crohn's disease is treated. More than any recognition, Dan loved taking care of his patients. He loved them and they returned that love many times over. His joy came from sparing his patients the pain, discomfort, and humiliation of inflammatory bowel disease by finding the right combination of medications and thoughtful creativity. He fought against surgery if there was a possible medical solution. He talked with his patients for many more hours than any HMO wouId have allowed. He sat at their bedside and visited them late at night, he celebrated when they felt better. Nothing made him happier than a college student being able to return to school, or a young adult feeling well enough to plan a wedding or bear a child. He loved teaching young Gastroenterologists and, along with a grateful patient, created the Present-Levison fourth year fellowship in Clinical GI, which allowed the brightest young men and women to spend a post-graduate year learning clinical GI at Mt. Sinai. These fellows now care for IBD patients all over the world. Funeral services will be held on Thursday at 12pm at "The Riverside," 180 West 76th St., New York. Contributions in Dan's memory may be made to the Present-Levison Fellowship at Mt. Sinai, and sent to the Division of Gastroenterology, Mt. Sinai Hospital, Box 1069, New York, New York 10029. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASLOW, MARILYN MOORE
Snippets: MASLOW--Marilyn Moore, 83, of Naples, FL died Saturday January 9, 2016. While living in Scarsdale, NY and completing a course of professional study at Tobe Coburn School of Fashion Design, Marilyn embarked on a successful career as a children's fashion editor for Harper's Bazaar. Survivors include her husband Richard; six children, Jennifer Holtzman Maslow of Ashland, OR, Hilary Maslow of Charlotte, VT, Melanie Maslow-Kern of Dallas, Douglas Maslow of Dallas, Allison Maslow of Shavertown and Leslie Maslow of New York. She is survived by eight grandchildren: Percy, Temple and Rivers Holtzman; Eric Naud; and Olivia, Louise, Malcolm and Duncan Lumia. Also surviving are her beloved sisters-in-law, Louise Moore and Gyana Pendleton, and nine nieces and nephews. Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAGOPIAN, LOUIS THOMAS
Snippets: HAGOPIAN--Louis Thomas. Of Vero Beach, FL and Darien, CT, died after a short illness in his Florida home on January 9, 2016 at age 90. He is survived by his wife of 60 years, Joanne Kelly Hagopian; his daughter Susan Goddard and sons Thomas and Matthew; nine grandchildren; his sister Helen Geovjian; and more than 40 members of his extended family. Lou thought himself to be one of the luckiest men in the world, with a wife and family who loved him and whom he loved dearly, parents he respected and adored and a career he both enjoyed and succeeded in beyond his wildest hopes. As the son of parents who fled to the United States after their families were killed in the Armenian Genocide, he felt that he truly lived the American Dream and loved this country for it. Lou served in the US Navy during World War II and graduated from Michigan State University after the War. His career started in the auto business, but his skills in marketing and communications soon led him to a successful career in advertising with the oldest agency in the US, NW Ayer. He led NW Ayer for over 25 years, including the last ten as Chairman and CEO. During his tenure, Ayer was selected Agency of the Year and developed numerous iconic advertising campaigns with taglines such as "A Diamond is Forever" and "Be All That You Can Be." He also was Chairman of the Advertising Association of America and a founding member of the innovative Partnership for Drug-Free America. Lou was a man of style with an enormous heart, tremendous charm and a wicked wit. He loved to serenade his wife, Joanne, with "Misty" or "My Funny Valentine" whenever given the slightest excuse (and often without). An avid and excellent golfer for over 70 years, he started as a caddy at the Pine Lake Country Club outside of Detroit and ended as a member of the Royal & Ancient Golf Club in St. Andrews (where he won the Seniors Tournament at the age of 86). Services will be held at St. Thomas More Catholic Church in Darien, CT at 10:30am on Saturday, January 16. A memorial service will also be scheduled for friends and relatives in Vero Beach in the next several weeks. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that a memorial donation be made to Indian River Habitat for Humanity, www.irchabitat.org. Services are under the direction of Strunk Funeral Home and Crematory, Vero Beach. An online guest book is available at www. strunkfuneralhome.com. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITTELL, ROSALIND "RONNIE." THE FAMILY OF RONNIE LITTELL DEEPLY MOURN HER DEATH ON JANUARY 10

Beloved wife of David; mother of Bruce (and Heather) and Scott (and Sherri); grandmother of Nicole (and Tom), Danielle, Brent, Griffin, Marissa and Erika; great-grand- mother to Emma and Jack. The Ronnie Littell Special, a tribute to her father, is believed to be the longest running program on public television. Her memory will be a blessing for all she loved and all who loved her. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRESENT, DANIEL H.
Snippets: PRESENT--Daniel H.,M.D. The faculty and staff of the Dr. Henry D. Janowitz Division of Gastroenterology and the Department of Medicine at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai mourn the passing of Daniel Present, M.D. Beloved by his patients and revered by his trainees and colleagues, Dr. Present leaves behind a fifty-year legacy of research and treatment of inflammatory bowel disease. His innovations in the care of Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis immeasurably improved the lives of thousands of patients. Our deepest condolences go to his family: wife Jane, children Douglas, Stephanie and Tracy, and his grandchildren. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMOND, MICHAEL H
Snippets: DIAMOND--Michael H. The partners of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy LLP mourn the passing of dear friend and former partner, Michael H. Diamond. A highly regarded lawyer who made a tremendous impact on the litigation field in Los Angeles and beyond, Mike joined Milbank in 2000 as partner and head of the Litigation Group in the Firm's Los Angeles office. Prior to joining Milbank, he spent 23 years at Skadden, Arps, where he opened and expanded the firm's Los Angeles office. After retiring from Milbank in 2007, Mike founded a successful consulting and expert witness firm, MHD Group. During his career, he advised numerous corporations and their officers, directors and shareholders, on complex and high-profile disputes. Mike was also dedicated to pro bono work, applying his legal skills to a wide range of matters. These included the merger of Brandeis-Bardin Institute with the University of Judaism, which formed the American Jewish University, and his successful defense of journalists in a case related to the 2000 Democratic National Convention, which earned him recognition from the ACLU Foundation of Southern California. He held degrees from Brown University and Columbia University Law School. We extend our deepest sympathies to Mike's wife, Marilyn, his four children Seth, Cory, Beth and Debra and ten grandchildren, and to his entire family. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMYLIE, THE REVEREND ROBERT F.
Snippets: SMYLIE--The Reverend Robert F.,87 and a resident of Seabrook Village in Tinton Falls, NJ, passed away on Saturday, December 19, 2015. He was born in Memphis, Tennessee; grew up in St. Louis, Missouri; and spent most of his adult life living in Englewood, NJ and working in New York City. A graduate of Washington University, Robert was an ordained Presbyterian minister with a Masters in Divinity and Theology from Princeton Theological Seminary and a Masters in Philosophy from Columbia. A lifelong student of international affairs, world traveler, and advocate for peace and human rights, he had spent 27 years with the Presbyterian Church USA's Peacemaking Program in several capacities before retiring as the Director of its United Nations Office in 2002. He had also served as a US Navy chaplain, taught at the University of Florida as an Assistant Professor in Social Sciences, and had been a Visiting Fellow at New College, University of Edinburgh in Scotland. Robert was a widower; his wife, Yuri Yamamoto, was a concert pianist and teacher. He is survived by his sons, Mark and John. A memorial service is scheduled for 11am, Saturday, January 16, at First Presbyterian Church in Englewood, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Memorial Scholarship established by the family of his grandniece, Rachel G. Smylie, at the charity Geography of Hope. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNET, SYLVAN
Snippets: BARNET--Sylvan, born in Brooklyn, New York, on December 11, 1926, died at home in Cambridge, Massachusetts, on January 9, 2016. He served in the U.S. Army during World War II, then graduated from New York University (1948), Phi Beta Kappa, and entered the graduate program at Harvard (Ph.D. in English Language and Literature, 1954), where he wrote a prize-winning essay on Shakespeare. He spent his entire teaching career at Tufts University (1954-84), serving twice as chair of the Department of English. He published a number of essays in scholarly journals, a popular introduction to Shakespeare, and he served as General Editor of The Signet Classic Shakespeare, a paperback series (one play per volume) that is widely used in colleges and universities. He was also the author or co-author of several widely used textbooks-on argument (with Hugo Bedau, late of the Tufts Department of Philosophy), art, composition, drama, and literature, including "A Short Guide to Writing about Art" (now in its 11th edition), and "Introduction to Literature" (16th edition). In 1963, he and William Burto (his partner since 1952, deceased 2013) developed an interest in Japanese art, especially calligraphy, and they went on to build a collection that was exhibited in the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Freer Gallery, the Harvard Art Museum, and the Museum of Fine Art, Houston. The Metropolitan exhibition was accompanied by a catalog by Miyeko Murase, "The Written Image" (2002), to which Barnet and Burto contributed two essays, one on collecting, the other on looking at calligraphy from a Western point of view. (After Burto's death their collection was divided among the first four of these museums.) He and Burto also wrote "Zen Ink Paintings" (1982) as well as several essays on Japanese art. As a teacher of English literature, he was familiar with a good deal of writing about death. Among the favorite passages he carried in his head-he could not understand why some educators disparage "rote memory"-were Shakespeare's "Golden lads and girls all must/As chimney sweepers come to dust." and this epitaph by Sir Henry Wotton (1568-1639), "Upon the Death of Sir Albert Morton's Wife": "He first deceased; she for a little tried/To live without him, liked it not, and died." (Barnet said, shortly after the death of his partner, that Wotton's lines came to his mind every day, and that he regretted, every day, his inability to re-enact them.) He leaves his sister-in-law Saretta Barnet, a niece and three nephews and their spouses, nine grandnephews and nieces, a great-grandnephew and niece, and his longtime friend, Morton Berman. Most of his estate was bequeathed to a scholarship fund at Tufts, in honor of his parents, Philip and Esther Barnet. By his wish there will be no services. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOPPELT, ELLIE
Snippets: DOPPELT--Ellie. The members of Brae Burn Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed member Ellie Doppelt. Our sympathy is extended to her entire family. Paul Friedman, President Douglas Simon, Secretary 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCAGLIONE, CAROLYN, M.D.
Snippets: SCAGLIONE--Carolyn, M.D.,of Englewood, NJ died on January 10, 2016, age 88. Known professionally as Carolyn R. Denning, M.D., she was an internationally recognized pediatrician and one of the leading experts in the field of Cystic Fibrosis research and care. Carolyn Rebecca Denning was born on May 30, 1927 in Detroit, MI. She was raised in Franklin, KY and graduated from University of Kentucky in 1947. She graduated from Tulane University School of Medicine with an M.D. degree in 1952. After her internship and residency, she completed a pulmonary fellowship in 1957 at Babies Hospital, at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center where she worked with Dr. Dorothy Andersen and the group that originally described CF. She spent the remainder of her career in the Metropolitan New York City area. From 1963-1977, she served as Director of Cystic Fibrosis and Pediatric Pulmonary Disease Centers of Babies Hospital, at Columbia Presbyterian. In 1977, she founded the Cystic Fibrosis, Pediatric Pulmonary and GI Center at St. Vincent's Hospital, and served as its Director until retiring in 1995. For over 40 years she cared for hundreds of patients with CF and formed lasting bonds with their families. She trained many of the CF caregivers who are practicing throughout the world today, upholding her standards of care and compassion. She is survived by her husband of 59 years, Peter R. Scaglione, M.D., four sons and seven grandchildren. The family will receive friends at Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, NJ, on Friday, January 15 from 6-9pm and Saturday, January 16 from 12-4pm (3pm Remembrance). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Research Fund for Cystic Fibrosis, 455 Oradell Ave., Oradell, NJ 07649. A memorial service will be held at later date. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREASON, MARY TWOMEY
Snippets: GREASON--Mary Twomey, of Manhattan and Quogue, NY passed away peacefully on January 9th, surrounded by her loving family, after a brief and sudden illness. Mary was born January 15, 1932 in the Bronx to Timothy and Anna (nee King) Twomey. Mary was a wonderful and loving wife, mother, grandmother, and friend to all who met her. She is survived by Edward W. Greason, her husband of nearly 61 years, her sons Edward and his wife Marisa, William and his wife Margaret, and Michael, her granddaughter Elizabeth, and brother-in-law Robert, as well as many nieces, nephews and cousins. Among her many accomplishments, she was most proud of graduating from Marymount Manhattan College, where she later served as a Trustee for 19 years and received the College's President's Medal of Honor. Visiting at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel" Madison Ave and 81st Street, on Tuesday, January 12, from 3-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral mass will be held at 11am on January 13 at Our Lady of Peace Church, 237 East 62nd Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Mary T. Greason Scholarship Fund at Marymount Manhattan College or to Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRESENT, DANIEL H.
Snippets: PRESENT--Daniel H.,M.D. We at the Mount Sinai Health System are saddened by the passing of Daniel H. Present, M.D., a beloved physician who, in a five-decade career at Mount Sinai, was at the forefront of research into the diagnosis and treatment of inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD). Dr. Present was the first researcher to show the effectiveness of an immunosuppressant, 6-mercaptopurine (6-MP), in fighting Crohn's disease. When Dr. Present published his results in The New England Journal of Medicine (NEJM) in 1980, it changed the lives of thousands of Crohn's patients. Later, he studied the use of cyclosporine for severe steroid- refractory ulcerative colitis, and demonstrated that it could help avoid or delay colectomies in many of these seriously ill patients. In a third breakthrough in the late 1990s, Dr. Present studied cA2, also known as infliximab, an anti-tumor necrosis factor antibody, and showed, in another seminal paper in the NEJM, that it could help close fistulas in Crohn's patients. Early in his career at Mount Sinai, he was mentored by Henry D. Janowitz, M.D., for whom the Division of Gastroenterology is named. Dr. Present was also a talented clinician who cared for thousands of patients over his career. Over a decade ago, he and his wife, Jane, established an endowed fellowship at Mount Sinai to train graduates from outside institutions to become experts in the care of patients with Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. Dr. and Mrs. Present also maintained a foundation for clinical research of IBD. Upon his retirement from Mount Sinai in 2014, the foundation donated its principal in support of The Susan and Leonard Feinstein Inflammatory Bowel Disease Clinical Center at Mount Sinai. We extend our deepest sympathies to Jane and their children, Douglas, Stephanie, and Tracy, at this difficult time. Peter W. May, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, Mount Sinai Health System Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President and Chief Executive Officer, Mount Sinai Health System Dennis S. Charney, M.D. Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, President for Academic Affairs, Mount Sinai Health System 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRESENT, DANIEL H.
Snippets: PRESENT--Daniel H.,M.D. The Association of the Attending Staff of the Mount Sinai Hospital mourns the passing of a beloved colleague, mentor, and friend. Clinical Professor of Medicine, Dr. Present combined an active clinical practice with prolific ground-breaking research in Gastroenterology. In the tradition of Drs. Crohn, Ginsberg, and Oppenheimer, he continued Mount Sinai's pioneering work in the study of inflammatory bowel diseases. Through his investigations, an important class of medications was added in treating Colitis and Crohn's Disease. He was awarded the prestigious Jacobi Medallion in 1991 and was a great supporter of the institution. A long term AAS board member, he served as President of the physicians' organization from 1979-1980. Dr. Present will be remembered for his outstanding contributions to the School and Hospital, and his commitment to excellence. His legacy will continue in the generations of students he taught and the many lives he touched. We extend condolences to his wife Jane and his entire family. Eric Neibart, M.D., President Mark Reiner, M.D., Vice President Amy Weinstein, Administrator 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNET, SYLVAN
Snippets: BARNET--Sylvan, born in Brooklyn, New York, on December 11, 1926, died at home in Cambridge, Massachusetts, on January 9, 2016. He served in the U.S. Army during World War II, then graduated from New York University (1948), Phi Beta Kappa, and entered the graduate program at Harvard (Ph.D. in English Language and Literature, 1954), where he wrote a prize-winning essay on Shakespeare. He spent his entire teaching career at Tufts University (1954-84), serving twice as chair of the Department of English. He published a number of essays in scholarly journals, a popular introduction to Shakespeare, and he served as General Editor of The Signet Classic Shakespeare, a paperback series (one play per volume) that is widely used in colleges and universities. He was also the author or co-author of several widely used textbooks-on argument (with Hugo Bedau, late of the Tufts Department of Philosophy), art, composition, drama, and literature, including "A Short Guide to Writing about Art" (now in its 11th edition), and "Introduction to Literature" (16th edition). In 1963, he and William Burto (his partner since 1952, deceased 2013) developed an interest in Japanese art, especially calligraphy, and they went on to build a collection that was exhibited in the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Freer Gallery, the Harvard Art Museum, and the Museum of Fine Art, Houston. The Metropolitan exhibition was accompanied by a catalog by Miyeko Murase, "The Written Image" (2002), to which Barnet and Burto contributed two essays, one on collecting, the other on looking at calligraphy from a Western point of view. (After Burto's death their collection was divided among the first four of these museums.) He and Burto also wrote "Zen Ink Paintings" (1982) as well as several essays on Japanese art. As a teacher of English literature, he was familiar with a good deal of writing about death. Among the favorite passages he carried in his head-he could not understand why some educators disparage "rote memory"-were Shakespeare's "Golden lads and girls all must/As chimney sweepers come to dust." and this epitaph by Sir Henry Wotton (1568-1639), "Upon the Death of Sir Albert Morton's Wife": "He first deceased; she for a little tried/To live without him, liked it not, and died." (Barnet said, shortly after the death of his partner, that Wotton's lines came to his mind every day, and that he regretted, every day, his inability to re-enact them.) He leaves his sister-in-law Saretta Barnet, a niece and three nephews and their spouses, nine grandnephews and nieces, a great-grandnephew and niece, and his longtime friend, Morton Berman. Most of his estate was bequeathed to a scholarship fund at Tufts, in honor of his parents, Philip and Esther Barnet. By his wish there will be no services. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPERSMITH, JACK
Snippets: COOPERSMITH--Jack, of Boca Raton, died on January 10, 2016, at the age of 94. He is survived by his wife of 71 years, Anita Selikoff Coopersmith, his son Jeffrey (Marjie), daughters Leslie (Michael) Greenberg, Amy (Stan) Baratz, grandchildren, Lorie (John) FitzGibbon, Julie Myers, Jarred (Bernadine) Coopersmith, Aubrey (David) Lipscomb, Blake (Sara) Baratz, Justin (Rachel) Baratz, Courtney Baratz (fiancee Ryan Rosoff), great-grandchildren Bexley Baratz, Harlow Baratz, Hannah Lipscomb, Sophie Lipscomb, Lily FitzGibbon and Jane FitzGibbon. Jack thought of himself as one of the luckiest men in the world, with an adoring wife and family who loved him and whom he loved dearly; parents and in-laws who he respected and loved, and a career he enjoyed. He lived the American dream. Jack served in the US Army during World War II, landing in Normandy on D+3. After the war he was a founding partner of Tricap Realty, ultimately joining Leonard Litwin at Glenwood Management. He retired in 1992 as Senior Vice President responsible for all leasing operations. He was a founding member of Temple Avodah, Oceanside, NY. Jack was a man with style, a big heart, engaging charm and a wicked wit. He loved to dance with his wife to Frank Sinatra and big band tunes. He loved playing golf with his many friends at the Boca Woods Country Club. The family requests that memorial donations be made to the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation at: JDRF, 3001 Metro Drive Suite 100, Bloomington, MN 55425, 952-851-0770. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCAGLIONE, CAROLYN, M.D.
Snippets: SCAGLIONE--Carolyn, M.D.,of Englewood, NJ died on January 10, 2016, age 88. Known professionally as Carolyn R. Denning, M.D., she was an internationally recognized pediatrician and one of the leading experts in the field of Cystic Fibrosis research and care. Carolyn Rebecca Denning was born on May 30, 1927 in Detroit, MI. She was raised in Franklin, KY and graduated from University of Kentucky in 1947. She graduated from Tulane University School of Medicine with an M.D. degree in 1952. After her internship and residency, she completed a pulmonary fellowship in 1957 at Babies Hospital, at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center where she worked with Dr. Dorothy Andersen and the group that originally described CF. She spent the remainder of her career in the Metropolitan New York City area. From 1963-1977, she served as Director of Cystic Fibrosis and Pediatric Pulmonary Disease Centers of Babies Hospital, at Columbia Presbyterian. In 1977, she founded the Cystic Fibrosis, Pediatric Pulmonary and GI Center at St. Vincent's Hospital, and served as its Director until retiring in 1995. For over 40 years she cared for hundreds of patients with CF and formed lasting bonds with their families. She trained many of the CF caregivers who are practicing throughout the world today, upholding her standards of care and compassion. She is survived by her husband of 59 years, Peter R. Scaglione, M.D., four sons and seven grandchildren. The family will receive friends at Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, NJ, on Friday, January 15 from 6-9pm and Saturday, January 16 from 12-4pm (3pm Remembrance). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Research Fund for Cystic Fibrosis, 455 Oradell Ave., Oradell, NJ 07649. A memorial service will be held at later date. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRESENT, DR
Snippets: PRESENT-- Dr. Daniel H. A brilliant, creative, and abundantly loved giant has left us. Dr. Daniel H. Present, born April 3, 1934, passed away on January 12th from complication of Parkinson's Disease. He was 81 years old. His passing will be deeply mourned by Jane Werner Present, his wife, partner, lover and best friend of more than 59 years, his three children, their spouses, and four grandchildren, Tracy Present, Stephanie, Michael, Billy and Katherine Podalak, Douglas, Susan, Adam and Margot Present, and his sister Judy Present Liss; his friends, associates and the thousands of lives he touched during his 50 years of practice. Dan graduated from Syracuse University Magna Cum Laude, Phi Beta Kappa in 1955 and State University of New York Downstate College of Medicine, Magna Cum Laude, in 1959. He completed an internship, medical residency, Gastroenterology residency and GI Fellowship at Mt. Sinai Hospital, and entered private practice in 1964, where he quickly began to focus his attention on the management of Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. He was the recipient of the first research award given by the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America. Dan brought clinical trials into clinical practice. His first paper was accepted for publication in 1966. He subsequently published 329 papers. At the time of his retirement, his publications had been cited more than 15,000 times. During his 54 years at Mt. Sinai, he served as President of both the Association of the Attending Staff and the Alumni Association for which he received the coveted Jacobi Medallion for Conspicuous Service to the Alumni. Dan received every award in his field including the Samuel Bronfman Department of Medicine Distinguished Service Award, The American Gastroenterology Association Distinguished Clinician Award, Master of the American College of Gastroenterology, The WiIIiam Dock, M.D. Master Teacher Award in Medicine State University of New York, the Janssen Award for Outstanding Achievement Award in Clinical Gastroenterology, the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America Lifetime Achievement Award and the George Arents Award for Excellence in Medicine, the highest achievement awarded by Syracuse University. He is generally recognized as having pioneered the way Crohn's disease is treated. More than any recognition, Dan loved taking care of his patients. He loved them and they returned that love many times over. His joy came from sparing his patients the pain, discomfort, and humiliation of inflammatory bowel disease by finding the right combination of medications and thoughtful creativity. He fought against surgery if there was a possible medical solution. He talked with his patients for many more hours than any HMO wouId have allowed. He sat at their bedside and visited them late at night, he celebrated when they felt better. Nothing made him happier than a college student being able to return to school, or a young adult feeling well enough to plan a wedding or bear a child. He loved teaching young Gastroenterologists and, along with a grateful patient, created the Present-Levison fourth year fellowship in Clinical GI, which allowed the brightest young men and women to spend a post-graduate year learning clinical GI at Mt. Sinai. These fellows now care for IBD patients all over the world. Funeral services will be held on Thursday at 12pm at "The Riverside," 180 West 76th St., New York. Contributions in Dan's memory may be made to the Present-Levison Fellowship at Mt. Sinai, and sent to the Division of Gastroenterology, Mt. Sinai Hospital, Box 1069, New York, New York 10029. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESSMORE, MARY ANNE
Snippets: MESSMORE--Mary Anne, of Baltimore, Maryland, died peacefully with her family by her side on January 11, 2016. Mary's life was most remarkable for the effect she had on the people around her. She brought light and laughter to every room she entered. A rock of comfort and support for anyone grieving or feeling lonely, Mary loved to laugh and make others laugh, play games, cook, and spend time with friends. She loved her dogs, the mountains, music, boating, reading, and traveling. But most of all, she loved her husband, John, her son, Ike, and her daughter, Lindsey. For those fortunate enough to have met her, Mary will be remembered as one of the warmest and most thoughtful people the world has known. Generous and welcoming, she opened her home to everyone-friends and strangers alike-who needed a home-cooked meal or a safe haven. She was fiercely loyal to and supportive of those close to her and kind to everyone she met. Mary's family takes comfort in the knowledge that her legacy lives on through the immeasurable impact she had on others. While the joy and laughter that her memories evoke pale in comparison to her radiant physical presence, they ensure that she will never be forgotten. It is Mary's family's hope that all who knew her will honor her memory by striving to treat others with the grace and kindness that she did. It was the size of Mary's heart that made the world a better place. A celebration of Mary's life will be held at 5pm on Saturday, January 23, at Baltimore Country Club at Five Farms, 11500 Mays Chapel Road, Lutherville, MD 21093. All friends are welcome. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation in Mary's name to Dyslexia Tutoring Program (dyslexiatutoringprogram.org). As John Irving, one of Mary's favorite authors, once wrote: "It is hard work and great art to make life not so serious." In that respect, Mary was a tireless and masterful artist. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, RUBEN D.
Snippets: SILVERMAN--Ruben D.,age 88, died on January 14, 2016, of complications of Parkinson's Disease. A lifelong resident of Lakewood, NJ, Mr. Silverman practiced law in Lakewood for over 55 years, representing a broad and diverse swath of the Lakewood community including Congregation Sons of Israel (the first Orthodox synagogue in Lakewood), and the operators of the Point Pleasant Beach. Mr. Silverman was a graduate from Lakewood High School in 1944, and then enlisted in the United States Navy at age 17, serving on the USS Nassau during the closing days of World War II. Upon the conclusion of his military service, he returned to New Jersey where he attended and was a graduate from Seton Hall College. He then entered the first class of Seton Hall Law School, and, after obtaining his J.D., began a law practice with his late brother, Orion Silverman. He practiced law for 55 years before retiring. He held positions on the local election, tax and zoning boards. He is survived by his wife of 60 years, Phyllis, and three children: Sharon Lieberman (and her husband, Steven), Dr. Lawrence Silverman (and his wife, Jodi Moise) and Barbara Hirsch (and her husband, Dr. Mark Hirsch), as well as seven grandchildren: Rachel Lieberman, Jessica Lieberman, Benjamin Lieberman, Joshua Moise-Silverman, Samuel Moise-Silverman, Corey Hirsch and Sarah Hirsch. Funeral services will be at the Mt. Sinai Cemetery in Lakewood, NJ, on Friday, January 15, 2016, 9:00am. The family asks that donations in his memory be made to the Lakewood Historical Society or to the Overlook Foundation, Attention: Movement Disorder Fund, in memory of Ruben Silverman. Services entrusted to Torchinsky Hebrew Funeral Home, Washington, DC, 202-541-1001. 1/3

Snippets: COSTAS--Christophil Basil, of New York, NY, passed away on January 12 at the age of 75. His spirit will remain with us always. The family will be receiving friends at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home on Friday, January 15. The funeral will be at 9am on Saturday, January 16 at the Holy Trinity Cathedral. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNET, SYLVAN
Snippets: BARNET--Sylvan. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the passing of Sylvan Barnet, an esteemed Benefactor and generous donor to the Museum. With his late partner William Burto, he donated the 17 important Chinese and Japanese hanging scrolls, dating from the 12th to the 17th century, featured in the Met's 2002 exhibition "The Written Image: Japanese Calligraphy and Painting from the Sylvan Barnet and William Burto Collection." These scrolls are treasured enhancements to the Museum's extensive holdings of Asian art, and will continue to provide a great benefit to scholars and the general public for generations to come. Daniel Brodsky, Chairman Thomas P. Campbell, Director and CEO Daniel H. Weiss, President 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIGGEN, EDITH ADAMS
Snippets: KIGGEN--Edith Adams, a prominent music producer, died at Mt. Sinai Hospital on October 28, 2015. She died of advanced multiple sclerosis. Her career included working with such artists as Cab Calloway, Whitney Houston, Stevie Wonder and James Taylor. Mrs. Kiggen produced many events at Carnegie Hall, and the record "Swing Reunion," nominated for a Grammy in 1985. She was born in Pasadena, CA on January 19, 1936 to celebrated airline executive Alvin Adams and daughter of New York Governor Nathan Miller, Elizabeth Miller Adams. Edith Kiggen's brother, Ambassador Alvin Adams, Jr., died just two weeks earlier, on October 10, 2015. She is survived by her daughter Elizabeth Kiggen of New York City, brother Nathan Adams of Enis, MO, sister Helen Vollmer of Moraga, CA. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  COCHRANE, LYDIA GOODWIN (STEINWAY)
Snippets: COCHRANE--Lydia Goodwin (Steinway). Youngest child of Ruth and Theodore Steinway, and the last of her generation. Survived by sons John and Nicholas, their wives Elizabeth Fama and Ginger Gregory, and six grandchildren. While she spent most of her adult life in Chicago and Italy, part of her remained a New Yorker. Her East Coast nephews, nieces, great-nephews and great-nieces are saddened by her death and send condolences to John, Nick and the rest of the Cochrane clan. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  COCHRANE, LYDIA GOODWIN (STEINWAY)
Snippets: COCHRANE--Lydia Goodwin (Steinway). 87, died in Chicago on January 5 of cardiac arrest, surrounded by family. Lydia was born in New York to Theo-dore and Ruth Steinway (Davis), the youngest of six children. After attending Dalton, Putney, Smith, and the University of Chicago, she taught French for many years at the University of Chicago Laboratory Schools, introducing Montessori-style methods into the curriculum. Later, she translated scholarly books and articles from French and Italian with the remarkable precision and passion that she brought to every endeavor. She was married to Eric W. Cochrane, noted professor of Italian history at the University of Chicago (died 1985). They lived in Chicago and Florence, Italy. An active member of the Fortnightly of Chicago, Tuesday Ladies, and two book groups, she swam in the early morning with friends and attended season subscriptions to almost everything Chicago has to offer. She is survived by her sons John and Nicholas, their wives Elizabeth Fama and Ginger Gregory, grandchildren Sally, Eric, Caleb, Jean, Lydia, and Sam, all of whom knew her as a deep friend, and a large Steinway/Davis/Cochrane clan. She was intelligent, inquisitive, open-minded, decisive, self-reliant, elegant, and infinitely complex. A memorial service will take place in Chicago in the early spring. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHALLER, RALPH F.
Snippets: SCHALLER--Ralph F.,died peacefully in his sleep on the morning of January 10, 2016, next to his adored and adoring wife, Roni Schaller, who remained by his side throughout his illness. His friends and family cannot imagine life without him. A memorial to celebrate his life will take place on Sunday, January 17, at 1:30pm, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue. As Ralph told all who asked, "I had a great life, better than most." 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, PETER L
Snippets: SIEGEL--Peter L. It is with heavy hearts, we announce that Peter L. Siegel died January 6, 2016 due to complications from a bone marrow transplant for the treatment of Leukemia. Peter was born in New York City on March 24, 1950 and grew up in Great Neck, NY. He has a BA from the University of Mass. Amherst, and holds two masters degrees from the University of Chicago. He was a passionate sailor and resided in Brooklyn, NY. He is survived by his sister and brother-in-law, Deborah and William Cosentino, seven cousins, as well as his very dear friends Dave Turner and Christine Benner. He is and will be greatly missed. We will be holding a memorial service for Peter this spring in New York City, time and location to be announced. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'HARA, REBECCA BROWNING

O'Hara, Liza O'Hara Mercereau, Alice O'Hara, and Hedwig O'Hara; by her son, Henry P.
