Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADES, ALAN M
Snippets: ADES--Alan M. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Alan M. Ades, a loyal and devoted friend of the Met, who was a distinguished member of the Board for almost 25 years. Mr. Ades served as a Member of the Association from 1987 to 1999, and as an Advisory Director from 1999 to 2011. On behalf of everyone at the Met, we extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Member of the Association Joan Taub Ades, his daughters Jane and Susan Ades, and his family and friends. He will be missed, but his kindness to the Met will always be remembered. Ann Ziff, Chairman of the Board Judith-Ann Corrente, President & CEO Peter Gelb, General Manager 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIOVANNIELLO, MARGARET MONTGOMERY TORR
Snippets: GIOVANNIELLO--Margaret Montgomery Torr, of Cedarhurst on January 17, 2016. Devoted wife, mother, attorney, administrative law judge and bar association leader. Born on May 23, 1927, in Terre Haute, Indiana, a graduate of the University of Wisconsin and Brooklyn Law School. After marriage to husband Joseph on June 10, 1951, they attended law school together at night while working full-time, then practiced law as Giovanniello & Giovanniello. Later, an administrative law judge with the New York State Department of Labor, she was a leader of the bar, serving as president of the Brooklyn Women's Bar Association, the New York Association of Administrative Law Judges and the National Association of Administrative Law Judiciary. Judge Giovanniello is survived by her sister Helen Exton; four sons: Rocco, Raymond, Joseph Jr., and Earle and six grandchildren, Lauren, Ray Jr., Rachel, Daniel, Sarah and Elizabeth. Family will receive friends at Flinch & Bruns Funeral Home, 34 Hempstead Avenue, Lynbrook, NY, Wednesday, January 20, 2016 from 2-4 and 7-9pm. Interment St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale on Thursday, January 21, 2016 at 11am. For further information, please visit www.flinchand bruns.com. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  YANKAUER, MARGARET BONNY
Snippets: YANKAUER--Margaret Bonny, 80, of Ramsey, NJ, succumbed peacefully to cancer on January 15, 2016 with her sons by her side. Ms. Yankauer was born on April 12, 1935 in New York City to Eva (Slifka) and Leonard Berger. She attended Bronx High School of Science and Smith College. Known to her family and friends as Bonny, she was an expert collector and purveyor of fine vintage costume jewelry such as Trifari, Haskel, and Hollycraft. She was a frequent exhibitor at the Triple Pier antique show in Manhattan and was sought out by a wide range of domestic and international buyers from Europe and Asia. Her former husband, Theodore Yankauer III, preceded her in death. She is survived by her son Jeff and his partner Elaina Caola; son Stephen; daughter-in-law Rachel Schnoll and her three beloved grandchildren Sarah, Theodore and Benjamin. She is also survived by her partner and dear friend Dr. Jack Block with whom she shared the last years of her life. A service was held on Sunday, January 17, 2016 at 2pm at Feeney Funeral Home in Ridgewood, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that you consider donations to the American Cancer Society. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZALK, RICHARD
Snippets: ZALK--Richard, 72, of Manhattan, died January 15 after a long illness. Richard was the devoted son of the late Joseph and Lee Zalk, protective and caring brother of Connie, much-loved uncle to David, husband of the late Sue Rosenberg Zalk and adoring nephew of Milton and Estelle Zalk and the late Martin and Judith Bloomberg and Hy and Sylvia Plotkin. For more than fifty years, he maintained a steadfast dedication to his legal practice and his clients, while his sharp wit, irreverence, and passion for photography, flying and astronomy helped define his life. He cherished his affiliation with the SoHo Photo Gallery, a co-op for photographers, for more than thirty years, serving as President for four. His loyalty to so many long-standing friends kept him ever-charming, attentive, creative, and warm even in his years of illness. Memorial celebration to be held Saturday, January 30th at 11am at the SoHo Photo Gallery, 15 White Street, New York, NY. Donations can be made to the SoHo Photo Gallery in his memory. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADES, ALAN M
Snippets: ADES--Alan M. (1925-2016). Manhattan School of Music and its Board of Trustees are profoundly saddened by the passing of Alan M. Ades, a successful entrepreneur and deeply committed philanthropist who was a great friend to MSM and an influential force for progress at the School. A Trustee Emeritus who served as a member of the School's Board of Trustees for 21 years between 1990 and 2011, Mr. Ades, along with his wife Joan Taub Ades, made many profound contributions to MSM over the years, ensuring the School's advancement as one of the world's leading independent music conservatories. In addition to his important service as a member of MSM's Board, Mr. Ades' stewardship was reflected in his active commitment to the many MSM committees of which he was a member and by the generous leadership contributions he and Mrs. Ades made to the School, often by way of the Joan and Alan Ades-Taub Family Foundation. Many of Mr. Ades' most significant contributions to MSM were guided by his love of opera (he also served as a director at the Met Opera and Santa Fe Opera). In addition to providing generous support to MSM scholarships for classical vocalists, the Ades Family Foundation established and continues to fund the School's prestigious Alan M. and Joan Taub Ades Vocal Competition, an annual event that is judged by an esteemed panel of opera professionals and awards significant cash prizes to winning students. Perhaps most significant, Mr. and Mrs. Ades led the capital campaign for, and ultimately named, one of MSM's key performance and rehearsal spaces, an indispensable, flexible black-box space that not only accommodates full-scale opera and orchestral rehearsals, but also seats audiences of up to 200 for a wide variety of performances. This key addition to MSM's facility-the Alan M. and Joan Taub Ades Performance Space-opened its doors in 2007 and stands as a lively testament to the visionary leadership and generosity made to MSM by this prominent leader in business and philanthropy and his wife, Joan Taub Ades. Our Board of Trustees, Administration, Faculty, Alumni, and Current Students are united in expressing the MSM Community's sorrow at the passing of this singular individual. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Mrs. Ades, whose continuing friendship we so highly cherish, and to the Ades family; we know that Alan's long, rich, accomplished life and the many wonderful memories it inspires will be a source of comfort and joy in the days and years ahead. Lorraine Gallard, Board Chair James Gandre, President 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBER, CONSTANCE E
Snippets: LIEBER--Constance E. The Brain & Behavior Research Foundation, formerly the National Alliance for Research on Schizophrenia and Depression (NARSAD), deeply mourns the passing of its visionary leader and President Emeritus, Constance E. Lieber. Connie, who served as President of the Foundation from 1989 to 2007, felt that research was the best avenue to find meaningful and lasting solutions to alleviate the suffering caused by mental illness. In her role as President Emeritus, she continued to offer her vision and guidance to the Foundation on a regular basis. Connie, along with her husband Stephen, passionately believed in the need to seed the field of neuropsychiatric research with as many talented scientists as possible to make a substantive impact on the broad spectrum of mental health research, which she fervently understood holds our best hope for ending the immense suffering caused by mental illness. Since 1980, Connie and Steve have served as extraordinary philanthropic supporters and leading public advocates of schizophrenia and depression research. Connie worked tirelessly for the cause and grew our grants program to a total of $342 million and was helpful to so many families who were desperately seeking help for their children. We recognize that she enhanced the lives of so many through her work for Brain & Behavior Research Foundation and by supporting scientists throughout the world and have the deepest gratitude to both Connie and Steve. Their generosity in supporting research on mental illness is a great model for all of us. Our deepest sympathies to Connie's beloved husband Steve, their daughter Janice, their son Sam and daughter-in-law Mary, their grandson, and to all of their loved ones. Connie was our leader and guiding light, providing inspiration and motivation to all who ever had the honor and privilege of knowing and working with her. Jeffrey Borenstein, M.D., President & CEO, The Brain & Behavior Research Foundation Herbert A. Pardes, M.D., President of the Foundation's Scientific Council 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARNETT, RUTH
Snippets: HARNETT--Ruth. Age 91, passed away peacefully at her home in Boca Raton, Florida on January 10, 2016. She was predeceased on October 1, 2015 by her loving husband of 71 years, Bertram, a lawyer and retired New York State Supreme Court Judge. She is survived by her children, Andrea, a lawyer and retired Magistrate Judge in Washington, DC and her husband, Benjamin Fisherow; David, a psychiatrist in Medford, Massachusetts and his wife, Dr. Vivian Halfin; James, a lawyer in Madison, Wisconsin and his wife, Marsha Harnett; six grandchildren; and one great granddaughter. Ruth Harnett grew up in Far Rockaway, New York, and graduated from Brooklyn College. She later resided in Great Neck, New York, and in Manhattan. She served as the Director of the Nassau County, New York, Vocational Center for Women in the 1970's. She had many talents: she was an accomplished cook, a talented knitter and quilter, and a speaker of Italian. She read and travelled extensively. She was a beautiful, gentle, generous, elegant, and kind woman, beloved by all who knew her. Most of all, she was intensely loyal to her family, whom she loved as immensely, as we loved her. We will miss her greatly. A funeral was held on January 13, at Temple Beth-el in Boca Raton, Florida. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Planned Parenthood or to the charity of your choice. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIOVANNIELLO, MARGARET MONTGOMERY TORR
Snippets: GIOVANNIELLO--Margaret Montgomery Torr, of Cedarhurst on January 17, 2016. Devoted wife, mother, attorney, administrative law judge and bar association leader. Born on May 23, 1927, in Terre Haute, Indiana, a graduate of the University of Wisconsin and Brooklyn Law School. After marriage to husband Joseph on June 10, 1951, they attended law school together at night while working full-time, then practiced law as Giovanniello & Giovanniello. Later, an administrative law judge with the New York State Department of Labor, she was a leader of the bar, serving as president of the Brooklyn Women's Bar Association, the New York Association of Administrative Law Judges and the National Association of Administrative Law Judiciary. Judge Giovanniello is survived by her sister Helen Exton; four sons: Rocco, Raymond, Joseph Jr., and Earle and six grandchildren, Lauren, Ray Jr., Rachel, Daniel, Sarah and Elizabeth. Family will receive friends at Flinch & Bruns Funeral Home, 34 Hempstead Avenue, Lynbrook, NY, Wednesday, January 20, 2016 from 2-4 and 7-9pm. Interment St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale on Thursday, January 21, 2016 at 11am. For further information, please visit www.flinchand bruns.com. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMSON, RICHARD S

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARNETT, RUTH
Snippets: HARNETT--Ruth. Age 91, passed away peacefully at her home in Boca Raton, Florida on January 10, 2016. She was predeceased on October 1, 2015 by her loving husband of 71 years, Bertram, a lawyer and retired New York State Supreme Court Judge. She is survived by her children, Andrea, a lawyer and retired Magistrate Judge in Washington, DC and her husband, Benjamin Fisherow; David, a psychiatrist in Medford, Massachusetts and his wife, Dr. Vivian Halfin; James, a lawyer in Madison, Wisconsin and his wife, Marsha Harnett; six grandchildren; and one great granddaughter. Ruth Harnett grew up in Far Rockaway, New York, and graduated from Brooklyn College. She later resided in Great Neck, New York, and in Manhattan. She served as the Director of the Nassau County, New York, Vocational Center for Women in the 1970's. She had many talents: she was an accomplished cook, a talented knitter and quilter, and a speaker of Italian. She read and travelled extensively. She was a beautiful, gentle, generous, elegant, and kind woman, beloved by all who knew her. Most of all, she was intensely loyal to her family, whom she loved as immensely, as we loved her. We will miss her greatly. A funeral was held on January 13, at Temple Beth-el in Boca Raton, Florida. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Planned Parenthood or to the charity of your choice. 1/3

Gross, Chairman Robert B. Satloff, Executive Director 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDELSON, SOLOMON
Snippets: MENDELSON--Solomon. The Cantors Assembly sadly notes the passing of its distinguished past president, Hazzan Solomon Mendelson. Sol was a visionary with the capacity to realize many of his dreams, teaching his colleagues to reach well beyond the roles most often associated with a Cantor. In particular, he was a prolific commissioner of new Jewish music, persuading the finest contemporary composers to become his collaborators. He will be deeply missed. The Cantors Assembly extends its condolences to Sol's wife, Emma, his children Keith and Lauren, their spouses, his grandchildren, sister Betty, and his brother, our revered colleague, Hazzan Jacob Mendelson. Alberto Mizrahi, President Stephen J. Stein, Exec. V.P. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENTHAL, J. ROBERT, M.D. NEW YORK EYE AND EAR INFIRMARY OF MOUNT SINAI NOTES WITH SORROW THE PASSING OF OUR DEAR FRIEND AND COLLEAGUE J. ROBERT ROSENTHAL, M.D., A DEDICATED MEMBER OF OUR COMMUNITY FOR MORE THAN 55 YEARS. A RENOWNED CORNEA SURGEON, DR. ROSENTHAL WAS ALSO THE HOSPITAL'S FIRST MEDICAL DIRECTOR AND WENT ON TO SERVE AS SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT FOR MEDICAL AFFAIRS AND CHIEF MEDICAL OFFICER BEFORE STEPPING DOWN IN 2014. HE WAS A CHAMPION OF QUALITY SERVICE, ADVANCED RESEARCH, AND EXCELLENCE IN PHYSICIAN TRAINING. DR. ROSENTHAL WAS THE MEMBER OF A DISTINGUISHED FAMILY OF PIONEERING OPHTHALMOLOGISTS AT NEW YORK EYE AND EAR INFIRMARY. NEW YORK EYE AND EAR INFIRMARY OF MOUNT SINAI AND THE MOUNT SINAI HEALTH SYSTEM EXTEND HEARTFELT CONDOLENCES TO HIS WIFE GLADYS AND THE ENTIRE ROSENTHAL FAMILY. PETER W. MAY, CHAIRMAN, BOARDS OF TRUSTEES, MOUNT SINAI HEALTH SYSTEM KENNETH L. DAVIS, M.D., PRESIDENT AND CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, MOUNT SINAI HEALTH SYSTEM 1
Snippets: ROSENTHAL--J. Robert, M.D. New York Eye and Ear Infirmary of Mount Sinai notes with sorrow the passing of our dear friend and colleague J. Robert Rosenthal, M.D., a dedicated member of our community for more than 55 years. A renowned cornea surgeon, Dr. Rosenthal was also the hospital's first Medical Director and went on to serve as Senior Vice President for Medical Affairs and Chief Medical Officer before stepping down in 2014. He was a champion of quality service, advanced research, and excellence in physician training. Dr. Rosenthal was the member of a distinguished family of pioneering ophthalmologists at New York Eye and Ear Infirmary. In 2013, he received the John Kearney Rodgers Physician of the Year Award for his commitment to the hospital. New York Eye and Ear Infirmary of Mount Sinai and the Mount Sinai Health System extend heartfelt condolences to his wife Gladys and the entire Rosenthal family. Peter W. May, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, Mount Sinai Health System Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President and Chief Executive Officer, Mount Sinai Health System 1

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, RICHARD M.
Snippets: MARKS--Richard M.,M.D., aged 80, died peacefully at home on January 14, 2016, surrounded by family. Richard will be especially missed by his wife, Judith, his four children, Andrew, Gigi, Elisabeth and Matthew, seven grandchildren, innumerable close family members and longtime friends. Richard was a psychiatrist and psychoanalyst in New York City, where he practiced for more than five decades. Richard grew up in Brooklyn and graduated from Midwood High School. He went to Columbia University and then onto SUNY Downstate College of Medicine, graduating in 1961. A lifetime New Yorker, Richard was a psychiatrist in the Air Force, based in Texas, before returning to New York City to finish his training at Albert Einstein Medical Center in the Bronx and the New York Psychoanalytic Institute. An Attending Clinical Professor in the department of Psychiatry at Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Assistant Attending Psychiatrist at Montefiore Medical Center and senior supervisor in the Consult Liaison Service at Montefiore Medical Center, Richard co-authored "Undertreatment of Medical Inpatients with Narcotic Analgesics," in the Annals of Internal Medicine, an influential article that has been cited more than 1,000 times in academic papers. Richard was an avid reader of history and The New York Times, a devotee of opera, classical music, and art. Richard loved traveling with his wife-together, they visited 43 countries. More than anything, he loved spending time with his family. He will be deeply missed by all of us. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMSON, RICHARD
Snippets: ABRAMSON--Richard. The staff and trustees of Northwell Health (formerly North Shore-LIJ Health System) mourn the loss of Trustee Richard Abramson. A dedicated benefactor, co-chairman of the Investment Committee and a member of the Finance, Audit and Executive Committees, Richard and his wife Lorraine supported many programs at Long Island Jewish Medical Center. Richard's friendship, philanthropic support and dedication helped Northwell Health become a regional and national leader in health care. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Lorraine; children Gregg Abramson and Jill Manczyk; and grandchildren Emma, Leah, Miles and Sadie. Mark L. Claster, Chairman, Board of Trustees, Northwell Health Michael J. Dowling, President and CEO, Northwell Health 1/3

Snippets: LARSON--Rev. Dr. Lawrence A.A.,died on January 16, 2016 at the age of 81. Born on December 27, 1934 to Julia and Adolph Larson in Chicago, IL. Jeffrey Larson, Arlan Bussell, Merryl Dimaio, Lindsey Anderson, Jevan Anderson, eight grandchildren, two great-grandchildren and his sister Merryl Sanchez. Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADES, ALAN MAXWELL
Snippets: ADES--Alan Maxwell, died on January 17, 2016. He was 90 years old. He leaves his loving wife, of 57 years, Joan, two daughters, Jane Ades and Susan Ades and her husband, Stephen Lawlor and five grandchildren, Benjamin, Raphi, Kirya, Olivia and Isabelle. He graduated Townsend Harris High School in three years and joined the army at 17 where he became part of the Corps of Engineers. He rose to the position of staff sergeant soon afterwards. After the war, he attended and graduated from CCNY. He founded and was president of Auburn Label and Tag, Co. He loved classical music from the time he was a teenager, when he first worked concessions at Carnegie Hall and extended and embraced that passion by serving on the Board of Directors of The Metropolitan Opera. Additionally, he served on the Board of Trustees of The Manhattan School of Music and of Central Synagogue in New York, where he was also confirmed. While at MSM, he and Joan founded the Ades Vocal Competition and built The Joan Taub Ades and Alan M. Ades Performance Space, as well. He was an avid sailor and skier. Services will take place at 11:00am on Tuesday, January 19, 2016 at Central Synagogue, 652 Lexington Ave., New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to The Metropolitan Opera or The Manhattan School of Music. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLBY, DR
Snippets: COLBY--Dr. Marvelle S. The entire Marymount Manhattan College community mourns the loss of one of our most dedicated faculty members, Professor Emerita, Dr. Marvelle S. Colby. A leader in the business and entrepreneurial fields, Dr. Colby served Marymount Manhattan College for 21 years as a member of the Business Management and Accounting Division, during which time she also served as the Division Chair. In 2007, a number of Dr. Marvelle S. Colby's former students, colleagues, faculty, and staff joined together to create the Dr. Marvelle S. Colby Endowed Scholarship Fund to ensure that her legacy will live on at the College for years to come. Dr. Colby was a valued member of the Marymount Manhattan College community and we mourn this loss and share our condolences with her family. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY, Friday, January 22nd at 11:15am. The services will be followed by burial at Woodlawn Cemetery. Kerry Walk, Ph.D., President, Marymount Manhattan College; Hope Knight, Chairperson of the Board of Trustees, Marymount Manhattan College 1/3

Snippets: KAHN--Walter. SAR mourns with deep sorrow the passing of the beloved father of Nathan (Sandy) Kahn, generous benefactors and leaders of our school community. Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISSELBACHER, MARGA SCHIFF
Snippets: ISSELBACHER--Marga Schiff, (June 6, 1927-January 17, 2016). Loving mother of Tina and Jesse Isselbacher and grandmother of Kassidy Isselbacher Marino, Haley Singleton and Samantha Isselbacher. Devoted widow of Henry Isselbacher and sister to Robert (Bob) Schiff. Born in Oberthulba, she immigrated to the United States from Badkissingen at the age of nine, when she was sent by her parents alone to escape Nazi Germany. Her life was filled with the joys of marriage, parenthood and friendship and she gave of herself without reservation and with deep affection. She will be sorely missed by her immediate family and her sisters-in-law and nieces and nephews as well as the numerous friends for whom she cared so much during her full life. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYERS, DONALD I
Snippets: MEYERS--Donald I. Dr. Donald I. Meyers, a leader of the post-war generation of American psychoanalysts, renowned teacher and therapist, and beloved husband, father and grandfather, died on January 13, 2016. An exceptional researcher, teacher and doctor, Don, in loving partnership with his wife of 49 years, Helen, was an influential presence in the psychoanalytic world and a mentor to generations of psychiatrists and psychoanalysts. He was an accomplished therapist, specializing in child analysis, with one of the best reputations in NYC and around the world. As a Clinical Professor of Psychiatry and Training & Supervising Psychoanalyst, he was a pillar of the Columbia Center for Psychoanalytic Training and Research, Don had a significant impact on American psychoanalysis through his leadership at the American Psychoanalytic Association, where he opened the Association to a broader and more inclusive spectrum of ideas and practitioners. His academic work was in child psychiatry and child analysis. He was Director of Experimental Psychiatry at the Henry Ittleson Center for Child Research. Don was a loving husband, father, uncle and grandfather, and a beloved, loyal friend. He was devoted to his wife, Helen, who passed in 2010. He was universally loved for his sweet demeanor, generous spirit, silent strength, mischievous humor, encyclopedic musical knowledge, and uncommon empathy. All who knew him found understanding and comfort in his embrace. As a good friend has said, Don was all love. He is survived by his son Andrew, partner Fronda, sister Pat, granddaughters Rennie and Maddie, and nieces and nephews Erica, Lizzie, Jonathan, Peter, Ann, Skip, Janice, Sandy, Ken, Benjy, Susie and Judy. Services will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at 11:30am on Monday, January 25th. Donations may be sent to the APA Helen Meyers Traveling Scholar Committee, 309 East 49th St, NY, NY 10017. 1/3

Snippets: ANDERSON--Jeanne. The community of West End Synagogue, A Reconstructionist Congregation, has lost a courageous role model. Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIN, ESTELLE WEINBERG
Snippets: LEWIN--Estelle Weinberg. Born April 19, 1920, died January 19, 2016, three months short of her 96th birthday. Daughter of Benjamin and Mary Weinberg, Estelle was part of a loving family. She was predeceased by both her parents and her only brother, Michael Wayne. In 1941, she met the love of her life, Harry Lewin. They married on March 21, 1942 and lived together in wedded bliss. They were married for more than 64 years when Harry died in June 2006. Together they had two daughters, Linda Taub and Blylee Gardiner Bernstein. Linda's husband David passed away in November 2012. Estelle is survived by her daughters Linda and Blylee and Blylee's husband David Bernstein; three grandsons and their wives, Andrew and Suzanne Taub, Marc and Sandy Taub and Joshua and Lisa Taub. She had six great-grandchildren, Jake, Trevor, Chloe, Camille, Asher and Matthew. Funeral services will be held on Friday, January 22, 2016 at 12:00 noon. They will be conducted at Gutterman's Memorial Chapel, Jericho Turnpike in Woodbury, NY. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, DR
Snippets: GREENBERG--Dr. Herb, of Princeton, NJ, passed away after a courageous fight against cancer on Tuesday, January 19, 2016, at home surrounded by his loving family. Herb was the founder and CEO of Caliper Corporation. A lifelong Democrat and supporter of progressive causes, Herb fought for equal rights for minorities, women, and returning veterans, as well as abused animals. Herb lost his eyesight at the age of 10. He held multiple degrees from CCNY and a Ph.D. from NYU. Son of the late Harry and Helen Greenberg, Herb is survived by his two sisters, five children; Gary, Mark, Holly, Alex, and Sally; and one grandchild, Sarah. Donations can be made to Learning Ally, Helen Keller International, or SAVE, A Friend to Homeless Animals. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUARTARARO, SALLY
Snippets: QUARTARARO--Sally. The Boards and staff of James Lenox House Association and Carnegie East House are greatly saddened by the death of Sally Quartararo. Respectfully, Barbara R. Evans, President, James Lenox House Association; Beatrice Broadwater, President, Carnegie East House; Joseph H. Girven, Executive Director 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIERMONT, DONALD K.
Snippets: PIERMONT--Donald K.,92, of Fair Lawn, NJ passed on Tuesday, January 19, 2016 at home with his loving wife by his side. Born and raised in New York, he resided in Venice, FL for 27 years before returning to Fair Lawn where he had lived for many years. An avid golfer, he served as an officer of the Preakness Hills Country Club in Wayne. A very charitable man especially to the military, Humane Society and American Cancer Society, Don was a loyal and knowledgeable New York Yankees fan, and enjoyed travelling and time spent at the beach. Prior to retiring in 1988, he owned and operated Dave Stern Tires in Paterson and Morristown for 43 years. Beloved husband of Barbara (Stern) Piermont. Loving and devoted father of Donald Piermont, Jr. and wife Barbara, Jack Piermont and wife Marilyn and Sally Gillenson and husband Josh. Cherished grandfather of six and great grandfather of four. The family will receive relatives and friends Thursday, 7-9pm at Vander Plaat-Caggiano Funeral Home, 13-31 Saddle River Road, Fair Lawn, NJ, 201-797-3500. A Funeral Mass is planned for Friday, January 22, 2016, 10:30am at St. Anne R.C. Church, 15-05 St. Anne Street, Fair Lawn, NJ. Entombment will follow at Holy Sepulchre Cemetery in Totowa, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations to a charity of choice would be appreciated. For additional information, please visit www.vpfairlawn.com. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALEXANDER, JOHN
Snippets: ALEXANDER--John. 1/21/47 - 10/27/15 Kipling might have written his famous lines to read-If you can talk with politicians and keep your virtue, Or walk with judges and jurists-nor loose the common touch; If he had had the honor and pleasure of knowing you, John. You are fondly remembered on your birthday. Val 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLDBERG, LISA ELLEN
Snippets: GOLDBERG--Lisa Ellen, who lit the world, still lights our lives. John, Jed, Katie 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLNER, MARTIN
Snippets: POLLNER--Martin. The family of Martin Pollner mourns the passing of its devoted husband, father, grandfather and brother. In addition to his service to his family, Martin provided more than half a century of service to his country and to the legal profession, serving several United States presidents. He held senior positions with the United States government, including Deputy Attorney General under Robert F. Kennedy and Deputy Assistant of the Treasury and Director of Law Enforcement under Secretaries of the Treasury David Kennedy, John Connally and George Schultz. He helped develop civil rights legislation and developed and coordinated law enforcement policy within the Treasury Department, including the IRS, Customs, Secret Service and Interpol. In addition to service on various Cabinet committees, Martin headed the U.S. Delegation to several Interpol General Assemblies and, after returning to private practice, he was appointed by Secretary of State William P. Rogers as the U.S. representative to the International Narcotics Control Board of the United Nations, a position he held for several years. Over the years, Martin received numerous honors and awards, including the Townsend Harris Medal in 2005 and the Ellis Island Medal of Honor in 2007. After serving as an Assistant United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, Martin, in private practice, advised and represented individuals, including CEO's of major corporations as well as numerous luminaries, and companies; investigated corporate misconduct; and untangled complex tax issues, workouts and bankruptcies. Notwithstanding a stellar legal career, nothing delighted him more than his family. He is survived by his wife Valerie, his sons Daniel and Richard, and their spouses, Melissa and Deb, granddaughters Gabriella, Rebakah and Lexi, and his brother Philip. He was entirely unique, and we will miss him. For those who wish to honor his memory, we ask that donations be made to The Rogosin Institute, www.rogosin.org/donate, The Hebrew Home at Riverdale, or Cardiovascular Institute Fund of Mt. Sinai. Service Thursday, January 21, 2016, 12 noon at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave., NYC. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMSON, RICHARD
Snippets: ABRAMSON--Richard. What a unique gentleman; accomplished and so modest. Kind and gentle, we will miss him. Roberta and Stanley 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKEL, MICKEY (MURIEL)
Snippets: FRANKEL--Mickey (Muriel), 73, of Scarsdale, NY, passed away peacefully at home on January 18, 2016, and is remembered lovingly by her family. Wife for over 53 years to Steven; mother of Jill, Pamela and Wendy, mother-in-law to Steven, Jon and Adam; loving and adoring grandmother of Hannah, Jeffrey, Jacob, Eliot, Benjamin, Abigail, Ethan and Brooke; sister of Louis Morris and daughter of the late Harold and Edythe Morris. Mickey graduated from Scarsdale High School and the University of Pennsylvania and throughout her life was a dedicated and caring volunteer. She will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be private. Contributions in Mickey's memory can be made to Westchester Reform Temple, Scarsdale, NY. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAUSTEIN, HELEN
Snippets: BLAUSTEIN--Helen, passed away on January 18, 2016. She was a beloved mother, a devoted wife, an incredible grandmother and a wonderful friend. Though she is no longer physically with us, her spirit lives on in those fortunate enough to have known her. There will be a memorial service for her this Sunday at 1pm at Riverside Chapel, 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, WALTER
Snippets: KAHN--Walter. The Yeshiva University family is deeply saddened by the passing of Mr. Walter Kahn, Z"l, a revered member of the Queens Jewish Center and the Queens community who was widely admired for his support of Jewish education. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his beloved wife, Grace, and their devoted children: Nathan (and Sandy) Kahn, a member of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine Board of Overseers and YU Benefactors; Simon (and Robin) Kahn; Vivian (and Gerry) Adler; and his adoring grandchildren. The entire Kahn family emulates the noble ways of their deeply esteemed cherished parents in their respective communities. May they find comfort among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Richard M. Joel, President, Yeshiva University Norman Lamm, President Emeritus 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, JACOB
Snippets: FEINBERG--Jacob. Bone Marrow Registry co-Founder Jacob Feinberg dies at 87. The Feinberg Family and the Gift of Life Bone Marrow Foundation mourn the loss of the organization's co-founder, Jacob Feinberg. A CPA with Brout and Company and BDO, Jack later became a pioneer with his wife Arlene advancing the cause of bone marrow donor registration throughout the United States and abroad for the benefit of patients battling blood cancer. His efforts made possible bone marrow transplants for thousands of patients in need. The world is a better place thanks to Jack, a true hero, and his memory will live on through the lives he and Arlene saved together. He was the loving father of Jay, Steven, Edward of blessed memory and daughter-in-law Sheryl; loving grandfather of Shauna, Michelle and Skylar; brother of Robert and sister-in-law of Marty. Jack will be missed by the entire Gift of Life organization that he and Arlene created, and his countless friends and loving family. Contributions in Jack's memory may be made at www.giftoflife.org. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASTELLANOS, ELIDA
Snippets: CASTELLANOS--Elida, on January 21, 2016. Beloved wife the late Ambassador Rafael Castellanos. Loving mother of Rafael (Andria) Castellanos and the late Brenda (Paul) Schietroma. Cherished grandmother of Nae (Manuel) Breidenbach, Christina (Chad) Weaver, Rafael Castellanos and David Castellanos. Devoted great-grandmother of Nina and Courtney. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel" 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, today 2pm-5pm and 7pm-9pm. Mass of Christian burial, Saturday, 9am at St. Ignatius Loyola R.C. Church, 84th Street and Park Avenue, NYC. Interment to follow at Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Mrs. Castellanos' memory may be made to the Central Park Medical Unit, PO Box 440 New York, NY 10028 or CPMU.com 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, HERBERT
Snippets: ABRAMS--Herbert, M.D. Eminent radiologist, co-founder of Physicians for Social Responsibility, scholar of nuclear disarmament and human error, and to us, a devoted and generous uncle and great-uncle. We will miss you forever. Peter Lazes, Marie Rudden, Daniel Levy, Andrew Lazes, and Adrienne Lazes 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURZIN, CAROL
Snippets: BURZIN--Carol. Carol lost a long and courageous battle, but won the admiration, respect and love of everyone who knew her. She was kind and generous with an infectious laugh and smile that will always be remembered. She will be missed by all. Our deepest condolences to uncle Phil, Jeff, Karen, Sarah, Amy and Katie. Joel, Elaine, Beth, Jill and Robert Burzin 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEHANEY, LAURETTA VIRGINIA SMALLWOOD
Snippets: DEHANEY--Lauretta Virginia Smallwood, retired nurse, died peacefully at the age of 100 on January 11, 2016 in Bronx, NY. Beloved wife of the late Hilton DeHaney, she leaves to mourn a host of relatives and devoted friends. On Saturday, January 23rd, the family will receive friends at Christ Church (Episcopal) Riverdale prior to the service at 11am. An additional Memorial Service will be held on February 6, 2016 at St. Columba's Episcopal Church (Washington, DC) followed by the interment. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISSELBACHER, MARGA SCHIFF
Snippets: ISSELBACHER--Marga Schiff, (June 6, 1927-January 17, 2016). Loving mother of Tina and Jesse Isselbacher and grandmother of Kassidy Isselbacher Marino, Haley Singleton and Samantha Isselbacher. Devoted widow of Henry Isselbacher and sister to Robert (Bob) Schiff. Born in Oberthulba, she immigrated to the United States from Badkissingen at the age of nine, when she was sent by her parents alone to escape Nazi Germany. Her life was filled with the joys of marriage, parenthood and friendship and she gave of herself without reservation and with deep affection. She will be sorely missed by her immediate family and her sisters-in-law and nieces and nephews as well as the numerous friends for whom she cared so much during her full life. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Memorials  GARITY, EDWARD J

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYERS, DONALD I
Snippets: MEYERS--Donald I. Dr. Donald I. Meyers, a leader of the post-war generation of American psychoanalysts, renowned teacher and therapist, and beloved husband, father and grandfather, died on January 13, 2016. An exceptional researcher, teacher and doctor, Don, in loving partnership with his wife of 49 years, Helen, was an influential presence in the psychoanalytic world and a mentor to generations of psychiatrists and psychoanalysts. He was an accomplished therapist, specializing in child analysis, with one of the best reputations in NYC and around the world. As a Clinical Professor of Psychiatry and Training & Supervising Psychoanalyst, he was a pillar of the Columbia Center for Psychoanalytic Training and Research, Don had a significant impact on American psychoanalysis through his leadership at the American Psychoanalytic Association, where he opened the Association to a broader and more inclusive spectrum of ideas and practitioners. His academic work was in child psychiatry and child analysis. He was Director of Experimental Psychiatry at the Henry Ittleson Center for Child Research. Don was a loving husband, father, uncle and grandfather, and a beloved, loyal friend. He was devoted to his wife, Helen, who passed in 2010. He was universally loved for his sweet demeanor, generous spirit, silent strength, mischievous humor, encyclopedic musical knowledge, and uncommon empathy. All who knew him found understanding and comfort in his embrace. As a good friend has said, Don was all love. He is survived by his son Andrew, partner Fronda, sister Pat, granddaughters Rennie and Maddie, and nieces and nephews Erica, Lizzie, Jonathan, Peter, Ann, Skip, Janice, Sandy, Ken, Benjy, Susie and Judy. Services will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at 11:30am on Monday, January 25th. Donations may be sent to the APA Helen Meyers Traveling Scholar Committee, 309 East 49th St, NY, NY 10017. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLBY, MARVELLE (SEITMAN)
Snippets: COLBY--Marvelle (Seitman), 83, on January 19. Survived by her devoted husband, Selig Alkon, beloved children Lisa (Paul) and Eric (Ann), cherished grandchildren Owen, Jade and Ella. Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAYTON, ROBERT
Snippets: DAYTON--Robert. Robert Dayton, whose career spanned decades in support of a vibrant downtown Minneapolis, MN, died on January 17th. He was 73 years old. A great-grandson of the founder of Daytons, Bob carried on the family retail and community-oriented legacy. After graduating from Yale in 1964, Bob joined what was to become Dayton Hudson and then Target, rising to become General Merchandise Manager and then Vice President of Stores. While with Daytons, Bob attended the Program for Management Development at Harvard Business School. A merchandiser at heart, Bob became recognized for his deftness in identifying and supporting designers such as Calvin Klein and Ralph Lauren early in their careers. In 1977 Bob left Daytons and purchased Harold, an upscale specialty store for women. Working together with his wife Joanie, Bob restored its iconic status as a Minneapolis retail institution. In 1984 Bob spearheaded the development of The Conservatory, the first enclosed shopping complex in Minneapolis. Throughout his career Bob advocated for a thriving downtown and worked to strengthen the Twin Cities as a major league community through efforts to bring Superbowl XXVI to Minneapolis, keep the Timberwolves, and secure funding for a new outdoor Twins stadium. Bob served on several corporate boards including Northwestern National Bank, First American Funds, and Williams Sonoma. In 1992 Bob became CEO of Okabena, helping transform the Dayton family office into a nationally recognized leader in the then-nascent family office industry. Fiercely loyal to and enormously proud of the people and places he loved, Bob was committed to serving his community. He worked tirelessly on behalf of many non-profits including the Minneapolis Institute of Arts, Abbott Northwestern Hospital, the United Way, and Westminster Presbyterian Church. In addition, Bob served as a Trustee of the Blake School, Carlton College, and the University of Minnesota Foundation. In 1994 Bob founded and was later named Chair Emeritus of the Mentoring Partnership of Minnesota. Bob grew up in Wayzata, Minnesota and attended Blake, Eaglebrook, and Taft. While at Yale, Bob met his wife Joanie, then attending Skidmore College, on a blind date at the Dartmouth Winter Carnival. They were married in 1964 and had three boys. Bob enjoyed a number of hobbies, but none more so than golf. Beginning at Woodhill Country Club, his passion eventually extended east to Pine Valley and west to Cypress Point. He cofounded Spring Hill Golf Club and enjoyed playing in the U.S. Seniors. Bob will always be remembered for his warm heart, wonderful smile, infectious laughter, fantastic sense of humor, and tremendous spirit. He is survived by Joanie, his wife of 51 years, two brothers, three sons, and seven grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on February 18th at Westminster Presbyterian Church in Minneapolis. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  IMMERMAN, ROBERT M.

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIELENZIGER, DR
Snippets: ZIELENZIGER--Dr. Ruth, who helped change how Conservative Jews in America are taught the Bible, and inspired some of Israel's most enduring poetry of love while a young woman, died Thursday at the RiverWalk independent living facility of the Hebrew Home in the Bronx, one day shy of her 93rd birthday. Awarded her Doctorate of Hebrew Literature at age 66, Dr. Zielenziger was instrumental in creating the curriculum for teaching the books of Genesis and Exodus in Conservative Judaism at the Melton Research Center of the Jewish Theological Seminary in New York City. The Melton program emphasized critical inquiry and the study of Bible for character education. She was a proponent of studying the creation myths and texts of other Middle Eastern cultures in order to better understand the context in which the Bible was written. Born in London, the daughter of Leo and Lola Herrmann, ardent Zionists, she grew up in Jerusalem before the founding of the Jewish state, and served as an ambulance driver and chauffeur in the British Army during World War II, where her fluency in Hebrew, English and German was invaluable. After the War, she attended the Hebrew University in Jerusalem, where she met a German emigre and fellow student, Yehuda Pfeuffer, whom she renamed Yehuda Amichai. Amichai went on to become Israel's most celebrated poet, and the first drafts of many of his most enduring poems were composed as letters exchanged between the two. Amichai's letters to Dr. Zielenziger are now archived at Ben Gurion University in Israel. She moved to New York in 1947, to study at the Teachers Institute of the Seminary. While in New York she met and subsequently married Eric W. Zielenziger, a German Jewish survivor of the Holocaust who escaped the Nazis by living underground in Amsterdam for more than two years. They had two children. For 34 years, Dr. Zielenziger taught education at the Jewish Theological Seminary, after teaching for many years in Hebrew schools in Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island. Before relocating to Riverdale in their later years the Zielenzigers lived primarily in Freeport and Great Neck, NY. She is survived by her sons David, of Great Neck, and Michael (Diane Abt) of Oakland, CA and Manhattan and a brother, Dr. Gabriel Herrmann of Jerusalem. Services will be held Friday at 11am at Riverside Nassau North, 55 N. Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIN, ESTELLE WEINBERG
Snippets: LEWIN--Estelle Weinberg. Born April 19, 1920, died January 19, 2016, three months short of her 96th birthday. Daughter of Benjamin and Mary Weinberg, Estelle was part of a loving family. She was predeceased by both her parents and her only brother, Michael Wayne. In 1941, she met the love of her life, Harry Lewin. They married on March 21, 1942 and lived together in wedded bliss. They were married for more than 64 years when Harry died in June 2006. Together they had two daughters, Linda Taub and Blylee Gardiner Bernstein. Linda's husband David passed away in November 2012. Estelle is survived by her daughters Linda and Blylee and Blylee's husband David Bernstein; three grandsons and their wives, Andrew and Suzanne Taub, Marc and Sandy Taub and Joshua and Lisa Taub. She had six great-grandchildren, Jake, Trevor, Chloe, Camille, Asher and Matthew. Funeral services will be held on Friday, January 22, 2016 at 12:00 noon. They will be conducted at Gutterman's Memorial Chapel, Jericho Turnpike in Woodbury, NY. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSTEIN, HAROLD JAY
Snippets: ROTHSTEIN--Harold Jay, of Teaneck, NJ died on Wednesday, January 20, 2016, two weeks after being diagnosed with pancreatic cancer and one week before his 70th birthday. Carole Rothstein, his wife of 46 years had her head on his chest when he took his last breath. He was born on January 26, 1946 in the Bronx and was the youngest child of Rose and Milton Rothstein. He graduated from City College with a degree in sociology. He went on to complete his Master's in Education and "ABD" (all but his dissertation) for his PhD both from the New School. Starting out as a teacher in the late 1960s, Harold dedicated his life to education. He taught science until the mid- 1970s becoming an administrator in the 1980s and 1990s. Since retiring from the Board of Education he was an educational consultant mentoring students and teachers who wanted to become principals. He was proud of being involved in both Teach for America and the New York City Fellowship Program. Always the life of the party Harold lived every minute with passion. An avid photographer and world traveler he visited his 106th country in December. His life was filled with culture, music and art that he shared with his family and friends. Harold is survived by his wife of 46 years, Carole Rothstein, his sons Gabriel and Adam, his daughter and son-in-law Jessica and Randall Berman, his granddaughter Rachel Rose, his brother and sister-in-law Joel and Barbara Rothstein, and many nieces, nephews and cousins. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Harold J. Rothstein can be made to The Institute for Educational Advancement or the Lustgarten Foundation. Services will be 1pm today at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway (Route 4 West), Fair Lawn, NJ. Burial will follow at Cedar Park Cemetery, Emerson, New Jersey. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOREVIC, CHARLES

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLBY, DR
Snippets: COLBY--Dr. Marvelle S. The entire Marymount Manhattan College community mourns the loss of one of our most dedicated faculty members, Professor Emerita, Dr. Marvelle S. Colby. A leader in the business and entrepreneurial fields, Dr. Colby served Marymount Manhattan College for 21 years as a member of the Business Management and Accounting Division, during which time she also served as the Division Chair. In 2007, a number of Dr. Marvelle S. Colby's former students, colleagues, faculty, and staff joined together to create the Dr. Marvelle S. Colby Endowed Scholarship Fund to ensure that her legacy will live on at the College for years to come. Dr. Colby was a valued member of the Marymount Manhattan College community and we mourn this loss and share our condolences with her family. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY, Friday, January 22nd at 11:15am. The services will be followed by burial at Woodlawn Cemetery. Kerry Walk, Ph.D., President, Marymount Manhattan College; Hope Knight, Chairperson of the Board of Trustees, Marymount Manhattan College 1/3

Pre-deceased by his wife Rena in 2003, now beloved husband to Reva SternChasin, amazing father to Jeff (Lisa), Larry (Andrea), and Marni (Lee) and adored grandfather of Shelby Chasin, Samara Chasin, Jake Garfinkle, Jack Chasin, William Chasin and Ryan Garfinkle. Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAYTON, ROBERT
Snippets: DAYTON--Robert. Robert Dayton, whose career spanned decades in support of a vibrant downtown Minneapolis, MN, died on January 17th. He was 73 years old. A great-grandson of the founder of Daytons, Bob carried on the family retail and community-oriented legacy. After graduating from Yale in 1964, Bob joined what was to become Dayton Hudson and then Target, rising to become General Merchandise Manager and then Vice President of Stores. While with Daytons, Bob attended the Program for Management Development at Harvard Business School. A merchandiser at heart, Bob became recognized for his deftness in identifying and supporting designers such as Calvin Klein and Ralph Lauren early in their careers. In 1977 Bob left Daytons and purchased Harold, an upscale specialty store for women. Working together with his wife Joanie, Bob restored its iconic status as a Minneapolis retail institution. In 1984 Bob spearheaded the development of The Conservatory, the first enclosed shopping complex in Minneapolis. Throughout his career Bob advocated for a thriving downtown and worked to strengthen the Twin Cities as a major league community through efforts to bring Superbowl XXVI to Minneapolis, keep the Timberwolves, and secure funding for a new outdoor Twins stadium. Bob served on several corporate boards including Northwestern National Bank, First American Funds, and Williams Sonoma. In 1992 Bob became CEO of Okabena, helping transform the Dayton family office into a nationally recognized leader in the then-nascent family office industry. Fiercely loyal to and enormously proud of the people and places he loved, Bob was committed to serving his community. He worked tirelessly on behalf of many non-profits including the Minneapolis Institute of Arts, Abbott Northwestern Hospital, the United Way, and Westminster Presbyterian Church. In addition, Bob served as a Trustee of the Blake School, Carlton College, and the University of Minnesota Foundation. In 1994 Bob founded and was later named Chair Emeritus of the Mentoring Partnership of Minnesota. Bob grew up in Wayzata, Minnesota and attended Blake, Eaglebrook, and Taft. While at Yale, Bob met his wife Joanie, then attending Skidmore College, on a blind date at the Dartmouth Winter Carnival. They were married in 1964 and had three boys. Bob enjoyed a number of hobbies, but none more so than golf. Beginning at Woodhill Country Club, his passion eventually extended east to Pine Valley and west to Cypress Point. He cofounded Spring Hill Golf Club and enjoyed playing in the U.S. Seniors. Bob will always be remembered for his warm heart, wonderful smile, infectious laughter, fantastic sense of humor, and tremendous spirit. He is survived by Joanie, his wife of 51 years, two brothers, three sons, and seven grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on February 18th at Westminster Presbyterian Church in Minneapolis. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAINES, DANIEL W.
Snippets: HAINES--Daniel W.,died January 11, 2016, age 78. Husband of Brynne, father of Gordon and Laurel, retired Professor of Engineering at Manhattan College and University of South Carolina. Greatly interested in music, substitutes for wood in musical instruments, history of New Jersey and of White Plains, NY. Consider donations to ALS Association - Greater NY Chapter. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  MISSETT, BARBARA THATCHER
Snippets: MISSETT--Barbara Thatcher. 77 years old, died peacefully at her home in West Palm Beach, FL, on January 20, 2016, surrounded by her family. Barbara was born on May 25, 1938 in Washington, DC to Herbert and Virginia Thatcher. Barbara graduated from Rosemont College in Philadelphia in 1960 where she obtained her bachelor's degree in English. In 1980, she co-founded VIART Corporation, an art management firm based in New York City. During its twenty-nine years of operation VIART provided art advisory services to over 100 Fortune 500 companies, financial institutions, law firms, and private individuals including the acquisition of American, European, African and Asian art in all mediums and all periods. Barbara was a member of the Everglades Club in Palm Beach, FL, The Meadow Club of Southampton, and the Bathing Corporation of Southampton. Barbara was preceded in death by her parents and younger brother Denis Thatcher. Surviving are her sons Joseph Missett IV and Stephen Missett, her grandson Santiago Missett, and her siblings Judy O'Donnell, Sheila Taylor, Stephen Thatcher, Joyce Thatcher and Herbert Thatcher II. Family and friends will be received on Thursday, January 28, 2016, from 4-6pm at Quattlebaum's Funeral Home, 6411 Parker Avenue, West Pam Beach, FL. Funeral Liturgy with Mass will be celebrated on Friday, January 29, 2016 at 11am at St. Edward's Catholic Church, 144 North County Road, Palm Beach. A reception in her honor at the Everglades Club will follow. Entombment will be at a later date at the convenience of the family. Memorial contributions may be made to a charity of your choice. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIPSON, LYNN BAIRD
Snippets: TIPSON--Lynn Baird, died on January 18 in Basking Ridge, New Jersey, at the age of 96. He was a retired business executive and a 1941 graduate of Princeton University. He also attended the Hill School and later received an MBA from NYU. Tipson served in the Army Air Corps during WWII and piloted eleven missions in a B-24 bomber until he was shot down, hospitalized, and sent to a German prison camp until liberation. He is survived by his wife of 74 years, Yvonne Gaston Tipson, four children, Lynn Jr. of Gettysburg, PA, Frederick of Moorestown, NJ, David of Glenside, PA, and Suzy Hall of Milford, OH, as well as eleven grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. Tipson was born in Westfield, NJ, where his father was Mayor in 1928-29, and resided there, except for the war years, until 1967. A funeral service will be held at 2pm on January 30 at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Basking Ridge with burial at Fairview Cemetery in Westfield. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHASIN, DR
Snippets: CHASIN--Dr. Mark, 73. On January 22, 2016 of Monroe, NJ, formerly of Manalapan, NJ. Pre-deceased by his wife Rena in 2003, now beloved husband to Reva SternChasin, amazing father to Jeff (Lisa), Larry (Andrea), and Marni (Lee) and adored grandfather of Shelby Chasin, Samara Chasin, Jake Garfinkle, Jack Chasin, William Chasin and Ryan Garfinkle. Mark grew up in Merrick, NY, graduated from Cornell University (B.S.) and Michigan State (PhD) and dedicated his life to developing new medicines and drug delivery methods. Our world is forever changed. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOTTNER, HAROLD
Snippets: BOTTNER--Harold, 88, of Tampa, FL formerly of Mamaroneck NY, died peacefully on January 15, 2016 after a long illness. He will be dearly missed by his beloved wife of 64 years, Dorothy, and their children, Jane, Andy, and Karen (Noel). He also leaves behind grandchildren Ben, Carolyn, Rosie and Emma. Harold will be remembered for his entrepreneurial spirit, having started HMB, Inc., a successful commercial sweater manufacturing business. His easy manner, dry wit and huge sense of humor, always accompanied by a big smile and a catchy tune, endeared him to all who knew him. Above all, Harold's honesty, kindness and generosity to others were perhaps his most lasting and loving legacy. A memorial service will be held in New York in the spring. Memorial donations can be made to Myasthenia Gravis Foundation of America, myasthenia.org or the charity of your choice. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN NESS, JOHN R.
Snippets: VAN NESS--John R.,known as "Jack," 70, of Ossining, NY, died peacefully with his wife at his side, January 19, 2016, at Rosary Hill Home after a short, courageous struggle with cancer. Jack was born in New York City, December 24, 1945, later preferring to tell folks he grew up on a small island off the coast of New Jersey. He studied at Stephens Institute of Technology and later earned his BS degree at Long Island University. Taking pre-med courses, he planned to follow in the footsteps of his deceased father, who was a NYC physician. All that changed when he took a summer job at Thomas J. Lipton company where he discovered the many faceted world of food science. His enthusiasm for food science never diminished. During his 20 year corporate career, he worked at a number of leading food companies including Best Food and Chesebrough Ponds. He gained experienced in every aspect of food processing, plant production, food safety, product development and federal filing regulations and practices. He was a trained taster who could recognize the individual spices in any combination presented, much to the surprise of restaurant chefs, a number of whom he advised and befriended over the years. As his career evolved, his focus centered on canned foods and he became one of New York's foremost food processing authorities. As such, he was a consultant who was recognized and worked with the United States Department of Agriculture and food processing. An avid sailor and scuba diver since his teens, Jack left the corporate world behind to sail from New York City to the Caribbean with a sailor buddy, exploring practically every island there during their six month cruise. Soon after his return, he formed his own company, Van Ness Food Technologies, which he operated while living aboard his 37 foot sailboat, "Cruzin," docked at City Island, NY. In 1992, he found "the love he had been waiting for" when he met Carolyn, another enthusiastic scuba diver. They married in 2001 aboard a yacht in New York harbor. Throughout their years together, they traveled the world, lured by possible dive adventures in the Caribbean, Bora Bora, Europe, Mexico and the Red Sea. One of Jack's favorite sea stories was about his transatlantic sail aboard a 42 foot sailboat from Bermuda to Malaga, Spain. "Sailing across the Pond is on every sailor's bucket list and I couldn't be happier or more satisfied because I got to do it," said Jack. Jack loved being with friends and sharing sea stories based on his experiences sailing with Carolyn up and down Long Island Sound, always on the lookout for a new raft up spot and seafood restaurant. For almost 30 years, Jack's consulting business worked with international clients in Canada, Greece, Israel and Korea. He was a featured lecturer at the First Food Safety Conference held in Bangalore, India, where he taught Indian food scientists how to implement Hazard Analysis Critical Control Point safety principles. Jack was a hands on expert who knew how to build and manage a food plant from its conception to the time the canned food product was on the pallet ready to go to market. He was known for his strong sense of integrity and absolute dedication to ensuring the safety of any food product under his production management. He was a charter member of IFTPS, participating in annual food conferences in the US and abroad. Jack was more than generous in passing along his wealth of knowledge to his many clients, interspersed with updates about his latest sailing or diving adventures. His genuine enjoyment of life was contagious. It enabled Jack to engage in lively conversations and make friends with young and old alike. With the wind at his back, he has charted his course, leaving us with memories of an unforgettable personality, sharp wit, brilliant mind and smile. Besides his beloved wife, Carolyn, he leaves behind a worldwide group of business associates and longtime friends, whose many lives he touched. At his request, his ashes are to be scattered over the area waters that gave him so much pleasure. There will be a celebration of Jack's life during the coming sailing season. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASHINGTON, BRYAN R.
Snippets: WASHINGTON--Bryan R.,professor of late 19th and 20th century American literature and cultural studies, and a man of considerable wit, humor, style, elegance, and charm, with a passion for the beauty and joy of some of life's most abundant and finest offerings, died of cancer on December 31, 2015. He was 57. The son of Dr. Joseph R. Washington, Jr. and the late Sophia M. Washington, Bryan was born in Boston, Massachusetts. During his formative years, Bryan lived in numerous towns and cities in Wisconsin, Virginia, California, and Pennsylvania, where he attended the University of Pennsylvania. At UPenn, Bryan was a Benjamin Franklin Scholar; he graduated with a Bachelor of Arts degree (with honors) in General Literature in 1980. UPenn served as a catalyst for Bryan's graduate studies, which led him to complete his Master's Degree in English Literature at Christ Church, Oxford University in 1982 through Penn's Thouron Award, a British-American exchange program. Bryan received his second Master's Degree in English and American Language at Harvard University in 1985. He was also a Minority Prize Fellow from 1982-1987. Bryan received his Ph.D. in English and American Literature and Language from Harvard in 1989. Bryan launched his academic career as an instructor at Lafayette College in 1987 and was promoted to Assistant Professor in 1989. He served as a Ford Foundation Postdoctoral Fellow at Princeton University from 1991-1992. In 1994, Bryan was promoted to Associate Professor with full tenure. Bryan's scholarly work includes the publication of a book entitled "The Politics of Exile: The Ideology in Henry James, F. Scott Fitzgerald, and James Baldwin" in 1995. The book was well received and widely cited. It is considered by many to be one of the first works to position James Baldwin alongside white canonical American authors. Bryan also authored several articles and reviews, including: "Paris Blues(s)," an essay on James Baldwin; and "WASP Mischief: Martha Stewart and the Racial Status Quo." He was in the process of writing two books before he became ill. Throughout his career at Lafayette, which spanned over a quarter century, Bryan received numerous honors, including the Student Government Superior Teaching Award in 1989-1990 and 1992-1993, which is rare for a professor to receive twice. Bryan delivered presentations at Lafayette on topics such as "Blacks in Popular Culture" and "Black Writers in the Classroom." In May 2014, Bryan delivered "The Last Lecture" to graduating seniors; this was, sadly, Bryan's last lecture and last professional engagement. The title of the lecture was: "In the Course of It All: Life is Words;" this honor, along with the two student government teaching awards, suggests how deeply he was loved by his students- his courses were always over-enrolled. Students described him as inspiring, exciting, funny, and extremely smart. Bryan once described his teaching in the following terms: "If asked what I aim to accomplish in the classroom, I would say I am trying for a good conversation. For in all my courses dialogue is a primary emphasis. I enjoy lecturing, but my class presentations, generally, are designed to provoke dissuasion. Whether just beginning college work or about to finish, undergraduates (I believe) have something to teach me." As a resident of Doylestown, PA, Bryan's life included jazz and the American songbook as a joy, metaphor and interpretation of his many passions: writing, literary criticism, food, art, "beautiful things," and, of course, Paris. During evenings, he would often play his stereo or the piano and sing to Carmen McRae, Shirley Horn or other great jazz artists, while duck was in the oven (or some other scrumptious dish) along with a plate of pate and wine at the ready, all for the evening's feast to be shared with Russell Clinton, his husband and life partner for 23 years, and, on many occasions, close friends. During his stay fighting cancer in various hospitals and healthcare facilities, Bryan often said that the rooms that he was in were "simply awful", and "he wants to go out in style" - of course his care and room assignments were, in fact, top notch! But, we all know Bryan and his desire to be surrounded by beauty. So, what did he do to dress up his room(s)? He buys a beautifully designed Simon Pearce lamp for only a brief stay. And, at Christmas, even though he was unable to eat solid foods or drink, he had a bounty of epicurean delights delivered from Dean and Deluca for him to taste and smell, including his favorite wines and brandy, all for the decadence of it all, and to celebrate his favorite holiday in abundance with his dear Russell. In addition to his husband Russell, Bryan is survived by his father, Joseph; father and mother-in-law, Bill and Ruthann; brother, David, and his partner, Christine; Russell's sister, Debbie and her children Calvin, Travis and Kiara and numerous other family members and friends. A celebration of Bryan's life will be held at 4pm, Friday, January 29, 2016 at Buckingham Friends School, 5684 York Road, Lahaska, PA. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Abramson Cancer Center of the University of Pennsylvania Annual Fund, Penn Medicine Development, 3535 Market Street, Suite 750, Philadelphia, PA 19104 or online at https://www.cancer. pennmedicine.org. Reed and Steinbach Funeral Home, Doylestown www.reedand steinbach.com 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, JUDSON GARRETT
Snippets: PARKER--Judson Garrett, Sr. Passed away peacefully at home on January 13th at the age of 94. He was the beloved husband of Faith Lamb-Parker, the father of Sarah Grace Parker, Nicole Gabriele Ives, Anthony Lewis Copeland-Parker, Gwendolyn McDougald Parker, and Judson Garrett Parker, Jr., the grandfather of twelve, and the great-grandfather of one. He is survived by them all, in addition to many cousins, nieces, nephews, and countless friends. Born in Washington, DC on March 25, 1921, his early years were spent in Tarboro and Durham, NC. He received a BS from the Philadelphia College of Pharmacy and moving to New York in 1959, a Master's Degree in Social Work Administration from Columbia University. Before retiring in 1988 from the City of New York Human Resources Administration, he served under Mayor Ed Koch as a top administrator. Although he lived in many places and traveled the world, he was a New Yorker at heart. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCAFFREY, SUSAN MARY
Snippets: McCAFFREY--Susan Mary, age 59, a resident of the PGA National Golf Community, Palm Beach Gardens, and a former resident of Riverdale, New York, passed away on Friday, January 8, 2016. She is a daughter of the late Honorable Francis J. McCaffrey, Sr. and Irene McCaffrey. Susan was a graduate of the University of Notre Dame, Maryland, and worked in the financial business for over 25 years. She was Research Coordinator for the Institutional Trading Desk at E.F. Hutton; Head Equity Trader at New York Life; Equity Trader at Greenwich Street Advisors; Investment Advisor with Paine Webber, Inc., and most recently, Research Technical Salesperson with Lowery Research Corporation. Susan was a member of the PGA Member's Club where she was an enthusiastic croquet player. She was also a member of the Shelter Island Yacht Club and the Gardiners Bay Golf Club, both in New York. Susan enjoyed the arts and was a talented and avid artist. Susan is survived by her sister, Joan Patton of Boston, MA; two brothers, Francis J. McCaffrey, Jr. of Floral Park, New York and David McCaffrey, Sr. of Cambridge, MA; and four nephews, Joseph Patton, III, Luke Patton, Francis McCaffrey, and David McCaffrey, Jr. If you wish, donations can be made in Susan's name to Hospice of Palm Beach County Foundation: C.W. Gerstenberg Hospice, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL 33407. A memorial service is planned in the spring for family and friends. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, NORMA
Snippets: LEVY--Norma. The Board, Administration and Staff of the Gurwin Jewish Nursing & Rehabilitation Center express their heartfelt sympathy at the passing of Norma, beloved wife of our Chairman Emeritus, Al Levy. Norma was a passionate and devoted advocate for the founding and growth of our Center. She will long be remembered for her commitment to those we serve. We extend sincere condolences to Al and the entire family. Lawrence Simon, Chairman Bert E. Brodsky, President Herbert Friedman, EVP/CEO 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  REED, HOWARD
Snippets: REED--Howard, 90, of Wellington, Florida, died peacefully with his family in Dresher, Pennsylvania on January 21, 2016. Howard was a devoted and loving husband for 66 years to his beautiful wife, Dolores, who died just 23 days before, and a loving father to his children, Janet and Rob, their spouses Dan and Julie, and his grandchildren, Lindsay, Ben, and Michael. Howard was born in 1925 in Brooklyn, NY. At 17, he became a radio broadcaster for WBAX and later at WNYC, where at 19, he broadcast General Eisenhower's triumphant ticker-tape parade down 5th Avenue. When he enlisted in the Army/Air Force, he became a broadcaster for Armed Forces Radio in Berlin. Howard entered the publishing field in his 20's, and was the publisher for more than 50 magazines in a career that spanned over 50 years in New York and Stamford in fields as diverse as electronics, entertainment, floor covering, and education. A gifted speaker and storyteller, after his retirement from publishing, Howard was a regular lecturer for Palm Beach College on politics, economics, and the media. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, January 26th at 11:00am at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 630 Amsterdam Avenue, in Manhattan. Following the services, Howard will be buried next to Dolores at the Beth David Cemetery, 300 Elmont Road, Elmont, NY. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAYTON, ROBERT
Snippets: DAYTON--Robert. Robert Dayton, whose career spanned decades in support of a vibrant downtown Minneapolis, MN, died on January 17th. He was 73 years old. A great-grandson of the founder of Daytons, Bob carried on the family retail and community-oriented legacy. After graduating from Yale in 1964, Bob joined what was to become Dayton Hudson and then Target, rising to become General Merchandise Manager and then Vice President of Stores. While with Daytons, Bob attended the Program for Management Development at Harvard Business School. A merchandiser at heart, Bob became recognized for his deftness in identifying and supporting designers such as Calvin Klein and Ralph Lauren early in their careers. In 1977 Bob left Daytons and purchased Harold, an upscale specialty store for women. Working together with his wife Joanie, Bob restored its iconic status as a Minneapolis retail institution. In 1984 Bob spearheaded the development of The Conservatory, the first enclosed shopping complex in Minneapolis. Throughout his career Bob advocated for a thriving downtown and worked to strengthen the Twin Cities as a major league community through efforts to bring Superbowl XXVI to Minneapolis, keep the Timberwolves, and secure funding for a new outdoor Twins stadium. Bob served on several corporate boards including Northwestern National Bank, First American Funds, and Williams Sonoma. In 1992 Bob became CEO of Okabena, helping transform the Dayton family office into a nationally recognized leader in the then-nascent family office industry. Fiercely loyal to and enormously proud of the people and places he loved, Bob was committed to serving his community. He worked tirelessly on behalf of many non-profits including the Minneapolis Institute of Arts, Abbott Northwestern Hospital, the United Way, and Westminster Presbyterian Church. In addition, Bob served as a Trustee of the Blake School, Carlton College, and the University of Minnesota Foundation. In 1994 Bob founded and was later named Chair Emeritus of the Mentoring Partnership of Minnesota. Bob grew up in Wayzata, Minnesota and attended Blake, Eaglebrook, and Taft. While at Yale, Bob met his wife Joanie, then attending Skidmore College, on a blind date at the Dartmouth Winter Carnival. They were married in 1964 and had three boys. Bob enjoyed a number of hobbies, but none more so than golf. Beginning at Woodhill Country Club, his passion eventually extended east to Pine Valley and west to Cypress Point. He cofounded Spring Hill Golf Club and enjoyed playing in the U.S. Seniors. Bob will always be remembered for his warm heart, wonderful smile, infectious laughter, fantastic sense of humor, and tremendous spirit. He is survived by Joanie, his wife of 51 years, two brothers, three sons, and seven grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on February 18th at Westminster Presbyterian Church in Minneapolis. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIRO, EMIL
Snippets: SPIRO--Emil, passed away peacefully, surrounded by family on January 14, 2016 at his home in Santa Fe, New Mexico at the age of 88. Born in Germany, he escaped the Holocaust alone as a boy of 11, spending the years of World War II as a refugee in Switzerland. He came to New York City in 1947 as the sole survivor of his family, and established a successful career in the insurance industry. He is survived by his wife Jaffa, daughter Saguna (Robert), sons Lenny and David and granddaughter Dhyana. Donations in his memory can be made to the United Jewish Appeal or City Harvest. 1/3

Services will be held at Larchmont Temple on Monday, January 25 at 10am. Interment at Mt. Hope Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVITT, NELSON
Snippets: LEVITT--Nelson, was born in the Bronx in 1921. He fought as an Army Officer in WWII, was awarded a purple heart, served on the Jewish veterans board, owned a furniture business and dedicated his entire life to helping fight for human rights. Nelson had a passion for music and was a fine amateur pianist. He was also an avid runner who completed several New York City marathons through his 60's. Nelson had a devoted wife Yetta of 74 years, daughter Ronnie, son Ricky (deceased), son-in-law Deryl (deceased), and two grandchildren, Kyia, and Esu. He was deeply beloved by all who had the pleasure to know him. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVANS, JOHN C

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMONT, AUSTIN
Snippets: LAMONT--Austin. Austin Lamont, peacefully on January 16, age 79, of Belmont, MA and formerly of Santa Fe, NM, brother of Lavinia Rosenthal, Nicholas Lamont, and Nancy Sullivan; father of Carrie, Helen, Owen and Nathan Lamont; eight grandchildren and many nieces, nephews and cousins. Austin Lamont was born in Baltimore and graduated from Oberlin College in 1960 and from Boston University in 1962. He worked in documentary film production in the Boston area until he left to teach at Ohio University from 1967-69; he produced Film Comment magazine from 1968-73, co-founded Boston Film/Video Foundation in 1971 and co-produced "Conversations with Willard Van Dyke" in 1981. He moved to Santa Fe, New Mexico in 1984 where he became an expert in Western art photography, in which capacity he worked with the Andrew Smith Gallery from 1994-2004. He returned to the Boston area in 2006 to be closer to his extended family. A memorial service is planned for early in June. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIDENFELD, LORD GEORGE
Snippets: WEIDENFELD--Lord George. The World Jewish Congress mourns the passing of a giant, a committed philanthropist, world-renowned publisher of authors including Vladimir Nabokov, articulate advocate of the Jewish people and fearless defender of the Jewish State of Israel. George Weidenfeld grew up in Vienna and fled Austria after the Nazi takeover in 1938. Because he was saved by a Christian family, George never forgot that his life was spared by Christians and just last year, he created a foundation to rescue thousands of persecuted Christians in the Middle East. This man never forgot his debts and always repaid them. As an immigrant during World War II, George became an integral part of the BBC World Service and broadcast reports in several languages. In 1969, Queen Elizabeth acknowledged Britain's appreciation and knighted him, followed by a life peerage in the House of Lords in 1976. Last April, at the age of 95, Lord Weidenfeld was awarded the WJC's Theodor Herzl Award in London and became an honorary vice-president of the World Jewish Congress. There are few people in the entire world who have spoken out with more courage against injustice. Our dear friend George was one. He was one of the most inspiring and accomplished figures of the 20th and 21st centuries. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Annabelle, daughter Laura, grandchildren and great grandchildren. We will miss him deeply. World Jewish Congress President Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman of the Governing Board David de Rothschild, Treasurer Chella Safra 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNWELL, JOHN
Snippets: BARNWELL--John, on January 21, 2016. Beloved son of the late Thomas and Marie. Loving brother of Marie (Anthony), Patricia (the late Walter), Peter (Cathy), Robert (Colleen), William (Lori), James (Rose) and Michael and the late Thomas, Ann, Timothy and Stephen. Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, JACOB
Snippets: FEINBERG--Jacob. Bone Marrow Registry co-Founder Jacob Feinberg dies at 87. The Feinberg Family and the Gift of Life Bone Marrow Foundation mourn the loss of the organization's co-founder, Jacob Feinberg. A CPA with Brout and Company and BDO, Jack later became a pioneer with his wife Arlene advancing the cause of bone marrow donor registration throughout the United States and abroad for the benefit of patients battling blood cancer. His efforts made possible bone marrow transplants for thousands of patients in need. The world is a better place thanks to Jack, a true hero, and his memory will live on through the lives he and Arlene saved together. He was the loving father of Jay, Steven, Edward of blessed memory and daughter-in-law Sheryl; loving grandfather of Shauna, Michelle and Skylar; brother of Robert and sister-in-law of Marty. Jack will be missed by the entire Gift of Life organization that he and Arlene created, and his countless friends and loving family. Contributions in Jack's memory may be made at www.giftoflife.org. 1/3
