Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRZECHFFA, LESZEK
Snippets: BRZECHFFA--Leszek, died suddenly on January 14, 2016. He is survived by his beloved wife of 56 years, Magdalena; his son, Peter (Lisa), his granddaughter, Camille; and his brother, Jerzy Brzechffa. As a five year old in 1940, he was deported by Russia to the Steppes of Kazakhstan from Lwov, Poland, with his mother, Bronislawa, grandmother, and one year old brother. They remained there for six years. His father, Roger, had been one of the 14,000 Polish army officers shot and buried in the Katyn massacre in the same year. He returned to Poland after the war with his family. He graduated with a Master's degree in chemistry from the Gdansk Polytechnic Institute. He met and married Magdalena, also a chemist in 1958. In July 1967, he defected from Poland with his wife and son and successfully immigrated to America within four months. In December 1967, he found a permanent position as a research scientist at Sandoz Pharmaceuticals and retired in 1995. He was a very caring, loving husband, father and grandfather. He loved life, always smiled, was extremely positive and friendly to all he met. He was passionate about sailing, tennis, opera and traveling around the world with his lovely wife. A Memorial Mass will be held on Saturday, February 6, 2016 at 11am, at Our Lady of Mercy Church, Whippany Rd., Whippany, NJ. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUNOZ, MICHAEL HENRY, M.D.
Snippets: MUNOZ--Michael Henry, M.D.,64, passed away in the early morning hours of Tuesday, January 19, at his home in Woodcliff Lake, New Jersey. He was battling a rare blood disorder known as amyloidosis. Michael was born on February 14, 1951 at Fitkin Memorial Hospital in Neptune, New Jersey. He grew up in Colts Neck, New Jersey, where he helped his family run the Colts Neck General Store. He graduated from Peddie School, Syracuse University, and received his medical degree and Masters of Public Health from Harvard Medical School. He was a diplomat of the American Board of Ophthalmology, a Diplomat of the National Board of Medical Examiners, and a Fellow of The Academy of Ophthalmology. He was a Lieutenant in the United States Public Health Service. Michael had a large collection of comic books dating back to his childhood. He also was an avid collector of antique cars and frequently attended car shows. He enjoyed jazz, astronomy, and old war movies. He was predeceased by his parents, William and Frances Munoz, and his older brother, Eric Munoz, M.D. He is survived by his wife, Andrea Joy Munoz, their children, Daniel, Rachel, and William, his sister Wendy Lerrick, and numerous nieces, nephews, and cousins. Donations can be made to The Valley Chabad Friendship Circle of Woodcliff Lake, NJ or The Amyloidosis Foundation. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALRATH, DALE ROBERT
Snippets: WALRATH--Dale Robert, of Manhattan, NY and formerly Wilton, CT, died on December 31, 2015 at home, at the age of 94. He was a World War II veteran, Mad Man, and devoted husband and father, who succumbed to Alzheimer's after a 12-year dignified struggle. An exemplar of the Greatest Generation, he was raised on a farm in Ohio, graduated from Ohio Wesleyan on scholarship, enlisted in the Army in 1943, and fought on the Western Front throughout Germany, receiving the Silver Star, Bronze Star and Purple Heart before his honorable discharge in 1945. He moved to Connecticut in 1956, embarking on a 33-year career on the creative side with J. Walter Thompson in Manhattan. During his tenure at Thompson he helped develop the "Built Ford Tough" campaign and pioneered broadcast shoots in California. He was the most selfless of men, active in the community post-retirement, while caring for an ailing spouse for years. Survivors include his son Christopher Bret and daughter Rosalind Anne, both of Manhattan, and three grandchildren, Margot, Victoria and Amanda. His courage, dignity, sacrifice for others, vitality, kindness, and extraordinary decency are treasured by all who knew him. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLINGER, HARVEY
Snippets: MILLINGER--Harvey, 99, passed away peacefully at home, in the company of his family, on January 25, 2016. Loving husband of Sylva Dee, and father of Bruce (Xiao-Fang) and Donald (Gary Clinton). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Temple Sinai of Roslyn, Roslyn Heights, NY. He was a kind and gentle man, and family and friends were exceptionally fortunate to have shared his life for so many years. He will be greatly missed. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Memorials  JOHNSON, J. ROBERT. AGE 79, DIED JANUARY 14, 2016, OF COMPLICATIONS OF PARKINSON'S DISEASE IN CHARLOTTE, NC. BORN AND RAISED IN NEW YORK CITY, BOB WAS A GRADUATE OF MANHATTAN'S STUYVESANT HIGH SCHOOL AND WENT ON TO ATTEND THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA WHERE HE WAS A MEMBER OF THE SIGMA CHI FRATERNITY AND THE SPHINX SENIOR SOCIETY, THE OLDEST AND MOST PRESTIGIOUS HONOR SOCIETY OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA. UPON HIS GRADUATION FROM PENN IN 1958, HE WENT ON TO EARN HIS JURIS DOCTORATE DEGREE FROM NEW YORK UNIVERSITY'S SCHOOL OF LAW AND WAS A CAPTAIN IN THE UNITED STATES COAST GUARD. MR. JOHNSON PRACTICED LAW IN NEW YORK CITY BEFORE FINDING HIS TRUE CALLING ON WALL STREET. MR. JOHNSON'S CAREER BEGAN AT KUHN LOEB WHICH LATER MERGED WITH LEHMAN BROTHERS IN 1977. HE WAS A PARTNER AT LEHMAN BROTHERS WHICH WAS THE PINNACLE OF HIS WORK LIFE. HE ABSOLUTELY LOVED THE CAMARADERIE OF HIS LEHMAN PARTNERS AND ASSOCIATES AND RETIRED SHORTLY AFTER THE "GREAT HOUSE OF LEHMAN" MERGED WITH SHEARSON
Snippets: JOHNSON--J. Robert. Age 79, died January 14, 2016, of complications of Parkinson's Disease in Charlotte, NC. Born and raised in New York City, Bob was a graduate of Manhattan's Stuyvesant High School and went on to attend the University of Pennsylvania where he was a member of the Sigma Chi Fraternity and the Sphinx Senior Society, the oldest and most prestigious honor society of the University of Pennsylvania. Upon his graduation from Penn in 1958, he went on to earn his Juris Doctorate degree from New York University's School of Law and was a captain in the United States Coast Guard. Mr. Johnson practiced law in New York City before finding his true calling on Wall Street. Mr. Johnson's career began at Kuhn Loeb which later merged with Lehman Brothers in 1977. He was a partner at Lehman Brothers which was the pinnacle of his work life. He absolutely loved the camaraderie of his Lehman partners and associates and retired shortly after the "Great House of Lehman" merged with Shearsonmerican Express in 1984. In the ensuing years he pursued business ventures, was active in various charities and loved following his grandchildren's sporting adventures. A lifelong New Yorker, Bob moved to Charlotte, NC to be closer to his two daughters and his grandchildren. He is survived by his son Hal Johnson of Mill Valley, CA and Telluride, CO, his daughters, Brooks Johnson and Jennifer Miller of Charlotte, NC and his eight grandchildren: Reilly and Summer Johnson, Chase and Dylan Johnson, Mitchell Morrow and Cole, Cade and Cameron Miller. He is also survived by his sister Carole Bayer of Tucson, AZ and his many relatives in Gothenburg, Sweden. No services are planned but the family will come together to celebrate his life this summer per his request. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, ROBERT K.
Snippets: GINSBERG--Robert K.,died peacefully on January 26, 2016 at age 91. He was a devoted and beloved husband, father and grandfather and an accomplished professional engineer. Born May 23, 1924 in New York City to Bill and Tania Ginsberg, he was educated at Lincoln School and Yale University and served as a Lieutenant (jg) in the United States Navy during World War II, seeing extensive combat in the Pacific. He was a lifelong New Yorker who practiced engineering as principal in the firm William Ginsberg Associates, and he was for more than five decades a national leader in the design and construction of newspaper production facilities. He is survived by his beloved wife of 37 years, Nellie Wilson. He was predeceased by his first wife, Helen (1926-71) and is survived by their three children, Nina (Charles Smith) of Richmond, CA, William (Ellen Kelly) of New Haven, CT and John (Kathleen) of New York City. He is also survived by his grandchildren (Alex Smith, Susan Smith Emberley, Emily Ginsberg Dellisant, Julian Ginsberg, Connor Ginsberg, and Nina Ginsberg) and many other dear family members. A superb whistler, he lived with song in his heart and on his lips throughout his nine decades of loves and laughs and friends and joys. Gentle, kind and loving, he will be forever missed. A memorial service will be announced. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  PELL, BEATRICE LYNETTE (NEE HARBER)
Snippets: PELL--Beatrice Lynette (nee Harber), 95, of Somers, NY, died peacefully in her sleep on January 28, 2016. She is survived by Leonard Pell, her devoted husband of 74 years, dear sister Ruth Drucker (Bernard Gross) of Fort Lee, NJ, beloved children JoAnn Pearlman (Neil) of Somers, NY, Diane Maude Brossoie of Montross, Virginia, and Owen Pell (Pearl) of New York City, and cherished grandchildren and great-grandchildren Seth Pearlman (Jamie), Melissa Miller (Jonathan), James Brossoie, Jason Harris, Nathan Pell, Adam Pell, and Samantha Pearlman, Michelle Pearlman, Maxwell Miller, David Miller, and Alaric Puebla. Bea's energy, intelligence, humor and zest for life were apparent to all who knew her. Her family and friends will miss her deeply, and remember her with great love and affection. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY on Sunday, January 31, 2016 at 10:00am. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, ANNETTE
Snippets: KAUFMAN--Annette. A passion for music set Annette Kaufman on a fairy-tale course from North Dakota to a conservatory in NYC where she met and fell in love with Louis Kaufman, married him at the age of 18-and seldom left his side for the next 62 years. Mr. Kaufman, a Hollywood legend, played principal violin in over 500 films including Casablanca and Gone with the Wind. In his 2003 memoir, A Fiddler's Tale, he wrote that upon his proposal of marriage, Annette replied that she would like to be his accompanist. For the next 62 years, she was. They lived in Los Angeles, CA in a house designed for them by Lloyd Wright where, at the age of 101, Mrs. Kaufman died peacefully on January 25, 2016. The Kaufmans were well known in the Los Angeles pre-and post-war cultural scene. They were the first collectors of Milton Avery and, being softhearted and generous, helped many struggling painters during Depression-era America. In Brussels after the war, they were shown an obscure piece of music by Vivaldi, The Four Seasons; Mr. Kaufman became the first person to record it. A generous benefactor to many cultural institutions including the Library of Congress, the National Portrait Gallery and the Portland Art Museum, Annette was a vivid raconteur of a time in Europe and Los Angeles that, while largely faded from memory, lived on in her ebullient recounting of it. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Memorials  VERBY, STANLEY M

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANBER, MALCOLM MANUEL
Snippets: MANBER--Malcolm Manuel, 89, passed away on January 23, 2016 in New York City. He was born on September 10, 1926 in Chelsea, MA to Gustave and Ida Manber and grew up in New York City. Beloved father of Susan and David Manber, grandfather of Max and Sarina Abraham and brother of Edna Dressner, Malcolm was married for 49 years to Vivienne Marianne Schulman and was a resident of New York City and Rhinebeck, NY. He served as an Army radio operator during World War II and later attended the Columbia Missouri School of Journalism. He enjoyed a renowned career as a science writer at the Bayonne Times, The Newark Evening News, Medical World News and Physicians Weekly. Among many notable articles, Mr. Manber published one of the earliest accounts of the world's first artificial heart transplant performed by Dr. Robert Jarvik. Mr. Manber and his wife took great pleasure in being founding members of the Beekman Arms Antique Market in Rhinebeck where their business, Victorian Cupboard, specialized in English pottery for more than 35 years. Special thanks to the hospice team at NYU Langone for making his last days with family and friends peaceful and serene. Donations in Mr. Manber's name may be made to the American Cancer Society. May his memory be a blessing. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, BERNARD
Snippets: LEVY--Bernard, passed away peacefully at his home in Palm Beach, Florida at the age of 98. He was born in New York City on February 10, 1917 and attended New York University. Bernard was predeceased by his wife of 69 years, Laura Redfield Levy, who shared a love of life, travel, and dogs. He is survived by his sons Dean (Janice), Jonathan (Carol), and daughter Marcia Roesch (Geoffrey), and his seven grandchildren and six greatgrandchildren). Bernard was one of the most prominent dealers in early American furniture, first as a partner in the firm of Ginsburg & Levy, founded in 1901, and then from 1973 until his death with the firm Bernard & S. Dean Levy, Inc., of New York. Over the nearly 70 years as an active dealer, he was able to acquire and place a number of the most recognizable pieces in both private and public collections. He was a friend and advisor to many of the great early collectors, many of whose gifts now form the core of major museum collections. These include The Metropolitan Museum of Art, The Bayou Bend Collection, The Winterthur Museum and Historic Deerfield among many other institutions. He was always eager to share his knowledge and enthusiasm with collectors, curators, other dealers and especially his family. His eye for the very finest in Americana will be missed. Bernard was an avid and accomplished tennis player winning many local and regional tournaments. Into his seventies he remained active in competitive tennis attaining a national ranking. Anyone who played with or against him can attest to a strong will and a wicked drop shot. Also, he always had a good joke to tell and enjoyed making others laugh. He will be greatly missed. A celebration of his life will be held at a later date. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, LEWIS G.
Snippets: SCHWARTZ--Lewis G.,65, died Friday, January 29th at Stamford Hospital. Son of the late Edward Schwartz and Davida Schatz Edelson, Lew grew up in Meriden and West Hartford, Connecticut. He graduated from the Kingswood School (1968), Yale College (1972), and Cornell Law School. Lew began his legal career as an Assistant District Attorney in Manhattan, later becoming a litigator at Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. After returning to Connecticut, Lew became a partner specializing in employment law and litigation at Schatz & Schatz, Ribicoff & Kotkin, a firm started by his maternal grandfather that later merged with Shipman & Goodwin. In 2001, Lew joined Gartner, serving as Senior Vice President, General Counsel, Corporate Secretary, and Chief Compliance Officer, where he just celebrated his 15th year. Despite his myriad academic and professional accomplishments, Lew enjoyed no job more than his years as a coach and president of the North Stamford Little League. Lew's enthusiasm and love for life was boundless. He was an avid cyclist, wine enthusiast, and lifelong Yankee fan and 30-year season ticket holder. Lew's travels brought him to dozens of countries, and his network of friends and colleagues stretches around the world. Lew's most extraordinary role was as husband to Marjorie and father to sons Ethan and Alex, all of whom survive him and cherish his memory. The burial was private. For those wishing to honor him, please consider a donation to Stamford Hospital, sharecancersupport.org, or a charity of your choice. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Memorials  MAZZEO, ALBERTO DANIEL DIED PEACEFULLY AT CALVARY HOSPITAL IN THE BRONX ON JANUARY 29, 2016 AFTER A YEAR, LONG ILLNESS. HE HAD THE CONSTANT AND LOVING SUPPORT OF HIS SPOUSE MITCH MONDELLO, NEIGHBORS, FRIENDS, UN COLLEAGUES AND FAMILY IN ARGENTINA AND ITALY. ALBERTO'S GENEROSITY OF SPIRIT, COURAGE AND OPTIMISM WAS EXEMPLIFIED BY HIS ANSWER WHENEVER ANYONE ASKED HIM HOW HE WAS: "I'M OK, I'M GETTING BETTER." AND OF COURSE BY HIS EXUBERANT LAUGHTER AND LOVE OF MALBEC. IN ACCORDANCE WITH ALBERTO'S WISHES, HIS ASHES WILL BE SCATTERED IN THE HUDSON RIVER AND THE RIO DE LA PLATA, THE RIVERS FLOWING THROUGH THE TWO CITIES THAT HE CONSIDERED HOME. A MEMORIAL MASS AND INTERMENT WILL TAKE PLACE IN ZACCANOPOLI, HIS ANCESTRAL HOME IN CALABRIA. 1
Snippets: MAZZEO--Alberto Daniel Died peacefully at Calvary Hospital in The Bronx on January 29, 2016 after a year-long illness. He had the constant and loving support of his spouse Mitch Mondello, neighbors, friends, UN colleagues and family in Argentina and Italy. Alberto's generosity of spirit, courage and optimism was exemplified by his answer whenever anyone asked him how he was: "I'm OK, I'm getting better." And of course by his exuberant laughter and love of Malbec. In accordance with Alberto's wishes, his ashes will be scattered in the Hudson River and the Rio de la Plata, the rivers flowing through the two cities that he considered home. A memorial Mass and Interment will take place in Zaccanopoli, his ancestral home in Calabria. 1

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, KENNETH
Snippets: MANDEL--Kenneth, 76, of Briarcliff Manor, NY, passed away January 26, 2016 after a courageous battle with cancer. Ken was a loving husband to his wife of 52 years, Carole Leshne Mandel, and a devoted father to his daughters Wendy, Laura, and Jodi, and their spouses Yale, Jeff, and Kenny. He loved and adored his eight grandchildren, Josh, Arielle, Taylor, Jordan, Ethan, Emma, Matthew, and Maya. He is also survived by his mother, Olga, to whom he was a devoted son, and by his brother, Richard. He graduated from New Rochelle High School and went on to study at Cornell University and New York University. Ken held an array of sales positions that showcased his people skills, intellect and wit, culminating in the successful leadership of Mandel Investments until his retirement in 2013. He loved fishing and boating with his grandchildren, playing golf, spending time with his friends, and getting to know people. His greatest love was his family, especially spending family vacations at the Jersey Shore and Hamptons. Ken had a wonderful sense of humor, a gift for storytelling, and he left a lasting impression on those he met. He will be greatly missed. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACKWELL KONOWITCH, JUDITH
Snippets: BLACKWELL KONOWITCH --Judith, 59, of Irvington, NY. Grew up in Manhasset, Long Island. She work diligently to improve education. Survived by her beloved husband and best friend Paul Konowitch, her loving children Jeffrey and Margo Konowitch, her loving mother Marie Blackwell Deppen and devoted sister Nancy Semels (Daniel). Visiting Sunday (today) 5-7pm Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave., Dobbs Ferry, NY. Service Monday 7:00pm Temple Beth Shalom, 740 N. Broadway, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. Memorials to the Judith Blackwell Konowitch Scholarship Award, Checks should be made to the Dobbs Ferry Schools Foundation, JBK Award, DFSF Treasurer, 505 Broadway, Dobbs Ferry, NY 10522. 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, HOWARD
Snippets: SMITH--Howard. NYU Lutheran's board and staff are deeply saddened by the passing of chair emeritus Howard Smith. As chairman of Lutheran Medical Center and Augustana Center from 1966 until 2004, Smith, who died Thursday at age 85, left an indelible legacy on southwest Brooklyn. With his friend New York City Mayor John Lindsay and the American Lutheran Church, Mr. Smith brokered the 1977 expansion and relocation of Lutheran Medical Center from 4th Avenue and 46th Street to its present location, a former warehouse at 55th Street and 2nd Avenue in Sunset Park. He facilitated the creation of the Sunset Park Family Health Center, now called NYU Lutheran Family Health Centers, the second largest federally qualified health center network in the nation. He created a lasting financial foundation for Lutheran through Health Plus, an innovative government-sponsored insurance program for low-income residents. Lutheran's sale of Health Plus to Amerigroup in 2011 created an endowment that continues to help modernize the health system. Mr. Smith, a lifelong Brooklyn resident, was chairman emeritus of the United Hospital Fund, former president of the Brooklyn Public Library Board of Trustees, and past vice president and director of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce. Mr. Smith received a bachelor's in chemical engineering from Princeton University and served in the U.S. Army. He served 40 years as president of Virginia Dare Extract Company, which was founded by his grandfather Bernard, and was a former director of Dime Savings Bank of New York before it merged with Washington Mutual in 2002. He is predeceased by his wife, Elsie, and survived by his three children, Howard Jr., Jean, and Lilla, and grandchildren. NYU Lutheran mourns as we celebrate Mr. Smith's life and legacy. A wake will be held at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave., Brooklyn, on Tuesday, February 2, at 4-8pm. Services will be held at the Lutheran Church of the Good Shepherd, 7420 4th Ave., Brooklyn, on Wednesday, February 3, at 10 am. 1/3

Snippets: SAWITSKY--Arthur, MD. 1/31/1916 - 5/28/2009. Happy 100th Birthday! Extraordinary father, husband, friend, physician. We wish you were here to celebrate with us. We love and miss you every day and carry you in our hearts. Love, B, KHALEM 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, HOWARD
Snippets: SMITH--Howard. The board and staff of United Hospital Fund are deeply saddened by the death of our chairman emeritus, a health care visionary and dedicated civic and business leader. Over six decades, Howard passionately championed innovations in hospital care and community health that are now understood broadly as essential to health reform. His ability to see opportunity and make important and timely decisions, was anchored by his deep belief in the imperative of community service. UHF benefited enormously from his skillful and steadfast leadership as our wise and caring chairman for 17 years and almost 40 years of active engagement on our board. He leaves an enduring legacy in health care and an indelible mark on his beloved Brooklyn and UHF. We extend our deepest sympathies to his children and remember with affection his wife, Rev. Elsie Smith, who shared and extended his commitment and dedication. J. Barclay Collins II Chairman James R. Tallon, Jr. President 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, HON. FRANCIS T.
Snippets: MURPHY--Hon. Francis T.,died peacefully on January 27, 2016 at the age of 88 surrounded by his family. He was married to his beloved Sheila Theresa for 55 wonderful years before her death on September 28, 2014. He is survived by their five children, Timothy F. Murphy and his wife, Pamela; Eileen and her husband, Jeffrey Forsyth; Kathleen and her husband, Lance Scott; Sheila and her husband, Michael Sproule; Annemarie and her husband, Kevin Casey; and his sister Irene McInerney. He was a loving grandfather to Casey, Kaitlyn, Timothy, Matthew, Sean, Patrick, Michael, Brendan, Megan and Liam. After being honorably discharged from the U.S. Navy after World War II, he graduated from Fordham University and New York Law School. A member of the New York judiciary for 40 years, he served 15 years as a trial judge and 25 years as a Justice of the Appellate Division First Department, with the last 20 years as the Court's Presiding Justice. When he left the Court, he joined the New York law firm of Kelley, Drye and Warren as Of Counsel. Throughout his career Judge Murphy was an ardent supporter of providing full legal services and justice to the underprivileged and incarcerated. A gracious man with a generous heart and strong religious beliefs, he took counsel only from his own conscience. The loves of Tim's life were his wife, Sheila, his family, his friends and his life in the law. Friends may call on Sunday, January, 31 from 2 to 4pm and 6 to 8pm at Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY. Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated at Our Lady of Perpetual Help, 575 Fowler Avenue, Pelham Manor, NY on Monday, February 1 at 10am. Interment at St. Raymond's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Judge Murphy's name to The Province of St. Mary (for the work of the Capuchin Franciscan Friars) at 210 West 31st Street, New York, NY 10001 or donate online at: www.capuchin.org 1/3

Mains: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANEY, CHRISTINA B
Snippets: LANEY--Christina B. Christina Bertrand Laney, age 83, of New York City died January 21, 2016. A classic "New Yorker," in every sense of the word, Christina was a native of the Upper West Side for over 50 years. She was an avid Riverside Park gardener, a frequent face at Fairway, and knew every sidewalk crack and crevasse of the Upper West Side. The daughter of Vera Federoff, of Ryazan, Russia, and Bertrand J. Laney, of New York City, Christina was born in Hankow, China, on December 28, 1932, her family fleeing China in 1940, shortly after the Japanese offensive. A true explorer, Christina traveled the world with her family, attending schools in China, Panama, El Salvador, and finally, at the University of Texas, and at New York University. It was in 1953, that Christina, in her own words, "found her Nirvana"-New York City. For over 30 years, she was involved in the entertainment industry, acting in small movie and television roles, then working behind the scenes in public relations, advertising, and film production. At United Artists, Christina was the Assistant to the Director of Special Projects for six years. She also worked for the Writer's Guild. Christina was a Vice President of Women of the Motion Picture Industry, and won their Dottie Reeves Humanitarian Award for Community Service. Christina's hobbies were manifold. Her diminutive size and powerhouse personality made her a natural spelunker. She was a member of the National Speleological Society for many years. A talented artist and poet in her own right, Christina supported Women in Motion Pictures, and the Curtain Club. She championed dozens of causes including: The Humane Society, The New York Historical Society, Sierra Club, The Wilderness Society, World Wildlife Fund, The Nature Conservancy, and the ASPCA. Christina was a lifelong volunteer for groups such as Channel 13, The Girl Scout Council of Greater New York, and, for 50 years, the Riverside Park Conservancy, where she was honored for her volunteer contribution in her beloved garden on 78th Street and Riverside Drive. Before there was Google, there was Christina. A voracious reader and a fount of knowledge about a myriad of subjects, especially New York City, family and friends could always rely on Christina for an irrefutable answer. Into her 80s, Christina was a brilliant, plucky, feisty spitfire who continued to stimulate her mind by regular attendance at jazz concerts, museums, art galleries, and theater. She was a devoted sister, aunt, cousin, and friend-a tiny woman with a huge spirit, who will be deeply missed. Christina is survived by her older sister, Kera Toline Rogers of Charleston, SC; niece Catherine Anna Toline, husband Leo Lentsch; nephews, John Colin Toline, and son John, Mark Anderson Toline, wife Ann, and son North, and Paul Alexander Toline; and cousins, Barbara Laney Swenson of Hanover, New Hampshire, Ainslie Drummond of Florida, and Irene Morgan Kay of Australia. Christina's ashes will be interred in Moline, Illinois, with her parents and Russian grandmother, Barbara (Babi) Federoff. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in memory of Christina B. Laney to: Riverside Park Conservancy, 475 Riverside Drive, Suite 455, New York, NY 10115. 1/3

Interment will follow in Holy Mount Cemetery in Eastchester. Memorial donations may be made in her name to The Jewish Home for the Elderly, 175 Jefferson Street, Fairfield, CT 06825.
